TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Jones (from 96 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 67 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Schacht (from 25 citizens) and Senator Short (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate In Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Senators to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Housing
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned concerned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that the report of the parliamentary committee of public works of the forty-sixth parliament concerning its inquiry into Aboriginal and islander housing--the future, should be rejected on the following grounds:

(1) The Committee failed to adequately consult the Aboriginal and Torres Strait islanders people of Queensland in order to obtain their views by failing to advise details of existing guidelines for funding of housing, failing to adequately publicise the committee inquiry through the established Aboriginal and Islander networks.

(2) The terms of reference were unsatisfactory insofar as they do not address the vital issue of tenant ownership which creates no incentive for self-determination and not enough time was given for the communities to study the recommendations of the infrastructure on Aboriginal housing as addressed by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

(3) Senior administrators of the Departments of Housing and Local Government will be delegated the responsibility of expenditure of funds, re-enforcing their existing mandate over administration and financial management and vetoing any decisions made by the Housing Advisory Council, who will be responsible to receive and advise policy development and implementation and oversee the menial day to day activities such as:
(a) Rent assessment
(b) Tenancy neglect
(c) Tenancy agreement based on cultural differences between land lord and tenant
(d) Tenant unions

(4) No Aboriginal housing trust exists in other States under the Aboriginal Housing Rentals program will mean no economic base or self management for urban and rural blacks and will eventually mainstream tenants and homes, creating further funding under the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement and an endless financial resource institution for the Department of Housing and Local Government.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Queensland will reject the report of the Parliamentary Committee of Public Works and conduct further consultations with the Aboriginal and Torres Islander people of Queensland so that a report may be tabled which genuinely addresses the housing needs of Aboriginal and Islander people in Queensland.

DEBATE.TITLE: CARRIAGE OF GOODS BY SEA BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Before the adjournment last night I was speaking on the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill. I was saying that the Bill deals with the liabilities of carriers in relation to goods carried at sea. I traced the history of this, going back to the first of the Hague Conventions in 1924, which tried to lay down some conditions as to where liability rested with respect to the carriage of goods. I said that there had been two amendments to the Hague Convention--the Visby Convention and the SDR Convention. We now have a new protocol before us which, rather than amending the Hague Rules, sets out an entirely new system under which liability will be assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pointed out that only some of the trading nations have supported the protocols that we have had up to the present. While the present Hamburg Convention has been agreed to for some little while, there is still a great shortage of support in the world community for countries to sign the convention. I wish to develop that theme. I mentioned that the Visby Rules, in 1968, were the first modification of the Hague Rules for some while. They were followed by the SDR Protocol amending the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules of Law Relating to Bills of Lading which was signed in Brussels on 21 December 1979.

I refer to the relevance of the Bill to Australia. The Australian shipping trade is largely invisible. People know that both passengers and goods move by air and road, but the whole subject of shipping in Australia is a relatively invisible operation. I have a personal interest in shipping because I grew up in small boats and yachts. When I was an undergraduate I worked as a seaman on the coastal trade and used to lump cargo. I think I am the only person in the Australian Parliament today who has actually been a wharf labourer. Some members of the Labor Party may have had union positions in sheds on the wharves, but I used to actually lump cargo. Furthermore, I did it for no pay and was never a unionist--fortunately. I have retained a residual interest in both the maritime trade and the wharf labourers' operations ever since.

There are in the carriage of goods by sea some real risks which are not always recognised. Recently the loss of an oil tanker off the Western Australian coast attracted a lot of publicity. Having spoken to pilots on the Australian coast, I know that there is a high level of concern about the standards of some of the ships operating into Australian ports and through Australian waters, and the procedures that the Australian Government has to adopt to supervise and correct those deficiencies. We have always had inspections of lifeboats and lifesaving gear, and many a ship has been failed on those grounds and been denied sailing rights until those deficiencies have been corrected. I think it is proper that we do that.

We have also had a marked concern about the conditions on board ship. Although I sympathise with those crews which are being exploited, I do not believe that it is the Australian Government's business to interfere in the terms and conditions under which crews are employed on overseas ships as opposed to being concerned about the seaworthiness and the lifesaving gear on the ships. My view, having spoken to pilots, is that the inspection procedures in Australia are nowhere near as comprehensive and as rigid as those which the Americans operate, for example in their coastguard, which has power to go on board a ship and demand that it be in a seaworthy state before it leaves port.

I am mindful of an incident that occurred in Townsville some weeks ago. A tug skipper complained about hull plating on an overseas ship in Townsville harbour, and the ship was taken to Singapore for repairs before it could be loaded. That illustrates my point that there is room to improve the Australian Government's surveillance capabilities.

Lest people think that the recent incident where an oil tanker lost its bow off the Western Australian coast is isolated, I point out that I was reading a publication recently that contained an editorial which began by dealing with a passenger liner off the South African coast. In one sense the incident reported on is quite hilarious. The Greek master of that ship was reported to be one of the first people to leave the vessel. He and his dog got on a helicopter, allegedly on the grounds that when they got ashore he would be able to supervise the rescue facilities even more efficiently than if he stayed on board. It is a creative thought with respect to the responsibility of a captain of a ship. When questioned about this, he allegedly said that the order to abandon ship applied to him just as much as it applied to the passengers, and if they wanted to do so they were welcome to stay on board the sinking ship. Although that is a rather humorous incident, it illustrates some of the variable standards that are applied with respect to the responsibility for the operation of ships.

If we look at the Western Australian situation, we find that eight ships have been lost there in the recent past, in fact since July 1988. In July 1988 the Singa Sea, under a Philippines flag, sank with 18 crew on board. Also in July 1988 the Korean Star, under a Korean flag, was wrecked off Cape Cuvier. The Alexander P, a Panamanian ship, in March 1990 sank in the Indian Ocean with 25 crew on board. The Sanko Harvest, again a Panamanian ship, sank off Esperance in February 1991. The Manila Transporter, a Philippines ship, went missing with all its crew in 1991. The Mineral Diamond, a Hong Kong ship, went missing, and then the Kirki suffered a fractured bow. Since then the Dacyang Honey, a Korean ship, in August 1991 went missing off the Western Australian coast. Eight ships have been lost in a relatively short period. This reinforces my argument that not all ships entering Australian ports and harbours meet the standards that we would deem requisite for safety for maritime trade.

It is interesting that we have not had any serious accidents with Australian flag ships for many years. I cannot remember when we had the last Australian flag ship incident--it might have been when the Anro went on the sand at Caloundra about 15 years ago, and that was hardly a serious disaster.

There is quite a degree of public interest in this. Of course, the environmentalists get into it and worry, with some degree of legitimacy, about what might happen if we had a big oil spill. The classic case of that which is always advanced is the Barrier Reef area. There are good reasons to demand that we have adequate standards of seaworthiness and seaman-like practice in the operation of ships so that we minimise the risk of accidents. We cannot really eliminate accidents. Regrettably, something will happen some time off the Australian coast that will cause us a great deal of damage but, by careful thought and the enforcement of standards, the probability of that happening can be reduced to the absolute minimum.

With reference to the Barrier Reef, it is often said by environmentalists that, if ships were sent outside the reef and far to the east, we would not have any problem at all. Anyone who has been in those waters knows that for about 10 months of the year there are 25-knot winds either from the north-east or the south-east. Any accident outside the reef would certainly lead to an oil slick washing onto the seaward side of the reef. In my judgment it would be infinitely better if ships operated in the constricted waters between the reef and the coastline, where the probability is that a slick will go onto the shoreline rather than onto the reef. That is a divergence, but it emphasises the point that I am making that concern for the operation of ships is a necessary duty of this Government.

What are some of the shortcomings of the Hague Rules which have led to the creation of this Bill? Shippers felt that it was necessary to amend them. One of the principal concerns is that the responsibility of the carrier is only tackle to tackle, and that the original carrier is not liable for transhipped goods and is exempt from liability for navigational error, mismanagement of the ship and fire, unless the latter is caused by the carrier's fault.

Other criticisms and concerns are that claims are time-barred unless suit is brought within one year, and that fundamental breaches of contract are not provided for--for example, undeclared cargo, unreasonable deviations, gross negligence or wilful recklessness. In particular, the shippers felt that the current rules concerning the liability burden rest largely with the shipper rather than the shipowner, who is the carrier and who provides the service.

These matters were addressed by the 1978 United Nations Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea, which led to the formation of the Hamburg Rules. As I said before, these do not have universal application yet amongst the trading nations. Certainly, none of Australia's major trading partners have as yet acceded to the treaty.

Australia's maritime trade is very important to us. We are not one of the great shipowners of the world, but we are still a major player in world shipping. In 1985-86 world seaborne trade totalled 3,385 million tonnes. Only about 8 per cent of this tonnage was in trade to and from Australia. Australian flag carriers represented 0.6 per cent of world tonnage in 1985-86 and carried 4.18 per cent of Australia's seaborne exports and 5.8 per cent of seaborne imports.

One of the great topical issues at the present time is the balance of payments position, which under this Government has blown out disastrously. We are losing on average $1,500m a month through spending more than we earn as a nation. It is a popular misconception that we are not exporting enough to cover those losses. Looking at the balance of payments figures, in a general sense, imports roughly balance exports. It is true that we might be down a few hundred million dollars one month and up a few hundred million dollars the next month, but the great loss on our balance of payment comes from what used to be called, when I was an undergraduate, the invisibles--services such as insurance, shipping and transport, services which we do not have in this country and for which we have to pay.

Of course, one cost that is now of major importance in the invisibles is the payment for the borrowing of money. Something like 20 per cent of our exports now go to pay the interest on the borrowings we have made because of the huge balance of payments deficit that we have. I argue that it is very important for Australia to address the area known as the invisibles and to stop borrowing money in the first case if it is possible to do so, cognisant of the fact that we have to pay our debts at some time.

It is also important for us in the insurance field, and particularly in the transport field, to retain and maximise Australian ownership. As only something like 4 per cent of Australia's trade is going in Australian bottoms, I think we ought to be working to lift that to as high a fraction as we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Hear, hear!

—-It is very good sense for us economically. I am glad the Minister agrees with me. If the Minister agrees with me, I hope he will overcome some of the enormous work practice disabilities, both on the waterfront and in the Seamen's Union, that make it impossible for Australian owners to compete. At the end of the day, the reason we do not own the ships is simply that it is not possible to earn an income out of them. It is only because of the loss-making of operations like the Australian National Line, supported directly or indirectly by the taxpayers' dollar, that we own any ships at all. Let us address the inefficiencies in the labour market which make it impossible for Australian shipowners to earn a living.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not much more I would like to say about the Bill, except I would like to make reference to the amendments which were circulated a few minutes before I rose to speak. I indicated at the outset of my speech that I will be supporting the amendments to be moved by Senator Macdonald. I think that the amendment to be moved by the Government, although I have not had time to consider it, goes some way towards meeting the Opposition's proposals. My only comment on it at this stage is that I cannot understand why it is so late coming around, given the fact that the Committee that looked at this Bill made reference to precisely the point that the Government is now moving to amend. At the moment, my view is to support the amendments to be moved by the Opposition.

In summary, the difference between the existing regimes and the proposals in this Bill is very important. Not everyone in the industry agrees with the proposals in this Bill, but everyone in the industry agrees that something has to be done to change the present situation. This Bill is a significant move down that path to satisfy their concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to address some of the concerns raised in the second reading debate. I particularly acknowledge Senator MacGibbon's very positive contribution to this debate, which I would like to respond to. Senator MacGibbon raised rightly the very serious problem that is alarming world shipping, which is the totally unacceptable loss of large bulk carriers which has become something of an international scandal. The International Maritime Organisation is, in fact, treating the matter with a great deal of seriousness and is conducting research into why we are losing so many of these ships with, as Senator MacGibbon correctly pointed out, a very high loss of life.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that are largely overlooked, certainly in terms of the press reports on these incidents, is indeed that loss of human life. People concentrate, understandably enough, on the very serious problems that are posed to the environment by these incidents. What is often ignored is, I regret to say, that seamen are going to sea in ships--these days, large ships--which are inadequately provided with lifesaving equipment.

Senator MacGibbon was concerned about the extent to which Australia is addressing the problem of inspecting these ships, and he compared the regime here with that of the United States. We have the same powers as exist in the United States, under the same international conventions to which we are a signatory, to detain ships and to prevent them from sailing or loading cargoes if they are found to be deficient.

We carry out inspections on about 25 per cent of all of the foreign flag ships that visit Australian ports which, by international standards, is a very high percentage. However, I take on board the concern that Senator MacGibbon raised because we are addressing the matter of increasing that surveillance. But to do that will obviously require significant additional resources. We are addressing the question of what additional resources will be required and how those resources will be provided; in other words, who will pay for them.

We are also addressing the question of the actual inspections themselves. Here, as in the United States, the inspections are largely paper inspections. Inspectors go on board the ship to find out whether the ship is carrying the necessary certification from the class societies to attest to its seaworthiness and to have a look principally at the lifesaving equipment on board the ship.
I regret to say that, of the 25 per cent of the ships that we have inspected in the last 12 months, we have had to detain 60 per cent for serious difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Even things like charts can be 30, 40 or 50 years old; they are not even updated.

—-I regret to say that Senator MacGibbon's information is correct. Even more regrettable is the very significant loss of human life that has occurred. Hundreds of seamen have been lost at sea in the past two years from these bulk carriers. In fact the last one went down only a few months ago off the coast of Western Australia. Only two of the crew survived and more than 20 seamen died in that incident.

SPEECH.PARA: If the market worked perfectly, which it never has and never will, these incidents would not happen because the class societies that carry out the inspections on these ships would provide proper advice to insurance companies, which would then either lift the premiums to such a level that it would be impossible for the ship to be covered, or they would simply refuse cover on these ships.

Regrettably, what is obviously happening is that internationally this is simply being factored into the equations. The premiums are simply being raised rather than addressing the real problem of trying to correct the serious deficiencies in these ships. One of the real concerns is that half of the 60 per cent of the ships that were inspected and detained in the past 12 months were detained because of failures in the lifesaving equipment on board.

I have to say, as I said publicly after the loss of the bow of the Kirki, that it is bad enough for a shipowner to send a ship to sea in structurally deficient condition but it is totally scandalous to send a ship to sea knowing that even if it gets into trouble the basic lifesaving equipment on board the ship is not capable of saving the lives of the people on board that ship. Regrettably, I have to confirm the accuracy of Senator MacGibbon's comments this morning.

The Government is currently awaiting completion of the maritime inspector's report on the Kirki. We expect that to occur within the next month. I am heartened by the concern expressed by Senator MacGibbon on this matter and, upon receipt of that report, I will bring it to Parliament. It will probably be worthy of a debate. We intend to support the actions that the IMO is taking by addressing this matter with the shipowners, the class societies that carry out the inspections, and the insurance companies that provide the cover.

We will address the problem on every possible front by whatever means are available to us in order to apply whatever influence Australia can muster so as to redress what is becoming an international maritime scandal. It has almost reached the stage where a latter day Mr Plimsoll is needed to redress the problem. All I can do is express my appreciation to Senator MacGibbon for the comments he made about what is a serious problem and assure him that the Government will act to do whatever is in our power to try to redress it.

So far as the Great Barrier Reef is concerned, again I am forced into a position of agreeing with Senator MacGibbon--that is twice in one morning. Options were put to the Government to take ships outside the reef because it was asserted that this would be safer. In fact, it would be horrendously more dangerous to the reef to do so. As Senator MacGibbon has said, it is not only true that the weather conditions are atrocious outside the reef, but also the area outside the reef is largely uncharted and is therefore considerably more dangerous to shipping. The result, as Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, of a major accident outside the reef would be as disastrous to the reef as if it happened inside the reef because of prevailing winds and tides.

Rather than accept that option, the Government moved successfully--I think it is the first time it has been done--within the IMO to provide a special classification, under the international conventions for the Great Barrier Reef as a special area, which requires compulsory pilotage on all ships in excess of 70 metres in length and on all tankers, irrespective of their size. That new regime for compulsory pilotage I am pleased to say came into effect on the first of this month.

I will now address some of the other matters raised. Senator Powell noted in her contribution yesterday that charter parties are not automatically covered by the construction and jurisdiction provisions of clause 11 of the Bill as they were previously under section 9 of the Sea-Carriage of Goods Act 1924. The reason for that is that the construction and jurisdiction provisions of clause 11 of the Bill have been brought into line with the way in which the charter parties are treated in the amended Hague Rules. Article 5 of the amended Hague Rules provides that the convention is not applicable to charter parties unless a bill of lading is issued under a charter party. Australian shippers have the right--under article 3, paragraph 3, of the amended Hague Rules--to demand and receive a bill of lading. So it is in the hands of the shippers. The parties to a charter party can therefore, at the shipper's insistence, be covered by the amended Hague regime simply by issuing a bill of lading which they have a right to demand under the rules.

Senator Macdonald in his speech yesterday raised concerns about the possibility of significant amounts of insurance--I think the figure he quoted was $80m--leaving Australia and going overseas. It is simply not possible to make that assertion; we do not know whether it will. I, personally, have enough confidence in the professionalism of the Australian insurance industry--which, in international terms, I can assure Senator Macdonald is no slouch when it comes to professionalism--in matching any need to provide a commercially acceptable package under these new rules. Senator Macdonald does not have much confidence in the ability of the Australian insurance industry to do this; I do. I think it has demonstrated its expertise many times over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not a correct statement, Senator.
—-I am simply quoting what Senator Macdonald said in Hansard. Australia has to become--
—-I did not say I had no confidence in the industry.
—-I am asserting that the honourable senator must not have confidence because he said that $80m of insurance business will go overseas.
—-I did not say that. You could at least try to be truthful.

—-That is in fact what Senator Macdonald said, and the Hansard record attests to that; I have it in front of me. I am saying that Australia has to become more internationally competitive in all sectors of its economy. That is something which the Opposition is constantly harping on and the Government asserts that we must do that as well. I can assure Senator Macdonald that that applies as much to the insurance industry as it does to any other industry in Australia. I have no doubt that if the Australian insurance industry finds itself becoming uncompetitive under these changed arrangements then it will adjust its commercial practices to ensure that it can compete with whatever challenge is mounted by overseas insurance companies.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the key to this legislation and to the amendment which the Government will move is that, as Senator Powell said correctly yesterday and as Senator MacGibbon has also asserted this morning, we are a shipper nation and not a ship-owning nation. There is no question, or indeed any argument from the Opposition, that it is undeniably to the benefit of Australia that we agree to the Hamburg Rules being applied because they will benefit the shippers.

I was astonished to hear Senator Macdonald's last point. He asserted yesterday that I had given a commitment in the meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to provide a prescriptive arrangement to act as a trigger for our trading partners. I must have been at another committee meeting because I did precisely the reverse, as the Hansard record of the Committee will show. I refer to the Hansard of the proceedings of the Committee on 22 August 1991 where, in response to that request to put in a prescriptive trigger, I said:

I have got a very strong objection indeed to putting in some artificial trigger based on the commercial appreciation we might have today and trying to second guess something that might be the situation three years from now.
I then went on to say:
But I am happy to agree to a sunset clause as long as it is in general rather than specific terms.

I then went on to give an undertaking to the Committee, which I will now discharge. When we agreed that we would not include any reference to the need for consultation in the legislation, I agreed to make a statement on the record as to the Government's intentions in this matter. I formally prepared this statement so I could show it to honourable senators before the debate. I have gone one step further, as Senator Macdonald would note from the circulated Government amendment. As well as making this statement, I have also added clause 6 to the Government amendment, which reads:

A Proclamation must not be made under subsection (2) unless the Minister has consulted with, and given due consideration to the views expressed by, representatives nominated by shippers, cargo owners, carriers and ship owners.

For the benefit of the Senate, the Government will adopt this position: the Bill provides that the Hamburg Rules will be kept under review in order to determine the optimum time for implementation. I want to make it clear that the Government will not be moving to implement the Hamburg Rules until it is in the commercial interests of Australia to do so.

I cannot be prescriptive about future events, but I can say that there will be no moves towards implementation until the Hamburg Rules have come into force internationally and a sufficient number of our major trading partners have adopted or expressed an intention to adopt the Hamburg Rules as the basis for their marine cargo liability regimes. Any decision on the timing for implementation will also be made on the basis of a broad and comprehensive consultative process with representatives of shippers, cargo owners, carriers and shipowners. Therefore, the decision will not be taken lightly. It will be made after consideration and consultation in order to be in the best commercial interests of Australia. I do not think I could be much more categorical than that. In being as categorical as that and in putting that on the record, I am sure that members of the Opposition will accept that that is precisely what the Government will be bound to do.

Reasonably enough, Senator MacGibbon raised at the end of his contribution the question of why the Government had only this morning circulated its amendment. As the Hansard will show, the Committee determined that we would agree to an amendment in the Committee that would provide for a situation where, if no proclamation was made before the expiration of three years, the Parliament would have an opportunity to consider the matter and review the situation and to proceed to ratify those sections of the Bill and put them into effect, or to continue the period of time or to repeal the sections of the Bill if so desired. We drafted such an amendment and circulated it.

The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, under the unremitting and diligent chairmanship of Senator Cooney, brought to our attention a concern that it had. I thought it was a little bit tendentious and pernickety, but that is Senator Cooney; he is scrupulous in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He understands legislation, which I do not think you do, Minister.

—-I will not respond to that. He is scrupulous in these matters. I took on board the concerns that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee expressed because I thought they were reasonable. The Parliamentary Counsel had drafted the amendment in strict accordance with the decision the Committee took. I think that is reasonable. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee pointed out that its concern was that there was a discretion provided in the amendment that the Government may consider and do certain things, and that that would leave a non-prescriptive result at the end of the line where something may or may not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Parliament is very much the master of its own destiny: this House certainly is, and there was no difficulty with that. But, in immediately agreeing to the concerns of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, we redrafted the amendment to provide for a certain outcome, one way or the other, at the end of that period. Senator Powell has already commented on the one fundamental difference between the Opposition amendment and our amendment. The amendments are largely very much in the same direction, as Senator MacGibbon has noted. The difference is that, in the Opposition's amendment, if there is no resolution of the question at the end of that period, the sections of the Bill requiring accedence to the Hamburg Rules will lapse. That is not in accordance with the Government's policy, which is why we do not find that acceptable.

We assert that Australia should be giving the lead in accepting the Hamburg Rules, and that is precisely why we have put it in legislation. We want to give a clear message to our trading partners and to everyone else connected with this business--and I can assure honourable senators that the message has been delivered--that we do intend, as a shipper nation, to agree to the Hamburg Rules because they are to the benefit of shippers.

I am frankly surprised--and I have put this to Senator Macdonald and indeed others in the Opposition--that some people in the Opposition seem to find this matter a difficulty. It is very much members of the constituency that is claimed by the Opposition--certainly rural Australia, farmers and so on--who will be the chief beneficiaries of agreement to the Hambto gloss over this but I know that there are parties that have some objections to this issue. Frankly, I do not think they are objections that they would die in a ditch over at the end of the day, because I think they accept that this move to a better consumer protection is inevitable. Their objections are principally from interests in the insurance industry.

As Senator Powell put it quite firmly last night, this amendment is a policy position of the Government. I am pleased to say, as asserted by Senator Powell of the Democrats, that we will provide this additional protection to our shippers. So the fundamental difference between the Opposition amendment and the Government amendment--which I hope that on reflection the Opposition will support--is that, if nothing happens after three years, under the Opposition amendment the sections of the Bill relating to the Hamburg Rules will be repealed. If nothing happens after three years under the amendment that we are moving, those sections will come into effect. It will take a positive resolution of the Parliament to prevent that from happening. As far as the consumers and our customers are concerned, that is the correct way to go, and I commend that amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Deputy President, under--
—-Mr Acting Deputy President--
—-Minister, did you want to speak on a point of order?
—-You might listen to what I am going to say.
—-Order! Are you seeking leave?
—-Leave will be denied. Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—-Under standing order 191, I would like to make a personal--
—-Order! I ask both senators to take their seats. Minister, do you wish to make a point of order?

—-Mr Acting Deputy President, this is the second reading debate. Senator Macdonald has already spoken. We are about to go into committee, where in one minute's time he will get endless opportunities to speak as many times as he likes. He has already spoken once. He has not sought the leave of the Senate that he needs to be able to speak.
—-On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Macdonald rose and was not heard for more than about two words. He wished to put a point. I think a gross discourtesy was done to him--

—-Senator Tambling, please take your seat. Senator Macdonald, I will call you in a minute. I understand you may have wanted to claim to have been misrepresented. The point I am making is that it would be easier for the Chair and the Senate if, when you rise to your feet, you say, `I am speaking on a point of order', or, `I claim to have been misrepresented'. Then you will be heard. The simple fact is that you should have not have got to your feet and attempted to speak without clarifying that point, because the Minister had closed the second reading debate. If you wish to rise to your feet and claim as you do so that you have been misrepresented, then by leave of the Senate you may be heard.

—-Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I got to my feet and said four words--`Mr Acting Deputy President'. I was not even given the courtesy of saying what I was getting up about. Under standing order 191, I claim that parts of my speech have been misquoted and misunderstood by the Minister. I do not think I need leave, but I seek to make that explanation under standing order 191.
—-You may make that explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I preface my personal explanation by saying that the Minister may have got away with these sorts of things in the Northern Territory Assembly, but he will not get away in this Parliament with misquoting me deliberately. He said that I said I had no confidence in the Australian insurance industry. I quote what I said from yesterday's Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that only 4 per cent of Australian cargo trade is carried in Australian ships. The Insurance Council of Australia Ltd has estimated that the value of this lost insurance business could be as high as $60m. . .
That is what I said. The Minister alleges that I said I have no confidence in the insurance industry--an absolute and outright lie and misdirection.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think I need to tell you what it is. I would like that withdrawn.
—-Senator Macdonald, the word `lie' is an unparliamentary term. Will you withdraw it, please?

—-I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I withdraw that. What the Minister alleges is an outright mistruth, and the record will show it. If the Minister had any decency, he would get up and apologise. Also, the Minister has claimed that I said that in his undertaking he would include prescriptive criteria in the Bill. I must confess that I have not been able to read through this in full. Again I will quote from what I said in the debate yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister--

expressed strong objection to including prescriptive criteria in the Bill on the grounds that trying to define an appropriate spectrum of trading countries could not take into account changing trade circumstances and would cause unnecessarily complicated provisions to be drafted. . .
I further said, as recorded at the bottom of page 1706:

The Committee went along. . . on the understanding that he will give a specific undertaking that the section of the Bill dealing with the Hamburg Rules will not be proclaimed until it is in Australia's commercial interests so to do. The Minister also agreed that he would give an undertaking to have comprehensive consultations with the industry and shippers prior to proclamation . . .
That is what I said. That is what the Minister said. I will not have the Minister saying that I was demanding that he give an undertaking as to the prescriptive criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That's what you said.
—-I did not say that. Again, the Minister is deliberately going out to mislead this Parliament and the people of Australia with what he says.

—-He may get away with it in other places--

—-Order! Minister, I am running this chamber. You do not need to give any direction. Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.
Amendments (by Senator Macdonald)--by leave--proposed:
1. Clause 2, page 1, subclause (2), line 8, before "Part 3", insert "Subject to this section".
2. Clause 2, page 1, add at the end of the clause, the following subclauses:

"(3) If a Proclamation under subsection (2) is not made within 3 years after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, Part 3 and Schedule 2 are taken to have been repealed at the expiration of those 3 years, unless, before the expiration of those 3 years, each House of the Parliament passes a resolution:
(a) that Part 3 and Schedule 2 are to commence; or
(b) that the question of the commencement of Part 3 and Schedule 2 be reconsidered, in accordance with this section, after a further period of 3 years.
"(4) If a resolution is passed in accordance with paragraph (3)(a), Part 3 and Schedule 2 commence on the day on which the resolution is passed by the second of the Houses to pass it.

"(5) If a resolution is passed in accordance with paragraph (3)(b), the period of 3 years referred to in subsection (3) is taken to commence on the day on which the resolution is passed by the second of the Houses to pass it.".
3. Clause 2, page 1, add at the end of the clause, the following subclause:

"(6) A proclamation must not be made under this section until the Minister has consulted with representatives of shippers, cargo owners, carriers and ship owners, being representatives nominated by those groups.".

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government will be opposing the amendments for the reasons I have just given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I shall assist the Chair by making the Australian Democrats' point with regard to the Opposition's amendments, although it has been clearly articulated this morning by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). Our concern about the Opposition's amendments is that the result of inaction by the Parliament during the next three years would lead to the automatic repeal of part 3 of the legislation, a section which is extremely welcomed by the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: From the outset the Democrats have taken the strongest view of all the parties in this place that the Hamburg Rules should be implemented, essentially because we are a shipper nation and we see those rules as most appropriate for our own interests; hence our concern, particularly as there is to be the opportunity for a change of government between now and the expiration of that three-year period. We want to do whatever we can to cement the present Government's stated intention, as expressed in part 3 of the legislation, that the Hamburg Rules be implemented. Therefore, we are not able to support the Opposition's amendments, particularly in view of the foreshadowed Government amendments which go in the direction that we would want to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-From the outset I must say that what we are trying to achieve receives support right across the spectrum. It is just a question of how it is best achieved. The amendments, which provide that, unless something is done within three years, the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill will be repealed, are moved to make the Government do something positive within that three-year period so that the Parliament has another look at the legislation and retains its primacy over this legislation. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was concerned that, unless some sort of sunset clause was put into the legislation, it could be passed today and go on forever: it may never be introduced or it may be introduced at an appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not carry on with this because it is fairly technical, but the debate is: if nothing happens in three years, the Government says that the Bill should automatically start. We are saying that if nothing happens it should be repealed, unless one of two things is done: first, that it be legislated to commence straight away or, secondly, that it be legislated to go for another three years.

I do not disagree with what Senator Powell has said. As the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) said earlier, we are in favour of the Hamburg Rules. I mentioned that in the second reading debate. There is no disagreement. It is simply a matter of which is the best way to introduce the legislation. We believe that it is better this way because it will force the Government to do something positive before that three-year period is up; that is, to bring it back before this Parliament.

If the Government's amendments are passed, it means that in three years--we could perhaps be in an election mode in the four weeks before that time--the legislation will automatically commence and legal rights will change from that point onwards. We may come back a month or so later to repeal the legislation. However, in that period we may have had a different set of rules, different legal obligations, different liabilities. Anything could happen which escapes the notice of Parliament in that time.

If the Government's amendments are passed, it will also raise some very interesting conflict of law questions because the legislation will automatically commence in three years time. There is another provision in the Government's amendments that says that the legislation will not be implemented until consultation has been had with the industry and until it is in Australia's interest, in accordance with the Minister's undertaking. If the three years happens to come up and none of that is done or there has not been consultation, another provision says that the legislation will automatically start. Where that gets the Minister and his draftsmen, I am not quite sure. Why we should bother to try to correct the mess that the Government makes of all these things is completely beyond me. We do it in an attempt to make the legislation better for Australia.

I cannot understand the way in which this particular Bill has been dealt with--it is my first experience; I am only a simple, honest country boy. Yesterday Senator Powell said that she would tell me this morning what she would do about these amendments. I am still waiting to be told. The Minister indicated that he would put forward amendments. The first I see of them is when they are thrown on my table. For the past two or three weeks while Parliament has been sitting I have been dealing with the Minister's office in a completely apolitical way in trying to get amendments drafted, trying to get the matter completed--showing every courtesy in trying to get the Minister's staff to do things. And what happens? Senator Powell does not do me the courtesy of complying with her undertaking by telling me what is happening; the Minister does not do me the courtesy of showing me the amendments. It just leaves me in some amazement as to how this Government runs its legislative program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Let that be a lesson to me. I regret to say that on future occasions I will ensure that all conversations with Senator Macdonald on these matters are made a matter of record. First of all, I reject categorically the outrageous assertions that Senator Macdonald has made about being ignored either by me or by my staff. If that assertion were simply directed to me I would ignore it because, along with all the other personal nonsense delivered in here by Senator Macdonald, it is not worthy of note. But I am certainly not going to have my staff--a very professional staff they are--attacked in this chamber when they are not able to come in here and defend themselves. My staff, as I know that not only members of the Democrats but also colleagues of Senator Macdonald can attest to, are unfailingly cooperative with any honourable senator who contacts my office; whether from the Government, Democrat or Opposition benches.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, this is not a complicated amendment. This is not a schedule of 80 amendments that would require days of consideration. As Senator Macdonald knows, this matter was debated at length with him at the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. We have provided this system, which I think is very beneficial, in order to discuss these issues in detail with officers at these committees. The facts are, and Senator Macdonald knows them as distinct from the sophistry he is delivering here this morning, that every one of us in this chamber--Senator Macdonald, Senator Powell, Senator Kernot who had this responsibility before Senator Powell, and myself--completely understands all the issues that are encapsulated in this simple amendment.

Senator Macdonald knows--because we had a discussion about it last night on the telephone, as distinct from his assertion that he had no notice of this amendment--that the Opposition's amendment and the Government's amendment are precisely the same in their effect. The one difference between them is that if nothing happens at the end of the three-year period, under Senator Macdonald's amendment the sections of the Bill will be repealed and under the Government's amendment--now indicated by Senator Powell to have the support of the Democrats, because as a policy position we want to see the Hamburg Rules adopted--those sections will come into effect unless Parliament determines otherwise.

On the final point, I completely fail to understand the point that Senator Macdonald was trying to make about this amendment being an attack on the primacy of Parliament. That is a complete nonsense. So far as legislation is concerned, Parliament will be in precisely the same position in two or three years time as it is now; that is, it will be the master of its own destiny. If various aspects of this matter are not sufficiently dealt with by the Senate or the House of Representatives, whatever complexion they may have at that time, then the Houses of Parliament will take legislative action, as provided for under this amendment, to ensure that the sections of the Bill are repealed or that the review will continue. The power that Parliament will have at that time will be precisely the same power as Parliament has now. It will do what it determines it will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

I am afraid that I learn but slowly and will understand in future that those sorts of undertakings given to me mean nought.
