PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1991 contains amendments which are before the Parliament largely as a result of the sale of media interests formerly held by the Fairfax group and relates to the consequences of the current proposal for takeover of the group. It is fair to say that the timing of this Bill is quite extraordinary and speaks volumes for the extent to which the Government at all times puts political considerations ahead of the welfare of the broadcasting industry and, indeed, the national interest in terms of the types of arrangements that we ought to have, particularly in the print media.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a notorious fact, which is not disputed on any side, that we currently have an overconcentration of ownership, and therefore control, in the print media. The real question is what ought to be done about that. It is in many respects very difficult to unscramble the egg. The critical point is that we ought to have policies in place which are able to be brought into effect at any time irrespective of particular events.

At the moment we are seeing quite the opposite. The Government, in a very strange exercise of timing, is suddenly putting before the Parliament some amendments which are not of huge significance but which will collectively and fundamentally, in one sense, impact upon the fate of the current bids for the Fairfax group. That is a very undesirable environment. It means that the way in which that bid proceeds, the way in which the ABT is enabled to consider the bid, and the way in which the Government assesses the merits of the bid, will all be affected to some extent by legislation which is before the Parliament at the moment.

It is a very unhealthy situation. It clearly means that there is a lot of jockeying for positions, and attempts somehow to favour one bid rather than another. There has been an avalanche of outpourings from Caucus, particularly its transport and communications committee, which makes it abundantly clear that the Government is preoccupied with picking the successful acquirer which it believes will be most suitable for its political purposes. Broadcasting legislation should reflect what is in the national interest and, in many respects, should try to ensure that there is not editorial intervention and that there are sound and profitable newspapers, not those that are subject to control and influence by those whose commercial interests in and around the communications sector might cause them to act in ways which do not advantage the readership of the newspapers and, in a wider sense, the public interest.

The Commonwealth has no direct power over newspapers, as we know, but there are cross-media ownership rules which currently limit an owner, who has a prescribed interest in a commercial television licence, to under 15 per cent ownership of a newspaper which is associated with the service area of the television licence or where the owner is in a position to control more than 15 per cent of the votes at a general meeting.

It should have been abundantly clear to this Government many moons ago that that was simply an invitation for smart operators to put themselves in a position where they could acquire a significant influence. That is precisely what Mr Packer has done through the Tourang vehicle. The figure of 14.9 per cent is nothing more or less than the maximum to which he is currently entitled under the Act. It speaks volumes for his future intentions, and one would have thought that anyone with the power, motivation and wealth of Mr Packer would probably be doing the same thing.

It is a bit late in the day for us to start hand-wringing and saying, `Well, why do you take 14.9 per cent? Why do you claim to have a passive investment? Why do you restructure in such a way that you create the appearance of an arm's length vehicle when either you are interested or you are not? If you are not interested, why do you acquire even a 5 per cent interest, let alone a 14.9 per cent interest?' If somebody is wanting to put up that sort of money, one assumes that it is not just for the sake of trying to maximise returns on investments. It is clearly a strategic holding in an industry of significance and sensitivity and one in which very big stakes are being played for. It is against that background that we have to assess this legislation.

It is quite clear that there has been a great deal of community concern about the implications of the Government's manoeuvrings, its attempt to advantage one bid or another. At one stage it was thought that most people in the Government and the major players, particularly the Minister, would have considered that Packer was likely to be of most political succour to them. In recent times it would seem that Mr Hawke now thinks that Packer is backing Keating and as a result they have gone cool on that idea.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Why not just act out of principle?

—- Absolutely, and I am endeavouring to make that point in showing that the Government is doing the opposite. We have all these stories about Dr O'Reilly being feted at the Lodge, wheeled up by no less a person than the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) who, I thought, would have no responsibilities in this chamber for these things. Obviously Senator Collins is always keen to push these matters, yet we have the spectacle of Senator Richardson buying into this.
—-He has wide-ranging interests.

—-He has, indeed, and one is entitled to ask why and with what in mind. I would have thought that it was abundantly clear, given Senator Richardson's track record, that the word `principle' never enters into his considerations. It is all to do with pragmatism. This is simply another of very many examples where Senator Richardson thinks there is a market niche for the power brokers of the Australian Labor Party, particularly its right wing. Despite the fact that he is at loggerheads with Mr Hawke, he is quite happy to go up to the Lodge and have a chat about media and other matters. It would seem at the moment, given the other derogatory statements that have been made about the AIN bid being an up-market establishment outfit, that the Government is basically hoping that it can advantage the O'Reilly group.

SPEECH.PARA: All of that is fairly transparent. What is particularly interesting in this situation is the analysis by Bryan Frith in the Australian of 18 September, in which he describes these current moves as really just for show--in other words, this whole Bill in many respects is a charade. The Tribunal itself through its Chairman, Mr Peter Westerway, has publicly confirmed its concerns about the extent to which it is possible for people to rearrange their affairs so as not to be technically caught by the cross-media limitations. Probably the most recent example of that was the Kimshaw case. The ABT found in June 1981 that the ownership structure of Kimshaw had been devised to serve one purpose only, and that was to preclude a breach of ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting Act without affecting the ownership of interests in the 2UE licence. That case centrally involved Mr Packer's interests. We already have a classic example of how it is possible to circumvent the apparent restrictions on media ownership.

There have been calls for mandatory pre-notification and pre-vetting, yet all this Bill does is serve up a pretty weak imitation of pre-notification, which leaves it up to the potential acquirer to make its own judgment as to whether it might transgress. That is simply an invitation to restructure, if that is thought to be necessary, or for those, who are not so minded to circumvent, simply to take the view that one is not likely to transgress the limitations and that one should go right on ahead. What then happens is that, having succeeded in one's takeover, one then gets bogged down in a hearing before the ABT, if and when it finally comes on. It is much more difficult then to unravel the deal.

The Government is fully aware of all those serious criticisms, yet it has chosen to serve up what Bryan Frith and others would regard as largely a charade designed to create the impression that somehow they are making life a bit more difficult for a couple of the bidders who have foreign ownership and, in Mr Packer's case, cross-media problems. But at the end of the day there is little doubt, I would have thought, that neither of those two bidders will be in any way disadvantaged if this Bill goes through.

Our primary concern at this stage is to have the Bill referred to the Senate Standing Committee and for it to be in a position to examine much more closely the implications of the provisions, and hopefully to take the matter a bit further in terms of the most desirable outcome. I would have thought that it was clear that we need to assess the extent to which the power to exercise control should include potential as well as actual control. We should also assess what are the consequences of putting in the associate provisions which apply in other areas of legislation--whether those imputing rights of associates to one another, not only for the purposes of notification of transactions but also for the purposes of the substantive rules, is a matter that should be pursued. Then there is the question of whether there should be a mandatory waiting period on a transaction once notified. Also, whether the ABT should have more power and not simply given what is clearly a totally inadequate period of some 10 days to assemble all its material, to go to the Federal Court and obtain some sort of injunction, and even then be required to give a surety as to costs if it judges that a potential bidder is not doing the right thing. I would have thought that that is putting the ABT in an impossible position. It may well be that the Tribunal, and indeed the courts, should have wider powers.

To the extent that the ABT is susceptible to other influences, perhaps the courts are a better place in which to vest those powers. Certainly, at the present time, there are huge areas of discretion. It is really a matter for personal judgment on the part of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) as to whether he has any problems with the foreign interest holdings of both Dr O'Reilly and Conrad Black. In those circumstances, one can well imagine the sorts of pressures that Senator Richardson and others will bring to bear on the Treasurer if they take the view that one bid rather than another ought to be aided. I would have thought that that was a quite undesirable situation as well.

At the moment it is only open to the Treasurer to take advice from the Foreign Investment Review Board and to preclude such levels of foreign ownership if he takes the view that it is contrary to the national interest. In recent times we have seen the latest charade by the Caucus subcommittee, which would allow people to have very substantial foreign involvement as long as, somehow, the equity interests do not attract voting rights. We all know that there are plenty of ways in which to exercise influence other than by having one's name upfront on the voting scrip. That is yet another example of those manoeuvrings to which I have referred.

We want the Bill to be referred to the Committee for close examination. We are conscious of the fact that the bids have to be tabled by next Tuesday, but we do not believe that they are likely to be significantly affected even if this Bill goes through, because it is quite easy to drive a coach and four through these provisions. The Tribunal and, obviously, the Receiver will have to make their own judgment about the quality of the bids.

We will certainly be urging that any decisions that the Government might make by way of intervention are made on merit--not simply reflecting the perceived political advantage that might flow from one consortium or another--and that the rules are fixed rather than applied on a case-by-case basis. For all those reasons, as I understand it, we will be supporting the Government and the Australian Democrats in having the matter referred to the relevant Standing Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am interested in this second reading debate on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and have a sense of deja vu, particularly when listening to Senator Alston's contribution. It has been a practice of past times that Senator Alston and I have handled these portfolios in this chamber. To look at this piece of legislation from the point of view of principle comes easily to me, having moved amendments in this place to reinstate the prior approval facility for the ABT--much stronger amendments than those we see before us in the legislation today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear where the Democrats stand on the question of the powers of the ABT. Indeed, we are disappointed with the scope of this Bill. The aim of these amendments, according to the press release of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley), is to strengthen the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to establish the facts on ownership and control of media outlets. As I said, that principle is something for which we have argued for a very long time--indeed, have even put it before this chamber by way of substantive amendments which, of course, have not been supported by either the Government or the Opposition.

We have argued the case since the Murdoch amendments in 1981. It is fascinating to reflect on the fact that a former Liberal government was responsible, via those amendments, for the weakening of the ABT in this very area. I understand from fairly widespread media reports recently that the former Liberal Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, has expressed some unhappiness with having presided over that move, as well he might. It puts some of Senator Alston's protestations about the weakness of the Government's actions in this case somewhat under a cloud.

The Bill falls very short of the Government's stated intention as well as falling short of promises made to the Tribunal and the expectations of the Tribunal. Once again, the Government fails to deliver the power that it has promised again and again to the Tribunal. It is important to say how pleased the Democrats are to see some moves, at least, in the direction of strengthening the powers of the Tribunal, even though there is no question that this move is motivated by the situation created by the Fairfax sales. Nevertheless, an opportunity is there, and it is for that reason that the Democrats want to put forward a series of amendments which would give some spine to this piece of legislation.

If the Opposition does fall behind some of the things that Senator Alston and the shadow Minister for communications (Mr Smith) have said, it will have the opportunity to do so as, at least in this chamber, we have the numbers between us. It is not a matter of standing up and making fine statements. It is a matter, as it always is in this chamber when there is a principle to be supported, of putting up amendments--in this case they will be put up by the Democrats--and the principle being put into practice.

I would not like to think that this piece of rather weak legislation--albeit motivated by current media machinations of ownership and control--would be all that would pass through this Parliament, but that we would be able to amend it and strengthen it. We will not be able to do that as eight Democrats, we will require Opposition support and that needs to be put on the record.

Australia's cross-media ownership laws are perhaps the only significant progressive advance in media policy implementation under this Government, certainly, and previous governments, for a long time. This short history is littered with examples of the Tribunal's powerlessness when faced with ruthless media proprietors determined to be the biggest cross-media owners, take things to the limits and do whatever can be done to circumvent those rules--rules which the Democrats welcomed when they were introduced, rules which are essential in this country to enable the media to be independent and broad-ranging and to contribute to our cultural and democratic processes.

Always, however, the Tribunal has been faced with the problem of unscrambling the egg. Senator Alston has already mentioned the example of Kerry Packer's Australian Consolidated Press owning television's Channel 9 and radio station 2UE concurrently, which shows how difficult it is to unscramble a
transaction after it has occurred, but it is not the only example of areas where the Tribunal has been faced with this problem.

The impending Fairfax sale is a major test of the effects of the cross-media ownership rules. We have heard in evidence given by the Managing Director of Tourang, Mr Trevor Kennedy, at the meeting of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Print Media on 1 October this year, that the amendments, at this point anyway, are totally ineffective and are simply readjusting shareholdings. Tourang has escaped the obligation to provide any information to the Tribunal, despite the number of unanswered questions about the roles of merchant banker, Mr Malcolm Turnbull, and Mr Trevor Kennedy in the syndicates, and the potential control that Mr Packer may exercise through them. All this Bill does is give the Tribunal permission to investigate a possible breach of the Broadcasting Act prior to a commercial transaction taking place, but only if the Tribunal can provide enough evidence to front the Federal Court to argue for an injunction.

The Tribunal is not being given the right of prior approval on media mergers or takeovers. The Tribunal is not being given the power to sanction or reverse a takeover after the fact. In addition, the Bill gives the Tribunal only a measly 10 days to collect enough evidence to justify an injunction.

The Bill is fatally flawed and, therefore, weak to the point of almost being totally ineffective. I intend to move amendments that will rectify what we see as the Bill's major inadequacies. As I say, we look to the Opposition for support for these improvements. One of the irredeemable flaws is that the amendments only deal with shareholding in media companies, yet the Act extensively covers the notion of control by other means; for example, control by directors. It would be commercially idiotic for the Bill to assume that because a person does not have a shareholding that person does not have control.

Rectifying this problem is difficult. The Bill needs to be altered to require a combination of shares and board positions to be considered when deciding whether a person has a requirement to notify the Tribunal. The simple alternative, of course, is to lower the threshold which is considered a prescribed interest for the purpose of notification to, say, 5 per cent. A more certain solution would be to require a more general obligation to pre-notify transactions, or, to adopt the simplest solution of all, remove the Murdoch amendments, satisfy Malcolm Fraser perhaps, and allow the Tribunal to have a priori approval of transactions involving changes of media ownership. This is the sort of thing that I have proposed in this place before by way of amendment.

Unless suitable amendments are made, unless we can come to some agreement here in this chamber and prevail upon the Government to carry it through in the other place, there seems to be very little point in having the so-called trip-wire for, like the Maginot line, it can be easily stepped over, as we have already seen. It is quite clear that the intention of bidders is there to do just that.

The Australian Democrats have difficulty in understanding the definition of associates. It is, if you like, a cute definition but it only applies for the purpose of notification and does not change the substantive law relating to ownership and control. The Tribunal could seek an injunction if it believed that there was a prima facie case of a breach. But it would still have to prove that a breach had taken place which, in practice, is difficult, especially with the fetters that have been placed on the Tribunal's capacity to elicit information. The question of the 10 days will be directly addressed by an amendment to be proposed by the Democrats and, hopefully, supported by the Opposition. Usually, burden of proof requires taking oral evidence from directors of the company, which could be very difficult, especially since the issue of control touches on what can be described as commercially sensitive areas. Why not deem certain relationships to be associates, along the same lines as in corporations law? The proposed definition of associate is too wide to operate as a deeming provision and would be unfair and unworkable. A simple solution would be to introduce reverse onus requiring those who are caught within the definition of associate to demonstrate that they are independent. This would considerably strengthen the chances of the Tribunal making a prima facie case.

At this point I feel a little cynical because the Bill appears, in this area any way, to almost directly contradict the Minister's stated intention. The facts of providing a prima facie case would be difficult enough for the Tribunal under any circumstances. But, as I have said, the 10-day period that the Tribunal has under this legislation to gather information and make a decision on a transaction is really an affront. In practice, it is often dealing with complex company structures.

If the Tribunal requests further information under section 89X, it must wait seven days unless it can prove that it is reasonable to shorten the time. The FIRB, for instance, is allowed 30 days. The Trade Practices Commission has sought 28 days for its pre-notification process. Why should the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal not be allowed a similar amount of time? Again I appeal to the Opposition for support on this matter.

The Australian Democrats also believe that the public interest is best served by the process itself being public and accountable, with an option for the Tribunal to grant confidentiality where appropriate to protect commercial information. This is the case under the Act as it stands, before this amending Bill is passed. I do not see any reason to change that. In fact, it is fundamental to the operations of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as a public watchdog.

We in the Parliament now have a chance because we have an amending Bill before us to rectify the mistakes made by both this Government and the previous Government in the area of media policy. We can now right the wrongs of the Murdoch amendments, and we have the power to embody the original spirit of the cross-media ownership rules into the Act. The original cross-media ownership rules are, as I say, really the only positive move to be made by this Government in media policy. But they have not really been significantly tested until now and, as I have already demonstrated, have not been properly and effectively implemented because the Tribunal has not had the power to do so.

This is really the challenge that is before us with this legislation. It goes beyond the simple question of one series of commercial transactions that are being contemplated right now, although nothing could really be more important than the fate of the Fairfax newspapers in this country. I do not want to give the impression that the Democrats do not have strong views about the need for that exercise to be resolved in the interests of a free, independent and Australian print media.

Paul Keating's famous dictum, `queens of the screen or princesses of the print', was a vivid acknowledgment of the need for greater competition, Australian ownership and diversity of ownership. At the time that statement was made by Mr Keating, the Minister, Senator Richardson, who is presently in the chamber, and I were serving on what I would call the ill-fated Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation which, of course, was the Committee which paved the way to hand over our television industry to three network operators. The business entrepreneurs salivated while the Committee sat, and then jumped in; some of them broke their necks on the bottom of the pool. It was the beginning of the breakdown of the Australian media operation, and we are still suffering, both financially and in terms of the media operation itself, as a result of what happened in television equalisation.

As I say, the only really positive thing that came out of that, and subsequent Australian Labor Party government media policy, was the cross-ownership rules. We are being tested on our commitment to those rules. Will we give the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal sufficient powers, not just in the context of the Fairfax takeover bids but in the context of our commitment to the sort of media that this country deserves and must have? Or will we allow to pass a piece of legislation which is weak in the extreme and which is expedient? Senator Alston is perfectly correct in stating that this Government's media policy has been a sham, a shambles and an economic disaster, not just for the business enterprises involved but also for our economy as a whole. The ordinary public is still paying, by way of foreign debt and by way of interest rates and so on, for that debacle. Will we let this happen or will we, in particular the Opposition and the Democrats, have the strength of principle to make significant amendments, workable amendments, to this piece of legislation to advance the interests of the Australian community, the Australian media and the Australian democracy as well as our culture by giving the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal some teeth and by backing up those cross-media rules?

When the Government implemented the cross-media rules, it was a step away from the media dynasty approach of the past. But the Government now appears to be hell-bent on creating new dynasties. Media ownership in Australia is at a watershed. The Government can either continue to change the rules, shift the goalposts, during the game as it has done through television aggregation and other policies--FM radio conversion and now pay television and foreign media ownership--or demonstrate maturity and commitment in its media policy by giving the Tribunal the power to implement its cross-media ownership rules. That is the challenge we face in this chamber today in the passage of this legislation. We cannot achieve a perfect world, but we can use this vehicle, this amending Bill, to do something positive by confirming our commitment to cross-media rules and to a broad, diverse and independent media in this country.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: --Now is an opportune time for me to speak to the motion while Senator Coulter is in the process of arriving. The Opposition supports the motion. I do not wish to turn this into another speech on the second reading debate, but there is a massive number of amendments before the Committee, most of which have already been agreed to. There is a further group of amendments foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats, which will be moved in due course by Senator Coulter.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology covers fully the discussions and the reasons why these various changes were made. As a result of those amendments, the Fisheries Administration Bill and six related Bills are considerably better than they were when first introduced into the chamber at the end of May. The Opposition appreciates the changes made and agreed to and trusts that discussion on the remaining amendments can proceed in order as soon as possible.

The issues that have caused many of the amendments to be put forward relate to the rights of fishermen to the resource. An issue related to membership of the various committees and their make-up from time to time. The Opposition believes that membership should be as flexible as possible and with as little direction as possible. There will be times when views on changes in directors and participants will differ. Accordingly, the membership of those committees should be left in as fluid a condition as possible.

The environmentally sustainable development aspects have received a lot of coverage and these, too, have caused a substantial number of amendments to be brought forward. That, together with the rights and privileges of commercial fishermen as against the amateur fishermen, will be one of the major items for discussion by the proposed authority.

The Fisheries Management Bill caused the majority of amendments to be raised. Both the Government and the Opposition now concede that this Bill will now make the management of fisheries much more satisfactory than it was previously. I believe that we should now proceed to deal with the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I apologise for not doing this earlier, but I table supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to the amendments to be moved by the Government to the Fisheries Administration Bill, the Fisheries Management Bill and the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today we are debating the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1991, which takes up many of the recommendations of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Report No. 3 of the Committee was the result of an inquiry into the conduct of the 1987 Federal election and the 1988 referendum. The amendments proposed to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 and the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act 1989 are generally of a non-controversial nature, and as such the Opposition does not intend to move any amendments. However, I would like to speak briefly to some of the proposed amendments, which I understand have subsequently been changed somewhat.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to section 44 of the Constitution, which provides, among other things, that any person who holds an office of profit under the Crown shall be incapable of being chosen, or of sitting, as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives. I understand from my own discussions with the Electoral Commission that it is not possible by legislation to define clauses in the Constitution. That is the role of the High Court of Australia. However, I am also advised that the High Court has never addressed itself to what constitutes an office of profit under the Crown.

Over the years this has created considerable uncertainty for candidates. I myself was a victim of this uncertainty. When I was appointed to the Senate I was the Deputy Chairman of the Queensland Institute of Technology. Notwithstanding that this was a totally honorary role involving no payment, I was advised that it would be prudent to resign, which I did. As a result of that, a clause was introduced to define an office of profit under the Crown. It also proposed that a new clause be inserted to provide that a person who is, at the hour of nomination, an officer of the Crown is not capable of being nominated as a senator or member of the House of Representatives.

We had some concern about the definition and the clause. Following our discussions earlier today with both the Government and the Australian Democrats, I understand that the Government will withdraw that clause. However, because of the uncertainties involved, I think an attempt to define an office of profit is worth while. One of our concerns--and this was spelt out by the Committee--involved a person having to resign from a position or office of profit. The definition is very broad and, as far as I can see, it would apply to people such as members of senates of universities and local government councillors or aldermen. Recommendation 11 indicates that the Parliament should legislate to provide that if, people have to resign, their positions will be open to them after they have completed the election campaign and have failed to be elected.

The Opposition will support the removal of the clause at this time, as I understand the Government intends to reintroduce some sort of definition between now and the next election. I believe that this would remove a lot of the uncertainty that currently exists. The Opposition's view is that as many people as possible should be able to stand for election to either the Senate or the House of Representatives. I understand that, historically--and it is not for me to decide what our founding fathers thought at the time--one of the reasons for this part of the Constitution, concerning offices of profit under the Crown, goes back some hundreds of years. It came about because many hundreds of years ago the king of the day had a habit of appointing his own people to the public service and there was concern at the time that the king's appointees should not be running the Parliament also.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is steeped in history.

—-It is somewhat steeped in history. The Government might look at the British system when it brings this clause back in an amended fashion. I understand that it is fairly prescriptive and actually spells out in detail the types of people who would be required to resign.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 13, which substitutes proposed new section 170, has been introduced in an effort to prevent a recurrence of an election result being voided by the courts because of a subsequent discovery that an elected senator or member was not an Australian citizen. Honourable senators will recall the case of Robert Wood. When it was found that former Senator Wood should not have been elected because he was not an Australian citizen, his place was taken by Irina Dunn, who Robert Wood believed would be a caretaker until he obtained Australian citizenship. It did not work out that way because Senator Dunn, once ensconced, decided that she enjoyed the life somewhat and refused to resign. If my memory serves me correctly, at the time Senator Ray said that his `faith in human nature was restored. Self-interest won the day'.

As Senator Wood's position as a senator was found to be legally invalid, the Government could have asked him to repay his salary, electoral allowances and other moneys paid to him. This debt was waived although, again if my memory serves me correctly, Senator Ray did pass the remark that it was tempting to attempt to recover the debt. The introduction of this clause will assist to some degree in preventing a recurrence. It could still occur, but it is an attempt to prevent a recurrence. Other parts of the principal Act provide fairly heavy penalties if someone does not tell the truth upon nomination.

Clause 18 enables the use of licensed premises as polling booths, provided that liquor is not available for sale in the vicinity. This is in accordance with the Committee's recommendation that the use of licensed premises was not desirable, except where no other premises were suitable. It makes sense in very remote areas, but it would be absolutely intolerable where other premises were available. I would like an assurance from the Government that that is the intent of the clause. The Committee gave the example of the ski resorts where, because no suitable premises were available, local residents and visitors were required to record declaration votes, and that caused considerable delays and problems. I would like an assurance from the Minister in his response that it is the intent simply to use these premises where no other premises are available. It should only be an exception.

Clause 22 amends section 245 of the principal Act to provide a new infringement notice system to those people who do not vote. It is equivalent to an on-the-spot traffic fine and was designed by the Australian Electoral Commission to reduce the administrative costs of pursuing non-voters. This means that voters are now being invited to pay $20 for the privilege of exercising their right not to vote. In effect, the amendment introduces optional compulsory voting: the choice is either to turn up at the polling booth and register to vote or contribute $20 to the Treasury.

Let me at this stage observe that it is apparent that the Government and the Electoral Commission recognise that they do not have either the capacity or the will to enforce a system of compulsory voting. Other comments could be made, but time constrains me from doing so. As all the clauses in the Bill relate to the unanimous support of the Committee, as indicated earlier, the Opposition will not be proposing any amendments either in the second reading debate or at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1991 amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 and gives effect to the recommendations made by report No. 3 of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Inquiry into the conduct of the 1987 Federal Election and 1988 Referendums.

SPEECH.PARA: It is indeed a very necessary part of our scrutiny that we have an opportunity to look at how we conduct our elections and referendum processes. It is helpful to us to have the recommendations of this Joint Standing Committee embodied in the form of legislation before us this morning. Some of the more positive aspects of it that I would like to comment on from my experience as a campaign director are certainly those which facilitate the ease with which candidates can nominate. For example, it seems to me entirely appropriate that we accept facsimiles in the process and that an agent, the registered officer or a deputy registered officer of a registered party can lodge nominations of all the party's endorsed House of Representatives candidates in a State or Territory with the Australian Electoral Officer for the relevant State or Territory up to 48 hours before the close of nominations. That seems to me an eminently sensible suggestion and, as an administrator, one that I really welcome.

I guess one issue of concern to the Australian Democrats that I wish to flag, and one which Senator Parer has already touched on, is the office of profit under the Crown. As he rightly said, it has been a matter of contention for a long time. I understand what the Government is endeavouring to do in its prescriptive definitions in clause 4. My concern is that, in making it quite clear that certain categories of people must definitely resign, recommendation No. 11 of the Committee was not able to be included. I would like to dwell on that for a moment.

Recommendation No. 11 of the Committee said that those people affected by the requirement to resign from an office of profit under the Crown before nominating for election to the Parliament of the Commonwealth for which they are subsequently unsuccessful should have their employment and entitlements protected by suitable legislation. While it is now very clear who has to resign and by what time, it is not clear under this legislation whether those people have any rights or entitlements to re-employment. That concerns us.

I am grateful for the Government's offer to consider our request to have that section deleted, not because we oppose the definitions but because the end part of the process is not in place when we embark upon the first stage. At the moment, a grey area exists that has worked to the advantage of some people. I would prefer that grey area to remain until we have the whole process in place.

We all know about people who have been caught up in whether to resign and, if they resign, whether they get their jobs back. I certainly know that in Queensland in the teaching profession it was a real risk to nominate to be a candidate for a political party. I would not want to see us put in place anything that inhibits any citizen from taking up the opportunity to nominate to be a candidate for an election for any party or to nominate as an independent. That is why I will be moving at the committee stage to omit the definition of an officer of the Crown. I apologise that the amendment is not yet formally in front of Senator Parer. Consequentially, I signal that we would then be opposing clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank Senator Parer and Senator Kernot for their contributions to the second reading debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1991. None of the provisions of this Bill are individually earth-shattering. However, collectively they form part of the proper process of continually monitoring, revising and improving the manner in which we conduct elections and, for that matter, referenda in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: One very worthwhile outcome of the establishment of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has been this continuing review and refinement. As many honourable senators will know, I have had a bit of involvement in the conduct of elections over time: I have won a few and lost a few. One thing that Australian democracy is enhanced by is the respect which people have for the electoral process. Overwhelmingly they have respect because Australian elections are well and fairly conducted and people are therefore prepared to accept the legitimacy of the process when they are unhappy with the political outcome.

We continue to do that in many minor ways. For example, Senator Kernot raised points about making it easier for people to nominate and about catching up with the technology regarding the authorisation of electoral material distributed by video. Neither of those changes makes a very big difference, but they are part of the process. When they are put together with the whole series of modifications that have taken place over the years they ensure that the electoral process has the respect of the electors. That is a fundamental prerequisite of a modern democracy. Therefore, it is a Bill which is minor in its content but is part of a significant process that ought to be continued. I thank the Committee for its prior work and the Senate for its support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3--by leave--taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 4, page 2, lines 20 to 39, definition of "Officer of the Crown", omit the definition.

As I said previously, it is not our intention to leave this matter in abeyance, but rather to assist the Government to bring the matter forward again, and at that time make sure that we have in place some provision that will ensure that those people who have had to resign in order to nominate as candidates for an election will have the protection of their entitlements and employment that they enjoyed before nomination. For us to have done that in the time available today would have been impossible, and the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill is not the appropriate legislation in which to do so. We need to go back and amend several Acts, such as those concerning the Defence Force, the Federal Police and other bodies.

I signal that we certainly wish to take that action and that when this Bill comes back before the Parliament, as it regularly does, we will be in a position to pursue this option. Although we understand the Government's intention in categorising and defining what constitutes an officer of the Crown, we think that to do so without having the end process in place is not at all helpful to many people who want to stand as candidates, who will have to resign their positions and run the risk of not getting those jobs back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-There is quite obviously bipartisan support for the attempt by the Government to define an officer of the Crown. The view taken is that there should be some protection for candidates who do stand for election and are unsuccessful. As I indicated earlier in the second reading debate, I think it is in the interests of the whole community that as many people as possible be given the opportunity to stand as candidates. There should be very few restrictions on them.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been cases where the uncertainty that abounded made people somewhat nervous to nominate because, even if they were successful, in a close election the opposition party of whatever colour could use the constitutional provision of office of profit under the Crown to challenge a person who was subsequently elected. I suggest that a simple way of approaching this may well be for the Government to look at the timing of the resignation. I do not know whether that is constitutionally possible. If people could resign at, say, the declaration of the polls, it would solve the problem. If someone stood as a candidate and was not elected, there would be no need to resign whereas, if that person was elected, he or she could resign at the time of the declaration of the polls.

The Opposition will support the Democrat amendment, on the understanding, having had discussions with the Government, that the Government intends to introduce some sort of legislation between now and the election to get rid of the uncertainty that has existed for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I think has been indicated previously by the Minister, the Government is prepared to accept this amendment. We understand that there is shared concern. I think all the parties and all the people represented here are trying to achieve the same outcome. It is a question of getting the right process. The Minister has advised me that he is happy to assure the Senate that we will come back to this issue as soon as we can to try to get a comprehensive and agreed position that will deal with the issues that Senator Kernot and Senator Parer have raised. I am happy to incorporate those points which they have raised in the discussion on the consideration of how the matter might best be resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: An immediate reaction of my own, without advice, is that there is a potential problem in the option which Senator Parer raises, in that we get to a situation where, at least technically, a person who is nominating for a seat is not eligible to hold the seat. That is the contingent problem we have, but it may not be impossible to resolve. That is just a first reaction to a problem that has arisen in the past. It may be that, with ingenuity, some mechanism of the sort Senator Parer suggested ought to be considered. I will certainly raise that point in the discussions we have to try to lead to some agreed outcome on this matter. On that basis, we are prepared to accept this amendment and, consequentially, the amendment to clause 10, to which I will not therefore speak. I simply indicate that will also be our attitude to that amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 5 to 9--by leave--taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10 negatived.
Remainder of Bill--by leave--taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to make mention of clause 18, to which I referred during my speech in the second reading debate. It was of some concern to us that there was a possibility that licensed premises would become the order of the day rather than the rarity. I raised the point that the clause is acceptable to us on the basis that it is sensible, even though it is a requirement that no liquor be available within the vicinity of the polling booth, for example, to allow liquor on licensed premises in remote areas. The example given at the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters was that of ski resorts where people are required to lodge declaration votes because no other suitable premises were available. I make the point that it would be absolutely abominable and appalling if licensed premises were used when there were other suitable premises available. I would like the assurance of the Government on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My understanding is that certainly is also the Government's intention. We do not want to make this the new norm but, rather, we want to be able to cater for the necessary exceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
