SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Senate is debating a package of six very important Bills relating to the insurance and superannuation industries and, in particular, to the supervisory arrangements and prudential requirements associated with those industries. They are extremely important industries, given the growth in recent years and the foreshadowed growth in the years ahead in the superannuation industry and the superannuation funds available for investment in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: During the past decade, we have seen a growth in the assets of superannuation funds from $15 billion or thereabouts a decade ago to well in excess of $100 billion now. On the estimates of some, that figure will increase to no less than $600 billion between now and the end of the decade. Even if that figure is an overestimate--and I think it probably is--there still will quite clearly be enormous funds involved in superannuation over the years ahead, particularly with the advent of occupational superannuation as introduced by this Government--compulsory superannuation contributions--which will impose enormous additional costs on industry unless they are met by increases in productivity by industry or through corresponding wage reductions, in the sense of wage increases being less than they otherwise would, to take account of this increase in superannuation.

Let me make it clear at the outset that the Opposition supports the increased coverage of the work force through private superannuation schemes. That is a matter on which there is no disagreement between the major parties. However, we do have a significant disagreement as to whether the increase in superannuation coverage ought to be enforced in the compulsory way in which the Government is currently imposing it on industry. We believe that that is an objectionable way of going about the matter because it will cost jobs. The one legacy of this Government in the last couple of years has been the enormous job destruction and the loss of hope and opportunity--particularly for young people--in the job market that we have observed.

Today's figures for unemployment, released just an hour ago, show an enormous further increase in unemployment to a level of 10.2 per cent Australia-wide. Virtually every State of Australia now has unemployment officially running at levels of 11 per cent or more. The only two States where unemployment is now less than 10 per cent are New South Wales and Queensland, where the percentages are said to be 9.8 per cent.

As we all know, those figures are in any event a major understatement of the level of unemployment. The figure of 872,100 for seasonally adjusted unemployed persons at the end of September--an increase of 31,600 in the last month alone-- is an horrendous figure in its own right. It is even more horrendous when it is recognised that it is a major understatement of the level of unemployment in this country. The real level of unemployment is well over one million people. That is the legacy, the absolute tragedy, of the eight wasted years of disastrous economic policy of this Government.

The subject of superannuation is of great importance. As I say, the coalition is in agreement with the Government that we need to have increased coverage of private sector superannuation schemes because, with the growth in proportion and the absolute numbers of people who will be of retirement age and beyond over the next 10, 20, or 30 years, it is quite clear that the public purse will not be able to provide the retirement income that is necessary in a society such as ours. We will have to rely much more than we have in the past on the growth of private sector savings so that people can provide more for their own retirement.

In that capacity superannuation is one of the major forms of such provision. Therefore, it is of great importance that the funds that average Australians put into superannuation and savings for their retirement be protected to the maximum extent possible. An important element of the Bills before the chamber today does relate to putting increased supervisory arrangements and prudential arrangements in place so that the safeguarding of those funds can be protected.

In passing, I will just say that the growth of superannuation in Australia will raise some fundamental questions as far as the whole role of savings and the different forms of savings in our economy are concerned. That will have enormous economic impacts and impacts on investment and the whole growth of our economy.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The issue that I want to raise today relates to the tabling in the Parliament of the various reports by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner for the Northern Territory. Three reports were tabled in the chamber this week, but the issue is much broader and reports regularly come before the chamber. This week a report by then Mr Justice Maurice, Aboriginal Land Commissioner, on the Warumungu land claim was tabled. That report was made to the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand, and was dated 8 July 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The second report that I refer to is the report by Mr Justice Olney to the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Robert Tickner, with regard to the Wakaya-Alyawarre land claim. That report is dated 8 May 1990. The third report to which I refer is the report by Mr Justice Olney specifically relating to the Western Desert land claim; it was presented to the current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, and is dated 24 September 1990.

I am concerned that the presentation of these reports has been so tardy. In the case of the Warumungu land claim, three years elapsed between the date on which it was relayed to the Minister and its presentation to this Parliament. The other reports were nearly 1 1/2 years old and one year old before their presentation to the Parliament. I find that most unsatisfactory. It does not contribute in any way to the proper administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.
I will deal with each of the reports. It is interesting to note their current status in dealing with issues that have been raised and in the determination of land grants for particular people.

The Warumungu land claim is a very significant one. The relevant land basically surrounds the town of Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory. There is immense community interest in the claim, particularly among the Aboriginal traditional owners of the area. The Northern Territory has acceded to stage 1 of the claim and the Commonwealth has granted two portions of this area. Stage 2 comprises stock route reserves held by the Northern Territory Land Corporation which the Northern Territory Government is willing to acquire to facilitate the grant to claimants subject to satisfactory agreements pursuant to section 11A of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

I understand that today the Central Land Council has refused to countenance section 11A agreements notwithstanding that this arbitration mechanism was specifically inserted into the Act to overcome such difficulties. The Northern Territory Government and the Central Land Council have agreed in principle to the grant of the stage 3 area, which involves withdrawal of the claim to the land covered by the Tennant Creek draft structure plan, in return for the acquisition and grant under Territory title of land owned by the lessee of the Phillip Creek pastoral lease and the Conservation Land Corporation.

With regard to the claim in respect of Wakaya-Alyawarre land claim, the offer of Territory freehold title was made to the claimants through the Central Land Council prior to the hearing. This offer was not accepted except by Mr Jack Punch, one of the persons claiming traditional ownership, who wanted to establish an out-station in his country. Mr Punch insisted that the claim in his name be withdrawn in return for assistance with out-station development.

The Arruwarra estate of over 5,000 square kilometres was granted as freehold under the Northern Territory Crown Lands Act in December 1989. A large portion of stage A of the claim was not recommended for grant and is now subject to a repeat land claim. That is a separate issue relating to repeat land claims and I think it needs closer attention by the Minister, and certainly, in the future, by the Parliament. It is an issue that I believe the Liberal and National parties would give specific attention to in the future.

The western land claim area adjoins the Western Australian-Northern Territory border. This area was subject to two land claims. Two large portions were not recommended for grant. As the earlier claim, No. 27, has not been withdrawn, effectively a repeat claim is in place. The Northern Territory offer of Territory freehold to the total area has been repeated since the inquiry but, I understand at this stage, with no response.

These reports demand the attention of all people who have interests in these areas. They affect the long term commercial viability of the Northern Territory in many areas of economic activity, be they mining or pastoral pursuits. And, very importantly, they affect the lifestyle of many Aboriginal people and the conditions under which they live in the Northern Territory. I would hope that they will receive attention much more promptly than the Minister has obviously been able to give in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to respond to answers given by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook, to questions about the Robe River Mining Co. and, in particular, its Cape Lambert Services. Firstly, on 5 September Senator Crowley asked a question which was deliberately designed to defame Robe River Mining Co. Secondly, I asked questions on 9, 10 and 11 September 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: In his answers, Senator Cook, quite unfairly and without justification, abused and maligned a good Australian company, a company which has lifted its performance to best world standards. In fact, Senator Cook has misled the Senate in his answers. He has not told the truth. This disgraceful episode denigrates the rule of law and demonstrates clearly that he is a puppet of the union movement. He should either apologise, not only to Robe River Mining and the people of Australia but also to the Senate, or he should resign.

What has Robe River Mining accomplished? It has lifted its loading rates from 2,000 tonnes per hour in mid-1986 to 5,000 tonnes per hour in mid-1991. The frequency rates for all injuries have dropped from 433 to 268 in the same period. In 1986-87 there were 63 lost time injuries and in 1990-91 there were 12. Ships residence port time has dropped from 173 hours prior to 1986 hours to an average of 74 hours today. Tonnage output per employee for the years ending March 1985, 1986 and 1987 was approximately 10,000. This has risen to a staggering 31,000 tonnes per man, per year at March 1991.

Rather than criticising and maligning Robe River Mining, Senator Cook should be recognising in a positive and constructive way the achievements of management and congratulating the current work force for their achievements. Robe River Mining has achieved a 400 per cent increase in productivity. This has been achieved by workplace reform.
I would now like to look at the detail of the answers given to the Senate and why I contend that Senator Cook has misled the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator, on the question of misleading the Senate, I think you might have meant to use the words `may have' or `inadvertently'. In other words, you cannot attribute unparliamentary motives to particular Ministers. You also raised the question of the Minister telling an untruth. I allowed you to continue speaking. But I would remind you that it might be a better idea if you were to withdraw that remark and say that he may inadvertently have indicated something to the Senate which was not the case. It is up to you to rephrase it.
—-Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will rephrase it and say `why I contend that he may have misled the Senate'. On 5 September Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1989, in cases involving the Seamen's Union there have been some eight appeals by Robe River to the Industrial Relations Commission's Full Bench and two appeals to the High Court. The actions have all been about whether or not the same conditions that apply at all other ports in Australia should apply at this particular port, Port Lambert.
In essence, the outcome of these appeals has been for the Seamen's Union to be upheld in all cases.
Further, in answer to my question of 11 September, he said:

I have the details of the eight appeals here. They start from 13 June 1989--an appeal by Robe River against a Commission decision, dismissed. There was another on 6 September, dismissed; another on 5 October, dismissed; another on 8 October, dismissed; another again on 8 October 1990, dismissed; another on 19 June 1991, substantially dismissed and part of it referred for another hearing; another on 19 June, and the same result for that; and another on 22 July.
I contend that these statements are totally misleading, that they misrepresent the facts.

The first appeal date named by Senator Cook was 13 June 1989. Senator Cook claimed that the case was dismissed. He is patently wrong. The appeal was withdrawn on 26 November 1989, not dismissed. I contend once again that Senator Cook has misled the Senate on the outcome of this hearing.

A further appeal by CLS was lodged on 28 July 1989. This one, which Senator Cook chose not to mention, was against an award which was brought down on 21 July. On 26 September 1989, by leave of the Commission and with the consent of the unions, the reinstatement award against which this appeal was lodged was set aside and the appeal then dismissed. Hence, this appeal was in favour of CLS.

The second date mentioned by the Minister, 6 September 1990, was in fact a decision and award--the Engagement of Labour (Interim) Award. CLS lodged an appeal against this award on 7 September 1990, not 6 September. On 28 November 1990, the Full Bench issued a formal order quashing the award. In my view, Senator Cook once again has misled the Senate in stating that this appeal was dismissed. In fact, it was found in favour of CLS.

The next set of dates nominated by the Minister was 5 October, 8 October and, again, 8 October 1990. Senator Cook claimed that there were three appeals. However, here Senator Cook is double dipping in an endeavour to make up his numbers. There was an appeal on 5 October and this appeal was amended on 8 October. That is only one appeal and not two, as claimed by Senator Cook. There was another appeal on 10 October 1990, which I assume is the appeal Senator Cook referred to as being of 8 October 1990. Both these appeals were dismissed in favour of the unions. However, once again I contend that the Minister may have misled the Senate--there were only two appeals, not three.

The next dates nominated by the Minister were 19 June 1991, with the professed outcome of `substantially dismissed and part of it referred for another hearing', and once again 19 June 1991, with `the same result for that'. Once again, I contend that Senator Cook may have misled the Senate. Let us examine the facts.

On 19 June 1991, Commissioner Fogarty found a dispute and made the Recruitment of Seafarers Award and the Preservation of Employment (Interim) Award. On 8 July 1991, not 19 June, CLS filed an appeal against the Preservation of Employment (Interim) Award. On 9 September 1991, the Full Bench of the Commission found that there was an arguable case that CLS may have been denied natural justice when the Preservation of Employment Award was made. It directed Deputy President Harrison to make a report on various matters and that the hearing on the appeal continue in the light of that evidence.

I contend once again that Senator Cook may have misled the Senate with regard to the decision on 19 June 1991. There was only one appeal, not two, and that appeal was lodged on 8 July 1991. The appeal was not substantially dismissed and part referred to another hearing; it was referred in total to another hearing. In fact, in the final analysis, both awards--the Recruitment of Seafarers Award and the Preservation of Employment (Interim) Award--were set aside from midnight on 23 September 1991.

The final date nominated by the Minister was 22 July 1991. The Minister never stated the outcome but inferred that the appeal had been dismissed. There was an appeal lodged on 22 July 1991 which, with the consent of the unions, was adjourned on 3 September. It certainly was not dismissed.

In summary, the Minister nominated eight appeals by CLS and the days on which they were made. In fact, only six related to the nominated dates. Only three were nominated on the actual dates, and only two were upheld in favour of the union.

With regard to the appeals nominated by the Minister, I believe that the Minister has blatantly misled the Senate as to their outcome. It is a disgrace. The Minister should hang his head in shame. He hides behind parliamentary privilege and slanders the Robe River Mining Co. before the Australian public and the Senate. The Minister should immediately apologise or resign.

The Minister also claims in his answers that the Seamens Union wants the same conditions that apply in all--and I emphasise `all'--other ports in Australia. I contend that this is once again a misleading statement. The conditions vary, in fact, and are not consistent from port to port. The Minister then goes on to claim that CLS deliberately contrived to go into voluntary liquidation. He said:

. . . it goes into voluntary liquidation and another company is contrived to take its place and the process commences again. It is not unreasonable either to speculate that should the same processes be replicated with this company, as one would expect they would be, when the outcome is arrived at again and the final appeal source is exhausted, the existing company will go into voluntary liquidation and a new company will start.

What an extraordinary, incredible, unfounded statement. It is the statement of a desperate man who has lost his sense of balance, his rational judgment and his ability to be objective. It is a tragedy that a Minister of the Crown who should be setting the example in terms of world best practice should malign those who do.

Senator Cook and his mates are objecting to Robe River contracting out its towing service. Let us examine Robe River's history in contracting out its services--a policy which Robe adopted in 1987. For example, it has contracted out rail haulage, the electrical service, the catering service, on-site shops and plumbing services.

The following points should be noted with regard to the contracting out of towing services. Cape Lambert Services does no outside commercial work. Notice of termination of employment was given from early February 1991 for 30 June 1991. The decision to end Cape Lambert Services was no surprise. On 11 May advertisements were placed in the Courier-Mail, the Australian, the Melbourne Age and the West Australian seeking expressions of interest. Eight replies were received, including replies from Brisbane, Perth, Port Hedland, Darwin and South Australia. Westug, which is a privately owned company, was awarded the contract. The savings to Robe are enormous: $1.6m in the first year and $0.6m in subsequent years. Once again, I contend that Senator Cook may have misled this chamber.

Robe River has not contrived a new company. It has rearranged its business and contracted out a service to an independent operator, which is Robe's legitimate right. I repeat the statement that I made at the commencement of this speech: the Minister may have misled the Senate. I believe that he has been dishonest. He has been deceptive in answering a dorothy dixer asked by Senator Crowley on behalf of his mates. He has resorted to verbal thuggery against a company that has had the guts to eliminate weak management and stand up against union thuggery. The Minister has consistently said in this place that the umpire's decision should be obeyed, particularly with regard to the meat industry. The Minister now maligns Robe River for using that very umpire. The Minister should apologise to Robe River.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Don't address it to me.

—-Senator Ray is laughing. Maybe he thinks it is good. The Minister should apologise to Robe River. It is a company that is operating at the best world standards and within the law. The Minister should apologise to the Australian public and to the Senate for what I believe are misleading answers. In fact, he should apologise for being dishonest.

—-Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order on the use of the word `dishonest', which I believe is unparliamentary. It would probably be appropriate at this stage for the honourable senator to withdraw that and replace it with something which is parliamentary.
—-I will withdraw the word and replace it with the words `may have misled the chamber'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: --This morning I presented a petition to the Parliament from nearly 300 Australian citizens concerning the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. As a result of restructuring within the Organisation, there are some serious implications for engineers that I think should be drawn to the attention of the Senate. I propose to do so today by reading a letter that was sent to me by the professional officer technologists in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation together with the petition that I presented this morning. I do so because not only is it an issue of importance to those individuals--and I sympathise with them in the difficulties that they are facing--but it is an issue of great importance to the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: We are constantly being informed that the way ahead for Australia is that of a clever country. We are being told that science is the way that Australia can develop and grow. But we seem to be neglecting the fact that science is only one part of the equation. Engineers and the technology in which they have great competence tend to be ignored. That is why I wish to read to the Senate the letter from the Chairman of the Professional Officers Action Committee of DSTO. It states:

A unilateral salary and conditions determination on behalf of the Research Scientists in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation . . . has now created a situation in which the non-Research Scientists are debarred from SES equivalent positions. They are now unable to achieve the more senior levels in the DSTO and the Services will as a result not have access to advice at the more senior engineer level.

At a recent meeting of over two hundred Professional Officers at DSTO Salisbury, considerable anger was expressed at the effective termination of career prospects resulting from an award in favour of another group of professional staff. This has denied the reasonable career expectations of the majority of the professional staff at DSTO. At this meeting a committee was formed (The Professional Officers' Action Committee) with the purpose of working with the DSTO management and the relevant associations to find a way of resolving this problem.

A subsequent survey by the committee of Professional Officers within the DSTO has identified a further substantial group with concerns on this issue. There has thus been identified a total of over three hundred non-Research Scientist Professional Officers who are concerned about their career prospects as a result of this award. This is a very large proportion of this category of professional staff of the DSTO.

The enclosed petition is a result of the outcome of the different paths employed to implement the Structural Efficiency Principle at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, as applied to Professional Officers and Research Scientists. The determination for Research Scientists was brought about by a work value case while the Professional Officer Technologists were not accorded equal treatment under the Professional Officer structure.

The petition is a register of protest by a large . . . cross-section of those previously surveyed, and indicates the extent of the feeling of these important members of the Defence Community, regarding:
1) Loss of career prospects within DSTO for Professional Officers against Research Scientists.
2) Loss of salary relativity of Professional Officers with respect to Research Scientists without a demonstrated change in relative work value.
3) Diminution of the professional status of Professional Officers through a policy of denial of Senior Management positions to Professional Officers in DSTO.
4) Deterioration of workplace relations between Professional Officers and Research Scientists.
5) Less flexible working arrangements between Professional Officers and Research Scientists.
6) Professional Officers performing work and carrying responsibility at the same level as Research Scientists but receiving a lesser level of professional recognition and remuneration.
The letter goes on to say:

We feel that a gross misunderstanding of the values of this category of Defence Professional has taken place vis-a-vis that accorded to the Research Scientist category. It has to be understood that a very large part of the acquisition, enhancement, capability improvement and life extension of all the Services' equipment is primarily undertaken by non-Research Scientists.

What is particularly relevant is that the new award to the Research Scientists was made under the guise of the SEP and, it was claimed, was based on the similar CSIRO re-structuring. In both areas there has been demonstrable misrepresentation. In the first instance there is no way in which the spirit of SEP can have been enhanced by this biased decision and, in the second instance, the CSIRO case explicitly combines the Research Scientists, Experimental Scientist/Officers, Engineers and other professionals in a single structure which recognises skills and abilities, not prime degrees.

It is noted that the Prime Minister's Science Council has recently considered the state of engineering in this country and what ought to be done about it. That development of a strong engineering base is crucial to the return of a prosperous economy, is internationally acknowledged.

Australia has for years suffered from an `egg head' syndrome, in so much as this country produces an imbalance of Scientists in relation to Engineers and other Technologists, compared with other developed countries.

For instance, Australia has three science graduates to Japan's one, Germany's one and USA's one. By comparison, we have one engineering graduate to Japan's five, Germany's three and USA's two. The letter continues:
The policy adopted by the DSTO is to further repress the very talents that are needed both in Defence and in Industry to make this country prosperous again.

While, in the case of DSTO, senior management positions are denied to Engineer and other Professional Officers, the best interests of the ADF are not being served. That such a unique and valuable personnel resource is being lost to Australian Defence by inept management is unacceptable. Balance between Science and Technology is required to ensure that the necessary breadth of support is available and can be provided to the ADF both in peacetime and in times of National emergency.
What the Professional Officers want to achieve is:
1. An acknowledgment that Technology is equally as important as Science in support of the ADF.
2. A reinstatement of not less than previous relativities between Research Scientists and Professional Officer Technologists (viz. Engineers and Experimental Officers).

3. The re-establishment of a Professional Officer senior management structure (cf. CSIRO Senior Specialist in attachments) aligned with its own field of responsibility to give proper credence to the term `Technology', in the organisation's title: Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

4. To establish (if required, through the same work value path used in the case of the Research Scientists) the principles and foundation of a balanced structure between Research Scientists and Professional Officer Technologists.
Your active support in this ambition is sought through this petition.
The letter concludes by saying:

I would urge you to institute your own enquiries into this situation with a view to correcting the damaging effects it is having on the capability of the DSTO to respond to the needs of the ADF in a time of National crisis.

I am very glad that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) was here today while I read that letter, because I think it is a very important letter which should be taken into serious account by the Government. I hope that the Minister will do so.

When the restructuring of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation was announced several years ago, the Opposition supported the moves which the Government was proposing to make to give greater emphasis to the scientists and engineers in that organisation and less to the tradesmen, if you like, who were used in the development of projects. The emphasis was--rightly, we believed--on the fact that developmental work was properly and usefully the province of private industry, which could work in cooperation with the DSTO, but that the innovation, the research and early developmental work were properly the province of the scientists and engineers of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

I should point out that we have long had great difficulty in retaining scientists and engineers in public employment because of the salary levels which are applicable to such people in the public sector. It has been recognised that, if hopefully we are to retain them, there is a need to put whatever steps we can in place to improve their job satisfaction. The interest of the work, the opportunities to publish and the opportunities to attend national and international conferences go some way towards making up for the disparity in salary levels between the public and the private sectors.

When I see what is happening to the engineers and technologists in the DSTO, I am concerned that the restructuring may result in our losing even more of these highly qualified people whom we have such great difficulty in retaining now and who are so valuable to both our defence and the national interest.

I therefore urge the Minister for Defence to take this cry from the heart very seriously. We are talking about a substantial proportion of the work force of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and, as such, this matter should not be taken lightly. I would appreciate it if the Minister would take this issue on board and, hopefully, explain to the Opposition, possibly by way of a response in the Parliament when he has an opportunity to do so, why this restructuring at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation is being undertaken, bearing in mind the effects which it appears to be having. I would like the Minister's assurances that the interests of the nation and the defence forces are going to be paramount in any consideration of the petition from these employees of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE (HOME LOANS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: --The Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 will be receiving the support of the Opposition. Indeed, if had not been for the Opposition, I doubt that this Bill would ever have seen the light of day. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) may laugh but it was the Minister and his Government that managed to remove the entitlement of these personnel for a war service loan in the first place. It was only after the Opposition pointed this out to the Government and insisted that action be taken that this measure was introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) in fact originally denied that such action had been taken. If the Minister for Defence is not aware of the inadequacies of his colleague, let me put it clearly on the record that Minister Bilney claimed to me in correspondence that he was totally unaware that he had in fact allowed the removal of a war service loan entitlement from these people.

I debated the question of the defence service home loans scheme the day that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was down on the wharves in Sydney, just before Christmas, farewelling men and women leaving for the Gulf while at the same time taking away their entitlement to a war service home loan. That legislation was then going through this Parliament. The effect of the new legislation was to remove a war service home loan entitlement from anybody who joined the Defence Force after May 1987.

The proportion of young people in the Navy is fairly high, as I am sure the Minister is aware. That meant that a high proportion of young people going away in the Gulf fleet no longer had an entitlement to a war service loan. I acknowledge that it had been announced that there would be a waiver of the six-year waiting period for a defence service home loan, but it was not much use to someone who was injured and invalided out, and, if someone was killed and his wife wanted a defence service home loan, it was effectively removed altogether. Those men and women who went away to the Gulf were the first service personnel since World War I who had served in war but were not eligible for a war service loan. That is the reason we have this legislation before us today.

I would like to read into Hansard something else that the Minister might like to take on board relating to war service loans. On 4 December, during the debate on the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill, I pointed out:

. . . this legislation will not apply to reservists in the Gulf. Further, this legislation contains reversionary benefits allowing the surviving spouse of a regular serviceman who is killed still to be eligible for the loan calculated on his prospective service had he not been killed. This, it would appear, does not flow on to reservists in the same situation. Why are they so different in what is supposed to be an integrated force?
As I understand it, that issue has still not been addressed. It needs to be.

Minister Bilney, on 28 May, put out a press release announcing that there would now be home loan assistance for ADF members with Gulf service. That is when finally the Government acknowledged that it had made a boo-boo and that it did need to do something about home loan assistance for the Australian Defence Force members who had served in the Gulf. Minister Bilney trumpeted that he had introduced this home loan assistance but he failed to acknowledge that the reason people did not have the home loan assistance in the first place was that his Government had removed it in May 1987, when it concluded the old scheme. When it introduced legislation for the new scheme in December last year there was no provision for war service loans.

I am glad to see that the Government has taken our advice. It is now facing up to its responsibility and has decided to do the right thing by those who served during the Gulf conflict. But at the time when it sent those people away it was not to know that there would be no casualties. It is important that we have in place ahead of time a clear set of guidelines for overseas service, whether it is peacekeeping or war service, so that people know what they are entitled to--rather than having to change things around after the event as we are doing today with this legislation.

This is not the only area where the Government has fouled up on defence service home loans. Just last month I spoke in this place, in debate on a matter of public importance, about a case that was then before the AAT. That is a most unsatisfactory situation: there is concurrent usage by two defence spouses of their dual eligibility. The Government has long administered the home loan scheme so that there is no entitlement to take up that dual eligibility concurrently; in fact, people have been knocked back for some considerable period. What happened was that this year the AAT said that this was wrong and that legally people should be entitled to take up concurrent eligibility.

I am glad the true legal situation was finally recognised. What is so despicable is that since April this year there has been a continual stream of correspondence between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Defence about whether they are going to own up to this. I am very sad to say that the Department of Defence was arguing quite strongly that people should not get the opportunity to exercise their lawful eligibility because it would mess up the arrangements which the Government had made with the National Bank for the sale of the defence mortgages.

The Veterans' Affairs Department, to give it its due, seemed to be pushing to get that opportunity made available to Defence Force personnel, but, sad to say, the matter dragged on and on. I understand that eventually it had to be decided in Cabinet that this concurrent eligibility was to be announced. When was it announced? It was announced on 22 August this year. The interesting thing about that date is that 31 August was the last day on which Defence Force personnel who had this entitlement could decide whether they would stay in the old housing scheme or would revoke that entitlement and go into the new scheme. But in order to make that decision they had to be informed.

The Minister's announcement on 22 August gave them eight or nine days in which to make that decision. Unfortunately, many people would not have known about the Minister's announcement in time. In addition, in the months prior to that many people would have been revoking their entitlement. They had the opportunity through the year up to 31 August to revoke their entitlement under the old scheme and opt into the new scheme. In many respects the old scheme is better, but there was one advantage to the new scheme: a couple could exercise their eligibility concurrently and thus make it a meaningful loan on a home at today's high home costs.

The problem that is still facing defence personnel is that there needs to be some legislation produced in this Parliament if those people who have ignorantly revoked that entitlement are to be put back in the situation of being able to exercise the rights which the law says they had all along. I am glad of this opportunity to make it quite clear to the Minister that I will not let up on this and that I hope he will not, either. I hope that very soon we will see more amending legislation coming before this Parliament on the defence service home loans, so that we will put people into the position in which they should have been in the first place.

I do not wish to take the time of the Senate any longer on a Bill which, as I said at the beginning, is coming to this Parliament because we pushed for such a Bill. We are very glad to see that the people who went to the Gulf are going to get their entitlement to a war service home loan restored, but I challenge the Minister as to why this is being limited to people who served in the Gulf. Does it mean that he believes we have reached nirvana and we will never more commit people to a situation where their lives may be at risk in the defence of this country or in pursuance of its interests?

If the Minister believes that we are likely to have to do that at some time in the future, why is it that we are not restoring the position where everybody who had served this country in war since 1918 knew that they would have an entitlement to a war service loan? When is the Government going to restore that for those who in the future may have to give their lives for this country?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not intend to have a cross-fire debate on who is responsible for the Defence Force (Homes Loans Assistance) Amendment Bill, but I should at least say for the record that if the Opposition wants to claim credit for it I am happy to share it. I must say, however, that immediately at the start of the Gulf conflict, when we made a decision to commit several wings of our Defence Force to that conflict, we had discussions in my office with a variety of people to make sure that people's allowances and entitlements would be properly looked after and that if there were inconsistencies future legislation would overcome them. In any event, I do not think any future historian will be spending a lot of time on who takes the credit for this Bill. Senator Newman is correct in saying that it is a welcome Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I have only one thing to add. It is in response to something that was raised in the House of Representatives. My colleague was asked to provide the Opposition with information regarding the numbers of Defence Force personnel who served in the Gulf war. He sent me a note so that I can put it on the record here. The figures are as follows: Navy, 1,446; Army, 48; and Royal Australian Air Force, 155--for a total of 1,649.
I thank the Opposition. I take it from Senator Bell's nodding his head that he acquiesces in this Bill, and I wish it a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HONEY LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1991HONEY LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1991HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 September, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will be brief. I do not wish to challenge the legislation, which seeks to make provisions regarding the honey levy. We have no disagreement whatsoever with that purpose. In line with the user pays principle, the producers of honey, the farmers who collect honey from the bees, are helping to pay for things such as research and development of the industry, and this is fair enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we should be concerned that a lot of attention is paid to the honey industry. It is important to note that more regard could be paid to the other functions that are performed by bees. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be aware that bees play a role in the horticultural industry in Tasmania.
In fact, bees are very much like worms in that they are very effective, if underpaid, agricultural workers.

We rely upon bees to fertilise the majority of our horticultural crops. Apiarists are, in fact, contracted and paid to bring hives of bees into fields of broad acre vegetables at the appropriate time to ensure that fertilisation takes place. This, of course, is especially important for crops such as peas, beans and tomatoes. It is also important for crops such as poppies which are grown for seed purposes rather than for their fruit. This process is less important for crops such as corn, which are essentially wind fertilised. But bees are certainly of considerable importance to the Tasmanian horticultural industry.

It is also important, I believe, to recognise that these contributors to our horticultural economy are particularly vulnerable to the aerial spraying of insecticides. There is an incident that I am aware of, again in Tasmania, related to over-spraying. A particular winery in the Tamar Valley was subjected to over-spray in recent months, and not only were the plants injured but the work of the bees was certainly hampered. Attempts are made to justify the practice of aerial spraying, but I want to alert the Senate to the complications and the far-reaching effects which may arise from what may seem to be a simple practice.

It is not unlike, nor is it unrelated to, what happened last spring on the lawns which cover this Parliament House building. Observant senators would have noticed that sprays were applied to the grounds, ostensibly to rid the place of some sort of pest. I cannot remember what the pest was and I did not even see it. Observant senators would have noticed that the worms were most effectively killed, and that recently extra attention has been necessary to aerate the soil--the job that the worms might have done. I wonder what that has cost.

I do not want to make this a big issue, but I think it is important when we are considering such matters that we remind ourselves that we are part of a very complicated set of interrelated and interdependent organisms. To be able to sustain the ecology in which we live and to continue to derive benefit from it, as we do when we derive the benefits from workers such as bees and worms, we should be aware of how our actions affect them. With that contribution to the understanding of the ecology of the earth, I conclude my remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows--
HONEY LEVY (No. 1)

AMENDMENT BILL 1991 This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Levy on honey produced and sold in Australia. The Bill is one of three similar Bills, each dealing with a different way of selling honey, which provide for an increase in the maximum allowable levies or export charge on honey to 0.75 cent per kilogram. The levies and export charge are imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council.

Under the present legislation the maximum allowable levy for research and development is 0.50 cent per kilogram, which is the same as the current operative rate. The operative rate is determined by Regulation on advice of the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations, which is the national representative beekeeper organisation, or the Honeybee Research and Development Council. The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has advised that it wishes to increase the operative rate to 0.52 cent per kilogram from January 1992 as part of its program of progressively increasing the producer contribution to research and development.

To allow for this increase and any further increases, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has requested the raising of the maximum rate to 0.75 cent per kilogram. Increasing the maximum rate by 50 per cent will give industry the flexibility to increase its contributions to research and development over an extended period without the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

The Government commends the industry's foresight and support of the need for increased research and development. The Australian honey industry is currently contributing about 0.4 per cent of its gross value of production to research and development. Research and development is a major factor underlying this country's future growth. The Government is committed to continued matching of industry levies for funding of research and development up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. This has continued to encourage rural industries to increase their contributions to research and clearly the honey industry recognises the advantage of this commitment in moving towards the 0.5 per cent target.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
HONEY LEVY (No. 2)

AMENDMENT BILL 1991 This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Levy on honey produced in Australia and used in the production of other goods. The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum allowable levy to 0.75 cent per kilogram. The levy is imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I have already outlined the background to this amendment in my Second Reading Speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1991.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
HONEY EXPORT CHARGE
AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Export Charge on honey exported, but not levied under other legislation. The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum allowable export charge to 0.75 cent per kilogram of honey. The export charge is imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council. I have already outlined the background to this amendment in my Second Reading Speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays. I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The coalition supports the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, the Honey Levy (No. 2) Amendment Bill and the Honey Export Charge Amendment Bill. The honey industry is a small industry in comparison with other rural industries such as the wool, wheat, cattle and dairy industries. However, it still plays a valuable and efficient role within the rural sector. The figures from the 1989-90 annual report of the Australian Honey Board mentions that Australia generally produces 22,000 to 24,000 tonnes of honey a year. There are approximately 800 beekeepers.

SPEECH.PARA: Of this honey production, Australia exported over half, about 12,000 to 13,000 tonnes, which gained an export income of somewhere between $16m and $17m. Those exports went mainly to the United Kingdom, Germany, Singapore, the United States and Japan. Beeswax was also exported. Even so, Australia is a small producer compared with the worldwide honey industry. The 1989-90 annual report of the Australian Honey Board goes on to say that world production was 690,000 tonnes, with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics the largest producer at 225,000 tonnes. China was the second largest producer at 180,000 tonnes. Australia was eighth on this world ranking.

Australia undoubtedly commands natural advantages over our competitors. There are long hours of sunshine and a wide range of nectar laden native trees, which assist in producing honey that has both quality and flavour just as good as, if not better than, that of our competitors. However, the Australian industry has not been taking advantage of this situation. Consequently, too many bulk products, rather than branded products, have been sold on the open market. The Australian Honey Board believes that the future prosperity of the Australian honey industry lies in its ability to recognise and pursue marketing opportunities when they arise.

Australian honey has been valued on colour and viscosity, regardless of source--a practice that ignores many other fine qualities of our honey and, hence, limits the potential to command higher prices and increased consumer demand. Consequently, this has led to a decline in real incomes for Australian honey producers.

Due to the fact that Australia commands only 4 per cent of world trade, when honey is sold in bulk it must be sold at whatever the world price is. The Australian industry is not large enough to influence the price. This means that Australian honey producers in the future will move towards a brand product which can maintain a better price in a difficult marketing situation. There is very much a need within the industry for promotion and research and development.

At the present time, the honey industry is paying a levy of 0.45c per kilogram of honey for research and development. The standard dollar for dollar arrangements have been bipartisan for many years and go back well before the 1985 legislation.

Last year the industry provided $129,000 and that was matched by the Commonwealth. The Federal Council of the Australian Apiarists Association wants to increase the maximum level beyond the 0.5c per kilogram to 0.75c so that it can increase the operative level from the present 0.45c to 0.52c per kilogram in order to maintain the research and development process. This will also get it closer to the maximum set by the Government, which seems to be a sensible goal.

At the present time, all of these rural industries have a maximum level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production, while the actual levy or operative level is about 0.4 per cent. My colleague in the other chamber, the honourable member for Murray and shadow Minister for primary industries, Mr Bruce Lloyd, questioned what research arrangements were best for smaller industries to ensure that the dollar for dollar arrangement continues.

I agree with Mr Lloyd. This arrangement is an important one. The industry is contributing to research when many non-rural industries in Australia do nothing about this activity. Therefore, the dollar for dollar arrangement with the Government is a basis for some stability. In good times and in bad, the rural industry provides the money, which is a valuable concept.

In conclusion, the honey industry undoubtedly has a natural advantage in Australia and I can only hope that it strengthens in the future. It should be able to become a bigger and better industry in the sense of not only providing more in quality but also by being able to upgrade its quality image and maximise its return in the market. The coalition supports this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank Senator Tambling for his perceptive remarks and wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without requests or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As Mr Hawke's solemn promise of one year ago that Australian unemployment would not reach 10 per cent has today joined the long list of the Prime Minister's recklessly made and readily broken promises, I ask the Minister whether the Government will now give an honest forecast of when unemployment will fall significantly from today's appalling rate of 10.2 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have repeatedly said in the Senate at Question Time that I was not prepared to forecast in respect of a number of matters including the unemployment figure. As has been pointed out here on a number of occasions, the Government, through the Budget Papers, did make a forecast in respect of unemployment through the year. The anticipation was that unemployment would increase in the first half of the fiscal year 1991-92 and trend downwards in the second half of this fiscal year. I repeat that Budget estimate or forecast. I remind the Senate, in confirmation of that, that unemployment is a lagged indicator of the state of the economy and economic activity.
—-So it will be worse later?

—-Well, the trend in unemployment from the June-July figures was totally different from the trend, if one could draw a trend, from the August figures. There has been a certain volatility in the figures. It is very difficult to be confident about trends in the unemployment rate over the short term.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of business and other surveys which, I suspect, indicate support for that Budget forecast. They include: the State Bank of New South Wales and Chamber of Manufacturing survey of business conditions which reports the best results in business conditions since before the recession; the National Australia Bank and the Westpac-CAI surveys are similarly positive about business conditions; the Dun and Bradstreet report on business conditions released this morning found that confidence is returning with new orders increasing and the expectation of profits will rise with the fall in interest rates; and the Department of Employment, Education and Training leading index on unemployment has risen for the fourth consecutive month in relation to the month of August. I refer to that material only to support the scenario established in the Budget Papers in relation to what would happen to the unemployment figures during this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. In view of his claim that the economy is picking up, despite the fact that there are now fewer than two job vacancies for every 100 unemployed people and in view of the Budget forecast of an average unemployment rate of 10.5 per cent, I wonder whether the Minister could now give an undertaking that unemployment in Australia will not exceed 11 per cent?

—-I have already answered that question. In the first part of my answer to the honourable senator's original question I said that I was not in the business of speculating about unemployment rates at any particular time.
—-The Budget Papers did.

—-If Senator Alston had been listening instead of talking all the time, he would have heard what I said about that, too. An official forecast is contained in the Budget Papers and I have already referred to that. I have got nothing to add.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Could the Minister inform the Senate of the changes to the social security system which would be necessary to combat the inequities of a consumption tax on social security clients and other low income earners if it were implemented? For example, would existing CPI indexation arrangements be adequate for payments not only to pensioners and beneficiaries but also to children? Would these changes compensate all those adversely affected by a consumption tax?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! There are too many interjections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am surprised at the din.
—-Tell us about Ravenshoe, given that you destroyed all the jobs up there.

—-I have told Senator Parer about Ravenshoe many times because he is a person who needs education about that and everything else. If he wants to ask another question about that matter I will again answer it. It is just as well that somebody can give some indication of the kind of changes that would be needed in social security if the consumption tax were to come into being, because we do not seem to be able to find anything out from those who want to propose the tax. The details remain secret. Nonetheless, there are some deductions that can be made about the kind of arrangements which ought to be changed.
—-The man you thought would be a great Prime Minister was behind the idea.

—-As usual, Senator Kemp is about six years behind the times. I was one who toyed with the consumption tax until I worked out that I could not compensate these people. The difference between those opposite and me is that I stopped when I realised that, whereas those opposite bat on harder because they care so little about them.

ANSWER.PARA: The social security figures show that there are four million adults and 1.3 million children who are dependent on pensions, benefits and family allowance supplements paid by the Department of Social Security. There are some 400,000 to 500,000 adults--with an unknown number of children--who are outside those boundaries, who are earning so little that they are not included but who do not qualify for social security for other reasons. They might be self-employed in small business with assets but they are very income poor. We are talking about a lot of people who have very real difficulties. The trouble is that it is almost impossible to compensate them through the social security system. First of all, those age pensioners who have savings do not get compensated for any loss in savings at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where was the compensation in the wholesale sales tax increases?

—-We do not worry about what Senator Kemp thinks because, unlike the rest of the world, no one cares. As far as the Opposition is concerned, no-one is suggesting there should be any compensation for savings. So they just go. The drop in the savings is just forfeited. Those pensioners who saved all their lives so that they could have some little comfort have to understand that they will get absolutely nothing for those savings. That is the first point.

ANSWER.PARA: To try to protect social security clients fully, there needs to be some compensation for that inflation increase, the CPI increase, which even the Liberal Party would concede is some 7 to 10 per cent. Obviously, the rate of compensation for pensioners will have to be higher. How one does that I do not know. People with less money--and that means families with children--are the ones that struggle. One wonders just how those who spend the great part of their income on basic necessities also get compensated.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You will find out in due course.

—-So will Senator Macdonald. He would not know because he is kept in the dark, but he is the happiest mushroom in the Opposition. The problem is that those people who have to spend a great deal of their income on clothes and food are the ones who are going to suffer the most. These are the people who have got the least possibility of ever being compensated.

ANSWER.PARA: People such as farmers and the self-employed, those who often do not earn enough to pay tax and are not necessarily in the social security system--that 400,000 to 500,000--are the ones that those opposite represent. Does Senator Boswell remember the farmers?

TALK.START.PARA: —-Hardly.

—-It has been a long time since he visited them, put it that way--Senator Collins is right. There is no plan--not even under consideration in the darkest recesses of the most evil mind--to compensate them, absolutely none. They are offered nothing. Therefore, we have a list of 5 1/2 million Australians, plus some children that we cannot yet count--so let us look at a nice round figure of six million--who cannot be compensated either at all or adequately. They are all people at the lower end of the income scale. More than one-third of Australia will be devastated by a consumption tax and no-one opposite will give any details--not just to us but neither to the six million. No-one will tell them what will happen to them. Those opposite do not know and they do not care.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the latest surge in human misery contained in today's shocking unemployment figures, which show that 10.2 per cent of the work force is now unemployed. Given that the Prime Minister now has 872,000 shattered Australian lives swinging around his neck and has clearly shown himself to be a social justice failure, what level will unemployment have to reach before the Government agrees with Paul Keating's acolyte Joan Kirner, who said as recently as last Monday night:

QUESTION.PARA: For some time now I have been saying to the Prime Minister that we need a jobs policy.
In other words, the Government simply does not have a national jobs policy, and I think the Australian electorate would like to know when it proposes to do something about it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not have much to add to--
—-I'll bet you haven't.

—-I will have an answer later for the honourable senator. I do not have much to add to the answer which I gave to Senator Michael Baume on this issue. The fact of the matter is that the Government projected at the time of the Budget--with great regret, of course--that unemployment would be likely to rise during the first half of this fiscal year, and that it would improve in the second half of this fiscal year. Those figures were provided in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that we have a situation of unemployment arising from a recession and a high level of structural change in the Australian economy. Those two factors are contributing to the present levels of unemployment. In so far as the bulk of that unemployment figure is concerned, it is dependent upon growth in the Australian economy. I have nothing to add to what I said earlier about the predictions which are set out in the Budget and the various comments I made from independent commentators about a return to growth in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the fact that Senator Button does not quibble with my quotation from Joan Kirner that he now concedes he was wrong when he told the Senate last Tuesday that the Victorian Government had not been criticising the Federal Government for not having a jobs policy. Does it follow from that that Senator Button is simply content to ignore Mrs Kirner's comments as yet another desperate attempt to help Paul Keating or does he now concede that, in fact, there is no such thing as a national jobs policy?

—-I do not want to follow the labyrinth of Senator Alston's tortured mind through its various chambers in answering the second part of his question, which had very little to do with the first part. I would like to look at the Hansard before I accede to the second question which Senator Alston has asked me because I think he has misquoted what I said. Would he deny that?
—-Yes, I would deny it.

—-Okay. We will see what is in the Hansard and what, in fact, I said about that issue. Anything that Mrs Kirner has said about this issue I have seen in the newspapers, just as Senator Alston has. That is all that I can say about it. I have said nothing else about it.

—-Is the Minister for Social Security aware of conflicting studies which have analysed how Australians--including both the rich and the poor--have fared under Labor since 1983? Is there any evidence that the poor in Australia are worse off?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would have thought that all honourable senators would have been interested in how the poor in Australia have fared during the course of the last eight years. There have been a few studies which have suggested that the rich got richer and the poor got poorer; some people in this chamber have even chosen to use those studies on occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think Senator Maguire is referring to the study by Mark Lombard who looked at this question and came to the conclusion that the poor had, indeed, got poorer. The difficulty was that he looked only at taxable income and that, of course, is a pretty inadequate measure by which to judge any of this. In fact, he qualified his own study when he released it. His words were:
There has been no attempt to assess changes in wealth distribution nor to measure standards of living.
Despite his own qualification, he managed to make that very same link. He went on to say:

Absent from this study, therefore, are changes in welfare provisions, changes in the taxation on expenditure, the cost of living, et cetera. This study is confined to income distribution in Australia, as measured by taxable income.
There are so many things outside of taxable income that can measure just how families are doing that it makes such a study virtually irrelevant.
More importantly, there is a more recent study by Dr Ann Harding and Mr John Landt, of my own Department, on trends in disposable income which, of course, is a far better measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Have you accepted the concept of a two-tiered Australian society?

—-I have often worried about Senator Watson. The concept of a two-tiered Australia is abhorrent over here. That is why the Labor Government, since 1983, has worked tirelessly to make sure that those at the bottom end of the income scale have had improvements. That is what I am about to outline.

ANSWER.PARA: The key conclusion of that study by Harding and Landt was that lower income groups are better off. That should come as no shock to those who have had any sort of genuine look at what disposable incomes have done. Social security recipients' incomes, in particular, have substantially increased. Between 1983 and 1991 payments have increased for full rate single pensioners without children and not receiving rent assistance by 15.4 per cent in real terms; by 14.7 per cent for comparable pensioner couples; by 26 per cent for maximum rate adult unemployment beneficiaries not receiving rent assistance; and by 54 per cent for those who are receiving maximum rent assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Are you telling us they have never had it so good?

—-That may well be bad news for Senator Parer and his ilk, but for all the people who have to rely on those kinds of payments, obviously the disposable income jump--and it is a very substantial jump in real terms--is something that they are welcoming.
—-Get out of the ivory tower.

—-Senator Kemp ought to have a listen some time. Every time any Government Minister answers a question, Senator Kemp has more to say than the person answering the question. He ought to listen occasionally.
—-No chance.

—-I wish there was no chance--I have a bit of support for that over here. Given those very significant increases, one wonders why Dr Hewson would so selectively quote from the Harding and Landt study last week when he was at the ACOSS conference. Then again, when he was walking into ACOSS to do what he did to it--not to mention what he did to his own shadow Minister--one can understand why he would want to fudge. For all of those people on low incomes, the fudging on the consumption tax and the fudging on what happens to the unemployed after nine months is about to end. Exposure is at hand, colleagues--look out!

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the situation with the current cease-fire in Yugoslavia? As communication systems have been prime military targets in Yugoslavia, making it almost impossible for the thousands of Australians with family and friends there to contact them directly, what procedures are in place for Australians to obtain information about the safety of their relatives in Yugoslavia? Finally, what information does the Minister have about the extent of damage to the world's most perfectly preserved--or formerly most perfectly preserved--walled renaissance city, Dubrovnik?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-So far as the cease-fire is concerned, it does appear that, while breaches of the cease-fire of 8 October have been reported, it is generally being respected. It is encouraging particularly that one aspect of that agreement, the lifting of the blockade on Croatian ports, is already being implemented. The test of the latest agreement will come when the deadline of 1800 hours on Saturday, 12 October, local time, approaches for the lifting of the siege of the Yugoslav army barracks and the withdrawal of the Yugoslav army from those barracks.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government's position is very clear on these matters. We once again call on all the parties to respect the cease-fire agreement and to negotiate a peaceful resolution of the conflict. We call for that outcome not only for the peace of the region but because we believe it is in the best interests of the peoples of Yugoslavia themselves.

So far as the safety of Australian citizens, of which there are some thousands, in Yugoslavia is concerned, our Embassy in Belgrade has confirmed that telephone communication with Australian citizens in Croatia is simply not possible at the moment. Although phone connections with Belgrade are not possible, we know that some phone calls have been made directly from Croatia to Australia and to Italy. Communications with other republics in Yugoslavia are still possible. We believe that most mail is getting through, but some towns and villages in Croatia cannot be reached.

To some extent, we foresaw that this predicament might arise if things got serious, as it had also been the problem in other situations, such as Kuwait, where we were caught up with this kind of consular communication issue. The first of two circular letters was sent to all Australian citizens in Croatia suggesting that they consider relocating themselves to safer places. That letter was sent on 1 August, well before communications were cut off.

A second letter with similar advice was dispatched on 27 September, and in case some did not reach their destination the message was also broadcast on Bosnia-Herzegovina radio. The second letter was sent to about 2,000 Australian citizens in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, and by 7 October only some 20 letters had been returned to the Embassy as being undeliverable. There had, of course, been earlier advice about the security situation in the country through my Department's travel advices, the first of which was issued on 19 April. Given the dangers of travelling to and within Croatia, senators will appreciate that there are constraints on our own staff in Belgrade travelling there at present.

As for the very last question about the situation in Dubrovnik, the fact that there are no telephone communications between the Adriatic coastal ports and Belgrade does complicate access to information regarding the latest developments. According, however, to the latest information available--as of last evening, 9 October--from EC monitoring forces present in Dubrovnik, there had been no damage at all to the historic section of the city. We can all only hope that that situation will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Is the Minister aware of proposals by Australian National to upgrade and improve the rolling stock, services and marketing of the Indian Pacific rail service? If he has, and since such proposals hinge on an agreement to bring the operations of the Indian Pacific under the control of a single body, first, is he aware of growing concern that the service, which can claim international significance as a unique tourist attraction, is in grave danger of collapse unless urgent action is taken to attract new customers in a sustained and systematic way; secondly, what stage have negotiations reached on the question of control of the service by a single body; and, thirdly, what role is the Government playing in attempting to achieve long overdue change to the antediluvian management and operations of this important and potentially attractive and lucrative service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with a response to Senator Beahan's question. The Minister is aware of proposals by the Australian National Railways Commission to operate the Indian Pacific rail service and that these could only be effectively implemented if the service can be placed under single management. The recent offer by New South Wales to transfer control of the Indian Pacific to Australian National is encouraging and the Minister would urge that the Western Australian Government follow suit.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises that airline deregulation has substantially affected loadings on this service and that it is important that some way be found to attract patronage back to the service if it is to survive in the long term. This view is shared by Federal and State transport Ministers, who at the 4 October 1991 meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council instituted a study of the options for the future of interstate rail passenger operations and a report to the March 1992 meeting of the Council. The study will consider the possibility of establishing a national rail passenger organisation and will as a matter of priority consider the Indian Pacific service. The management and operation of the train, however, are matters for the operator of the service and the Government expects that these matters will be satisfactorily addressed once improved institutional arrangements are implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Given that the Government is expected to save $166.6m in 1991-92 and $368.3m in the next financial year by the introduction of a $3.50 co-payment for general practitioner consultations, what will be the budgetary implications of the jellybacked compromise of reducing the co-payment to $2.50 for patients attending bulk-billing practices and the Government's making up the $1 difference? Indeed, does the Government intend to make up that $1 difference?

—-The question of the co-payment or the funding of GP services is a matter that is still under discussion within the Parliamentary Labor Party. I have nothing to say about those discussions until they are concluded.

—-I ask the Minister for Defence whether he has seen an article by Brian Toohey in the Sydney Sun-Herald of 6 October and in the Adelaide News of 7 October this year which claims that the new Collins class submarines are too big for our stated needs and are primarily intended to assist the Americans in intelligence collection. Can the Minister advise the Senate about the accuracy of this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not think that even Brian Toohey would take any insult over the fact that he has yet to write an article that has ever been complimentary about Australia's strategic outlook or about our defence forces. As usual, when he writes on these matters there is a fair degree of licence.

ANSWER.PARA: First, Mr Toohey seems to think that because there was a reduction in super-power tension we should be involved in a contraction of the Australian defence forces. He also grossly misunderstands our defence planning. He still assumes that it is based on expeditionary aspirations, and on some subservience to our allies in terms of the equipment purchases that we make. I have to assert that our capabilities are very much tailored to our own needs and not to those of our allies. Wherever we can adopt practices of inter-operability, we do so because it makes sense.

The Toohey article is wrong in some of the figures it uses. He asserts that the Oberon standard displacement is 1,600 tonnes compared with 2,500 tonnes for the Collins class. In fact, that figure for the Collins class is the dive displacement figure rather than the standard displacement.
