The surface displacement of the Oberon is 2,030 tonnes whereas the Collins class is 2,450 tonnes. He continually asserts that the Collins class submarine is much bigger than the Oberon; in fact, it is about a foot less in width, and slightly shorter.

Overall, the article lacks any real strategic sense. The facts in the article are grossly wrong. I have to say that this Government, for good reason, rejected the option of nuclear powered submarines, on the grounds of both cost and excess capability. We also rejected the options for smaller submarines because of their lack of endurance.

In conclusion, the decision to buy the Collins class submarine has been reinforced in my mind as a correct decision by the number of other countries in the region and also in the Commonwealth that have come to look at the project and to admire and compliment us on it. Virtually universally, they have said that this is the best conventional submarine in the world. That very much reinforces our view of it and, I think, very much runs contrary to Mr Toohey's comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister, as reported in today's press, written to the Prime Minister advising him that he doubts whether our business tax system is internationally competitive, that Australia is investing too little to sustain adequate growth and that environmental and Aboriginal heritage processes are blocking development? If so, are those criticisms of the Government's performance still accurate and what is the Government doing to overcome them? I also ask whether the Minister decided to write to the Prime Minister because he felt that the Prime Minister was ignoring his views or blocking him out of this very crucial debate in the same way as the Prime Minister has blocked out the Minister's Victorian counterpart, Minister White. Finally, will the Minister table his letter to the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We always get the true flavour of a question from the stupidest bit in it. The last bit was the stupidest bit.
—-Why did you leak it?

—-As I have said to Senator Alston before, he approaches every problem with an open mouth and I wish that he would just close it for a second so that we could get on with answering Senator Short's question.
—-What about trying to answer the question?
—-What about getting your colleague to let me answer the question?
—-You are a big boy now.

—-Yes, I am. That is one of your problems, I know. The stupidest part of the question was about my Victorian colleague David White. The fantasies the Opposition builds on snippets of useless information obtained from newspapers just amaze me.

ANSWER.PARA: On the substance of the question, I did see that there was an item in the Australian today which referred to a letter that I had supposedly written to the Prime Minister. Senator Alston does not know much about these things--perhaps he does not know much about anything--but if he read the piece in the Australian properly, he would have seen what the alleged letter was sent to the Prime Minister for. Perhaps he does not understand that.

The point of Senator Short's question is essentially about business taxation. The fact of the matter is that this Government reviewed a whole range of taxation issues in 1988, including business taxation. For example, at that time we set a corporate tax rate which was low for the overall OECD group of countries. From time to time, business tax regimes are reviewed. That major review in 1988 is three years old now, and it is appropriate to take stock of business tax arrangements further, particularly given the changes which have taken place in other countries in the intervening period.

Of course, that review process is implemented in light of many taxation reforms that have already been made, such as the introduction of capital gains tax, but the review of business taxation and other forms of taxation is done on an ongoing basis. There will be further discussion of these matters. I confirm that that is taking place as part of the process of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister again: will he table the letter that he wrote? I presume that he is not denying that he wrote it. Does the Prime Minister share the Minister's view that Australia's business tax system is internationally uncompetitive?

—-I do not know what Senator Short expects me to say in answer to the second part of his question. I was trying to say that the Government reviews these issues and takes into account a number of views. That was the answer to the first part of his question. Senator Short wants to prejudge any review by saying, `Does the Prime Minister share the Minister's view?'. If one looks at the first answer that I gave, one sees that it is a very silly question. That part of the question seems to me to be quite irrelevant, so I do not propose to answer it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns his recent visit to the United Nations General Assembly in New York. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the recommendations made by the United Nations expert study on means for increasing transparency in arms transfers which was presented on 23 September? I particularly ask what the Government's position is with regard to paragraph 148, which states that the international transfer of conventional arms should not be primarily driven by economic or commercial considerations, given that a prime motivation for seeking to double Australia's military exports, as recommended by the 1986 Cooksey report, is to offset the cost of military exports. I further ask the Minister what steps he intends to take with regard to paragraph 152, which recommends that individual states enact and enforce legal instruments to control and monitor arms imports and exports effectively, and paragraphs 154 and 168(c), which recommend that information about Australian military exports--

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators--Come on!

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am asking specific questions about specific paragraphs of a United Nations document.
—-Don't let them intimidate you, Senator. I am right behind you.
—-I thank Senator Collins.
—-Order! Senator Vallentine, would you please ask the question.

—-The question relates to the specific paragraphs that I have mentioned--paragraphs 152, 154 and 168--which recommend that information about Australian military exports be passed on to the United Nations for an arms transfer register.

—-Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vallentine has clearly defied your order to ask a question and she is in the process of reading us a long book. I suggest that she be asked to sit down.
—-There is no point of order but, Senator Vallentine, I did ask you to ask the question.

—-The question relates to those paragraphs that I have mentioned. I want to know what the Australian Government is going to do about them, given that the Australian Government currently refuses to publish this information about arms transfers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is a perfectly reasonable question; I agree with Senator Vallentine. Those opposite are a collection of louts and chauvinists and narrow-minded, insensitive souls. It is entirely appropriate that we should deal with this question in our own way, which I will proceed to do. As to the first question on the expert groups--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Then we will both bore them to sobs. The report of the UN expert group, which was released on 23 September, makes the following recommendations: states are encouraged to make all their military activities as open as possible; states should ensure that they have in place the legal and administrative machinery for effectively regulating and monitoring their arms transfers; a universal and non-discriminatory arms transfer register should be established as soon as possible under UN auspices, with the specifics of the register to be further developed within that UN framework; states should be encouraged to engage in efforts to achieve regional and subregional measures of transparency in relation to arms transfers; the wider sharing of information on defence might be reflected in the provision of information to the UN or in the context of possible regional measures, or both; and, finally, all states should give high priority to eradicating the illicit arms trade, with the UN having a role to play in this area in increasing international awareness of the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question, specifically in relation to paragraph 148 of the report, it is true that the experts have said that the international transfer of conventional arms should not be primarily driven by economic or commercial considerations. We, the Australian Government, agree with this. But this assertion by the experts needs to be read in the context of the report as a whole, which is focused on restraining excessive transfers of conventional arms and encouraging governments to exercise strict controls on exports. Most significantly, the report does not suggest that exports as such are not legitimate. Indeed, it specifically recognises `the sovereign right of states to acquire arms for their defence', and that `arms transfers cannot be considered necessarily destabilising'.

As to the last part of the question, the UN experts group was established to facilitate proper UN consideration of this whole issue. That consideration is currently occurring, with what I am advised are vigorous efforts currently under way in New York in which Australia is actively engaged, to achieve a widely agreed General Assembly resolution on this issue. We hope very much that such a resolution can be achieved and Australia, as it always seeks to do, will observe any obligations which such international action imposes on us.

Specifically, finally, with respect to paragraph 152 of the report, Australia, of course, already has a well-established legal and administrative regime to control and monitor conventional arms exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it correct that, as reported in today's Australian, the Government's Major Projects Group, which was purportedly set up to remove impediments to large scale developments in Australia, has not met since it was established as part of the 12 March industry statement? If so, is this total lack of action a measure of the Government's lack of commitment to encouraging investment and job opportunities in Australia?
—-I believe the answer to the first part of the question is no. If the answer to the first part of the question is no, as I believe it is, the second part becomes redundant.
—-I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Was the Government's Major Projects Group established as part of the March economic statement? If so, has it met since 12 March?

—-In so far as formal meetings are concerned, I am unable to answer that part of the question. I do not know. I do know that there has been considerable activity by the group. I will obtain an answer to Senator Campbell's question as to whether there have been formal meetings of the group, which is what I said in my answer to the first question.

—-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I want to return to the unemployment figures. Given today's confirmation that unemployment now exceeds 10 per cent--which is equivalent to the whole of Western Australia being unemployed or 15 members of parliament representing jobless electorates--I ask the Minister: does the Government consider this acceptable collateral damage from its economic policy or will it change direction? At what point will the Government adopt a more interventionist industry policy? Will it be when the equivalent of Queensland, Victoria or New South Wales is unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to see that, in spite of the shadow portfolio changes which have taken place in the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot has picked up the great traditions of her Party articulated by a former spokesman on this issue. I do not know whether Senator Kernot was here earlier when I answered two or three questions about unemployment. First of all, I went through the Budget projections about growth in the Australian economy this fiscal year and changes in the employment figures. I do not propose to do that again because what I said is in Hansard. I do not necessarily recommend that Senator Kernot read that but, if she wants to read it, it is available to her in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot then took a leap by asking the Government to adopt a more interventionist industry policy. This is something about which I have been questioned by the Australian Democrats over the years, although I have never quite understood what they meant by a more interventionist policy. I hope that now Senator Kernot has become the spokesperson she will be able to articulate that for us so that all of us will better understand it.

Let me just say this: in terms of industry policy, let me be quite brutal about it. In 1990, no amount of what Senator Kernot might call interventionist industry policy would have helped companies that were paying very high interest rates. No amount of interventionist industry policy would have helped with those issues. If Senator Kernot looks at the consequences of industry policy in terms of employment, she will see that manufacturing employment in Australia grew by more than 100,000 in the four years to 1990. That was the first time there had been growth in employment in the manufacturing industry sector for year after year, indeed decades, going back to the late 1960s. That happened. In the first quarter of 1990, manufacturing employment in Australia was at its highest level for a very long time.

Of course, since then there has been a recession. The consequences of the recession have been very bad in respect of employment generally, which is the first part of Senator Kernot's question, and in respect of employment in manufacturing. As the economy comes out of the recession, as I said earlier, the employment position will improve. Whether there are any measures taken by the Government in respect of industry policy which might facilitate areas of particular employment is a matter to be determined. We will let Senator Kernot know in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer also to the comprehensive exposure of the Minister's confidential correspondence to the Prime Minister and to the ready-prepared and blatantly leaked response of his colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Minister support the public campaign of his colleague to subvert the processes of Cabinet to prevent Cabinet's legitimate efforts to overcome the stagnation of positive investment that, in his words, will `go to the task of stimulating investment in the economy and generating employment opportunities'?

—-I have had two suggestions in the last five minutes about this letter and how it came to be published in the Australian, one from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and one from the Deputy Leader. No, he is not Deputy Leader yet, thank God. If he were he would interject even more.
—-He got only seven votes.
—-Yes. I do not wish to comment on what appeared in the Australian and who was responsible for it. I do not see that there is any point in that.

—-I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Arising out of that answer, I ask the Minister: why are we witnessing this public exposure of the arguments for posing Ministers to this Cabinet contest?
—-I suppose it is because Senator Hill is a bit of a voyeur.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. It relates to the recent circulation by the Reader's Digest magazine of an article appearing in its October edition claiming that the Australian waterfront is `a national scandal' and demanding that `the Federal Government legislate major changes'.
—-It was a great article.
—-Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of the information in this article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Boswell could be forgiven for saying that it was a great article because when I got halfway through it I actually had to go back to the front cover to see whether it actually had a little note on it to say that it was a paid advertisement for the Federal Opposition. I do not believe that this article--and I invite any reasonable person who has not read it to read it and give his or her opinion; it is a major seven-page article on waterfront reform by the Reader's Digest--reflects well in any way at all on the journalistic standards of such a well-read publication as the Reader's Digest. It certainly does not. The blatant bias in this article is as breathtaking as I have seen.

ANSWER.PARA: Also, I had to look at the front cover of Reader's Digest to see whether I was reading a five-year-old copy of the magazine because the information in it is so dated and inaccurate that it is simply ridiculous to include it. But I note that it is the most recent edition of the magazine.

All of the sources and the information quoted in this article predate the Government's waterfront reform program and include, for example, a study of waterfront costs from 1988; examples of past inefficiencies from the 1989 Inter-State Commission report; anonymous quotes from `former' stevedoring employers--all of those quoted in this article are given anonymous names; there are little asterisks next to their names which note at the bottom of the page `not real name'--and, best of all, a reference to a 1989 quote from that well known expert on the waterfront, Senator Warwick Parer.

The reason why it is worth noting this article is that not only is it inaccurate and grossly biased but also it was sent, I assume, to thousands of people, including all members of parliament; the copy sent to me had an accompanying letter from the Editor-in-Chief, Mr Hugh Vaughan-Williams, commending it to me and telling me that he hoped I would find it an informative article.

I referred to one quote in the article from Senator Warwick Parer. I have to say, in fairness to the Reader's Digest, that there are only three politicians quoted in this article. This seven-page article on waterfront reform is dated October, this month. Three politicians are quoted: Senator Warwick Parer, John Sharp, the shadow Minister for waterfront reform, and John Hewson. That is it.

Indeed, John Hewson is quoted with approval by the Reader's Digest. I refer to the statement by Dr John Hewson that troops should be used on the waterfront. Despite the article in the Reader's Digest, which is a widely read magazine, being seven pages long, its description of the Government's waterfront reform program takes three sentences at the end of the article.

In March this year my office provided a written set of answers to a written set of questions seeking factual advice from the Reader's Digest. No attempt was made to contact either me or any other member of the Government to provide any statement for this article.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Why should they?

—-Senator Alston asks, `Why should they?'. Despite the majority of the seven pages of this article being devoted to bagging the unions as the sole villains on the waterfront, it does not use a single quote from a union official either.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no doubt many people have read this article. It is grossly inaccurate, highly dated and extremely and transparently biased. I will be writing to the Editor of the Reader's Digest and asking him to correct the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The Minister would be aware of the added burdens to all Australians of today's awful unemployment casualties. The Minister would also be aware that after the last Federal election his mate, the failed Labor member for McMillan, Barry Cunningham, was given the cushy job as Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I ask the Minister to explain why, in these difficult times, Mr Cunningham's salary has been increased by 33 per cent from $57,679 per annum to $76,660 per annum, plus a district allowance of $4,430 and a current personal income tax rate of only half of the normal mainland tax rate?

—-I will endeavour to find out what level of remuneration Mr Cunningham receives. I am delighted to hear Barry referred to as a mate of mine. There were times in the last couple of years when I thought that might not have been the case, and the fact that our relationship has been repaired is important. When it comes to the appointment of administrators, I can recall Norfolk Island going to an ex-Liberal leader in New South Wales. It has hardly been an unusual practice.

—-I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: has he seen reports of proposals to deregister unions which seek flow-on of wages struck in voluntary employment agreements? Do such proposals recommend themselves to the Government? Can Senator Cook advise the Senate whether there is a less complicated, less provocative and more effective means of dealing with this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes, I have seen an article promoting the ideas referred to in this question. It appeared in the Bulletin on 1 October. It consisted of an interview in part with Mr Howard, the shadow spokesperson from the Opposition on industrial relations. As I said yesterday, it again reveals that Mr Howard does know his slogans quite well but he does not know any detail or real background in the field of industrial relations. Certainly he does not stand up to journalistic probing.

ANSWER.PARA: In this article, he committed, in my view and in the view of the industrial relations community, a major faux pas and destroyed his own credibility when he replied to the question, `If a union takes action to flow-on an enterprise agreement to other workplaces, what will a coalition government do?'. The reply to that question was, `The coalition government will deregister the union'.

In this interview, Mr Howard was given several opportunities by the interviewer to get off the hook but he insisted on biting more deeply into the point of the hook and insisted on continuing with this argument that the union would be deregistered. Reading between the journalistic prose of the Bulletin one can see disbelief in the mind of the interviewer about what Mr Howard was saying.

A number of questions arise from the assertion that if a union sought to flow on an enterprise agreement in another enterprise it would be deregistered. Assuming that deregistration could be achieved, the first one is: how would it stop leapfrogging from one award or agreement to another? Simply deregistering a union would not stop it.

In fact it would put that organisation outside of the Industrial Relations Commission, where the checks and balances exist to direct its behaviour along more reasonable lines. It would put it outside of the law and give it complete freedom to go about doing the very thing that Mr Howard says is reprehensible. Presumably, if it was doing it within the system it would be able to survive outside of the system. Presumably, if it was being preyed on by a government when there are more reasonable courses of action to direct its behaviour, it would command support from other unions. The mere fact of its deregistration would do nothing to prevent the so-called alleged crime and do everything to encourage that type of practice.

John should talk to Ian. It would help John Howard to talk to Ian Viner. Ian Viner was Minister for Industrial Relations in the Fraser Government for a short period. Mr Viner tried to talk about and act upon deregistration and learnt that in Australia there are seven industrial relations systems. The Commonwealth presides over one of them but there are six others in the States.

If a union is deregistered at a national level there is no reason why that would automatically mean deregistration at a State level. If this behaviour that is complained of is reprehensible, then it can continue at a State level. What Mr Howard is talking about is in no way an antidote for the crime that he perceives to exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On a point of order, Mr President: this is really a debate.
—-Order! It is becoming a very long answer.

—-Section 294 of the Industrial Relations Act requires a Federal Court to be satisfied that a union's behaviour is sufficiently grave to warrant such an action. Looking at precedential law and the activities of the Federal Court in making judgments on these matters in the past, there are no grounds to assume that the Federal Court would hold that such behaviour was grave and warranted the action of deregistration. There is no reason to believe that the Federal Court would share Mr Howard's ideological obsessions as he has portrayed them in the article.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude the answer by saying that it is about time Mr Howard and the Opposition learnt that the best way to practise industrial relations in this country is to adopt the cooperative approach of this Government and not try to regurgitate the conflict approach of the Fraser years. He would find that the industrial relations system--if he could at least develop a nodding acquaintance with it --has the in-built checks and balances to resolve the problem, and I recommend he read section 115 of the Federal Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —- My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the Government's assurances in the March industry statement and in correspondence to industry bodies that strong anti-dumping and countervailing legislation would ensure fair competition in the domestic market for Australian farmers against highly subsidised imports, and in view of today's announcement that applications have been made to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to import 30,000 to 40,000 tonnes of wheat and barley into Australia--which would be subsidised, as the only countries, other than Australia, that do not subsidise are New Zealand and Argentina --will the Government give an unequivocal guarantee to the already hard-pressed Australian grain grower that he will not be further hit by unfair competition from highly subsidised imports on his domestic market, as he is in the corrupt world export market? Is the Minister aware that our anti-dumping laws will not stop this imported grain as, according to our anti-dumping laws, it takes at least 135 days before duties can be imposed and grain would firstly have to come into Australia and cause material injury before any action could be taken by the industry under the anti-dumping legislation? Can the Minister tell the grain grower what action his Government intends to take to stop this unfair situation arising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The advice given to me late this morning by Mr Crean's office is that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has not received any actual application for import permits for wheat or barley. That is not to say that such an application may not be received, but the question is perhaps a little premature in that light.

ANSWER.PARA: The article in question to which Senator Boswell refers does point to the threat of some possible injury from future imports. It is my understanding that the legislation does allow for anti-dumping applications to be lodged on this basis. Mr Beddall, the Minister for Small Business and Customs, has advised me that he has asked the Australian Customs Service to contact the Grains Council of Australia to provide any guidance necessary for the Council to lodge any application that it might wish to in these circumstances.

More generally, the Government is very conscious of the need for timely and effective anti-dumping procedures. Senator Boswell will no doubt recall that in March this year in the course of the industry statement the Government did announce shorter times for the Australian Customs Service to conduct its preliminary inquiries. There is of course an ongoing review taking place at the moment as to some larger aspects of anti-dumping policy.

In particular, the Government decided to strengthen those processes immediately by speeding up the processing of anti-dumping subsidisation complaints by Australian industries so that in most cases where there is injury to local producers provisional measures will be available 40 days sooner than at present. Better access to the system has now been provided for Australia's agricultural and horticultural producers--the immediate context to which Senator Boswell referred. Generally, the time taken for the first stage of the process--the prima facie stage--has been reduced from 55 to 35 days. Again, it is intended that there be an overall reduction of 40 days in the time taken to reach a preliminary finding.

So Senator Boswell's reference to 135 days is, at least as I understand it, the outside term within which these actions can be effective. Certainly, a number of processes and procedures are in place to enable a faster action than that to be taken if the context so requires it. I repeat: to the extent that some guidance may be necessary in response to a possible application that may be made to deal with a possible import application that may be made, the Customs Service is willing to provide that guidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the Grains Council or the wheat growers would be able to manage a preliminary anti-dumping case when the wheat is on the water and is coming into Australia without the price which would determine whether material injury had already been done?

—-That is a technical question, to which I am simply not in a position to give a clear cut answer. I do not have enough material at my fingertips. All I can say is that the advice I have been given on relatively short notice does suggest that there may be some procedural way through this which will meet the particular point that Senator Boswell has raised. I am sure that if the Grains Council seeks the advice of the Customs Service it will be taken through the options in that respect. I will refer Senator Boswell's question to the relevant Ministers for perhaps a more detailed answer in this respect and do my best to get him an early reply.
—-Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Walters asked me a question as to whether the Government knew that the National Companies and Securities Commission, under Mr Bosch, was allowing companies to avoid prosecution by the payment of substantial sums of money to general revenue. I was unable to answer that question yesterday; I did not even know of this allegation. I understand it came in the course of a royal commission hearing and it is not appropriate for the Government to comment on unsubstantiated statements or allegations which are made in the course of a royal commission hearing.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I can say that it was a well-known practice of the National Companies and Securities Commission to reach commercial settlements with companies in relation to matters arising from its supervision of the activities of those companies. The lack of enforcement action in relation to corporate law was a key factor in the Commonwealth and the States replacing the old regulatory structure with the Australian Securities Commission, which has as one of its principal objectives the investigation and enforcement of the corporations law.

I add that, in a situation in which no one Minister or parliament--that is to say State or Federal--was responsible for corporate legislation, as was the case with the cooperative scheme under the national companies and securities legislation, it is no wonder that the law was not enforced properly. That is the reason why this Government made a commitment and established the Australian Securities Commission which, I have to remind honourable senators, the Opposition opposed. Mr Henry Bosch, who was then the Chairman, said in a radio program yesterday that he could not understand all the fuss about this as it was set out in his book.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Patterson asked me a question relating to expenditure on promotional or advertising materials concerning the proposed introduction of the $3.50 charge for general practitioner consultations. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.
—-Can you read that? Is it long? I would like to know the answer.

—-The response given at the Senate Estimates Committee on 19 September 1991 related to the expenditure expected to be incurred by the Health Insurance Commission in preparing for the introduction of the $3.50 co-payment on 1 November 1991. Based on anticipated commitments, it would have to be made to achieve a 1 November implementation of the Budget proposals. The most significant of those commitments--
—-I can't hear you.
—-The honourable senator should tell his colleagues--including the senator next to him--to keep quiet and then he may hear.
—-Order! There is too much comment.
—-Could Senator Tate--
—-I do not need a lesson from Senator Walters on elocution.
—-Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—-The most significant of these commitments have been deferred pending finalisation of the Caucus decision. In respect of promotional activities, an amount of $30,000 has been spent to date--
—-Order! Senator Tate, resume your seat. There is a point of order.

—-Mr President, Senator Tate completely misunderstood what I said. I said, `I cannot hear Senator Tate'--and it was mainly because of the chatter on this side that I could not hear him. I asked you, Mr President, whether Senator Tate would be able to start again because I was unable to hear.
—-Order! There is no point of order, but what Senator Walters said was true; there was too much talk on the Opposition side for Senator Tate to be heard.

—-The most significant of the commitments for expenditure referred to in the Senate Estimates Committee have been deferred pending finalisation of the Caucus decision. In respect of promotional activities, an amount of $30,000 has been spent to date for the production of a leaflet composed of $25,000 for inclusion with Medicare cheques immediately following the Budget and announcing the Budget changes and $5,000 for the presentation of promotional brief concepts by four agencies. No advertising agency has yet been appointed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Herron asked me a question relating to a consultancy carried out by Bernie McKay and Associates for the National Health Strategy. Rather than seeking leave, I will take up everybody's time by reading the three pages of the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Bernie McKay and Associates were engaged to carry out a consultancy jointly funded by the National Health Strategy and the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Committee. The consultancy formed the basis of issues paper No. 2 of the National Health Strategy. While Bernie McKay and Associates were the main consultants, the firm led a team including a number of subcontractors. Mr McKay's firm was selected following consideration of tenders from six consultants. The selection was made by the AHMAC working party on health care funding, which included representatives of the States and the Commonwealth as well as the peak public and private hospital organisations.

The working party made its selection on the basis of the consultants' understanding of the project objectives, their strategic analysis and reporting capacity, their project planning and management ability, the expertise of team managers and the overall cost and value of the proposals. The proposal put by Bernie McKay and Associates ranked very well on all grounds and the firm was overall considered to be the most able to complete the contract at the lowest price. At $443,000, it was the third most expensive tender in a range from $250,000 to $900,000. After the original contract was let, the AHMAC working party and the National Health Strategy extended the contract to cover some additional related tasks at a cost of a further $85,000, bringing the total contract price to $528,000.

Mr McKay was the Secretary to the Department of Health in 1987 until the July 1987 machinery of government changes. The consultancy dealt with issues relating to the access to, demand for and financing of hospital services and had nothing to do with the issue of the $3.50 co-payment for medical services.

The Government considers the paper to be good value for money given the wide range of issues addressed in the paper and the substantial pieces of original research, such as those reproduced in the appendices, which were carried out as part of the project. The Government has invited submissions on the issues raised in the paper. These will be considered by the National Health Strategy and the Government in formulating its policy on the issues raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron on 9 October 1991, relating to the National Health Strategy Review.

The reply stated that the $528,000 consultancy dealt with issues related to access to, demand for and financing of hospital services. Hospital services account for 44 per cent of health care expenditure. The cost of the public hospital sector is increasing at 12 per cent per annum. These costs are related to the growth of medical services over all. In fact, yesterday the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, said:
We have a problem in the growth of medical services in this country.
That is absolutely correct. He also stated:

There was also a recognition that general practice required attention, both in the growth in the number of services in the general practice area and in the deterioration in the quality of the service being provided by general practice.
That is also absolutely correct. I further quote:
We have an oversupply of doctors in general practice in this country.
That is correct. He then went on:
Our concern is to get to the root of the matter, to develop good policy--

Note that he says `to develop good policy'; there is no good policy in action at the moment, but he is going to develop one. He has called in somebody for $528,000, or $2,467 per page, to give him a policy. I continue:
to ensure that we get a handle on the costs so that we are able to restrain them in the longer term,

The root of the matter is not cost constraint; the root of the matter is that it is impossible to provide good quality health care with a scheme that is open-ended for the consumers who are bulkbilled at no cost and the provider doctors who bulkbill without constraint. The problem is Medicare itself.
Yesterday, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
Because we are proud of our achievement in implementing the most stable, efficient and equitable health care financing system in Australia's history--
Note the word `stable'. Health care costs in this country have been stable for 15 years. They were stable for seven years before this Government came to govern. It had nothing to do with Medicare.

The Prime Minister said the system was efficient. The Medicare levy and the amount that it has been bringing in has been dropping rapidly. It has dropped 25 per cent in the last four years. It is bringing in only 18 per cent of health care costs according to the current Budget estimates. The Prime Minister said that it is totally efficient. He also said it was equitable. This system has resulted in a position where quality of health care is available only to those who can afford it, and there are lengthening queues for those who cannot.

What has happened as a result of this system? The use of pathology has increased 42 per cent per patient over last the five years; radiology has increased 26 per cent; medical services used per person have gone up 23 per cent in the last five years; health insurance rates have gone up 100 per cent in the last five years; and the use and cost of pharmaceuticals has doubled in the last eight years. Waiting lists have gone through the roof. Every day, 80,000 people are on waiting lists for elective surgery in this country. The number of doctors has increased by 50 per cent in the last 10 years, and only 23 per cent are practising outside the major centres. The gap between medical fees and the Medicare refund has doubled in the last five years. The demand for screening is increasing. The cost of the public hospital sector is increasing at 12 per cent per year. The level of private insurance has nearly halved. It was 70 per cent in 1983 when this Government came into office and it is now 45 per cent for the whole of Australia. The majority of those people are in the older age groups and are taking more out of the system than is being put in.
The Prime Minister claims that we are proud of our achievement in implementing the most stable, efficient and equitable health care funding system in Australia. He also went on to say:
The major concern has been to ensure that nothing that we do damages the rate of direct billing for general practice services.

That is the very thing that is at the root of the whole problem, and he is going to do nothing about it. What this Government is trying to do is cost containment. Where is quality? It is not mentioned. All that the patient will get under the Government is more of the same--more cost containment, more rationing and more chaos in decision making, just as we have seen occurring at the moment in relation to the Government's small attempt at bringing in co-payment to restrain costs. The system is fundamentally flawed and it will not change until this Government goes out of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-For the past month we have heard the bleating of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) in an attempt to get him out of the ALP Caucus policy revolt. In his brief to the Caucus subcommittee, set up to examine the original $3.50 co-payment proposal, Minister Howe said that any proposal would have to achieve the same fiscal result for the health area.

SPEECH.PARA: In a doorstop interview on 3 September, Minister Howe again said:

. . .and any changes would have to be within the context of the Budget, in terms of the fiscal outcome. I mean we can't consider making changes that would shift the Budget's bottom line. I think the Caucus understands that the first consideration is certainly that the integrity of the Budget be maintained.
Later on in that same doorstop interview he said:
We have to sustain the package, in terms of the Government's overall bottom line.

In case Michelle Grattan had not heard what he said, he repeated that the bottom line had to be maintained and that the Budget should not be changed. The bottom line is that any change must meet the budgetary bottom line. Any change is a good policy and the criteria for good policy is set out in the resolutions. So three times Minister Howe reminded everybody that that was the case. In Question Time yesterday, the Prime Minister said:
. . . the Government's Budget strategy will remain intact. . .
There we have what the Minister for Community Services and Health and the Prime Minister said about this matter. Mr Willis then got in on the act. Yesterday in answer to a question he said:
Of course, it is the Government's objective to ensure that the Budget as announced is implemented and we will do everything in our power to ensure that happens.

There we have three Ministers--the Prime Minister, Minister Howe and Minister Willis --all telling us that the bottom line was that the budgetary implications would not change. We have all heard those senior Cabinet colleagues consistently maintaining that the bottom line of the Budget proposal must be maintained. But what has happened today? What did we hear today on the news waves? They scattered round last night. It is no wonder Government members were so grumpy in Question Time today. Until 3 o'clock this morning they were coddling together some other proposal to satisfy Caucus. They have come up with a proposal that can in no way preserve the bottom line.

I have done some rough calculations with the figures I have and it looks as though the proposal they are now putting forward would cost $100m. We heard three Ministers yesterday telling us that the bottom line was not going to change. They have been rolled. The Prime Minister has lost; Minister Howe will have lost; Minister Willis will have lost. But the way Mr Hawke keeps his numbers, the Left will have won. Mr Keating will also have lost because Mr Hawke will stay in power for just that little bit longer.
It was rather pathetic to hear the Prime Minister yesterday in Question Time defending his ailing health system. Senator Herron quoted Mr Hawke, and I will quote him again. He said:
. . . we are proud of our achievement in implementing the most stable, efficient and equitable health care financing system in Australia's history--it is a pride that we all share. . .

Do not let Mr Hawke speak on my behalf or on my colleagues' behalf. We do not share that pride and I am sure it is the royal `we'; I am sure there are some people on the other side of the chamber who do not share that pride when they face their constituents who are waiting on elective surgery lists or who cannot afford to pay their health insurance premiums. I am certainly not proud of the massive waiting lists and all the other degradation of the health system that my colleague Senator Herron ably outlined. How can the Prime Minister make such a claim about our health system?

Not only are there noticeable problems in the health care delivery system, but also the whole system has been grossly underfunded by the Medicare levy since its inception. Any members of the Australian public who think that their Medicare levy covers the cost of health care is deluded, misguided and misinformed. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber can tell the public that that is not the case until they are blue in the face, but the Government is wrong. There is no doubt that the Government has no idea which way to turn to remedy the problems in the health system or, in fact, in our economy. It is fresh out of ideas.

I remind the Senate that this ALP Government is divided not only over this issue but also over the leadership--the battle between Mr Keating and Mr Hawke. It is divided over the media ownership issue; the third runway at Sydney; at a ministerial level on fast tracking; and now on the Medicare rebate issue. It is divided, divided and divided again on major issues. I remind the Senate, as we have been reminded, and as we have reminded the Government over and over again, of the saying, `If you can't govern your Party, you can't govern the country'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The number of consultants, reviews, surveys and Senate committees that have been set up to look at and try to cope with Medicare is unbelievable. Here we have another one costing half a million dollars. When the Government does know the problems on which it must eventually make a decision, it is just a sheer waste of money. The Government's health policy is a complete shambles. As of today, it has no health policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Two months ago, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) said that there would be a $3.50 co-payment for bulkbilled patients. The Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) were rolled by their own members. Mr Hawke is a pathetic figure. He has been rolled by his Caucus. He is incapable of making any tough decisions because he is a prisoner of the Keating challenge. He is weak and pathetic and not a leader's bootlace. He cannot stick to a decision that has been made. He has come to the situation where meetings have been held--I do not know how many--and a committee has been set up. It has had three or four meetings, yet no decisions have been taken. At 6 o'clock tonight, there will be another Caucus meeting. Peter Walsh was right when he referred to the Prime Minister as `Old Jellyback'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think you are referring to Senator Walsh.

—-Yes, Senator Walsh. The whole integrity of the Budget is in a shambles. When do we debate the Budget? We are meant to pass the Appropriation Bills next week. Where are the figures? What will the figures be? We have absolutely no idea what the Government is putting forward. There has been no other time in Australia's history when we have not been able to debate the Budget figures and pass Appropriation Bills, not because of the Opposition taking opposing views but because the Government does not have a clue what to ask us to vote on. When are we getting the amended figures and what will they be?

SPEECH.PARA: We noted in the midday news that the Cabinet has come up with a new co-payment figure of $2.50. For heaven's sake, tell me the difference. If the Government is going to make a co-payment, then it has ruined its bulkbilling exercise anyway and it has acknowledged that the Opposition and the AMA have been right from the very beginning--bulkbilling will create overservicing. The Government has stuck by its plan to such a degree that it has created the biggest debt that is possible in the health care system. There are 75,000 people waiting to get into hospitals. The whole thing is a shambles and at last the Government is attempting to back off. But it is not willing to go the whole way. It is not willing to get rid of bulkbilling, except for the pensioners and the disadvantaged who we all agree should have access to bulkbilling.

The Government wants to give the Bonds and the Packers of this world the ability to get bulkbilling, and now it is saying that it will charge them $2.50 for the effort. The injustice of the whole thing is unbelievable. If the Government continues to tax the ordinary wage earner on $20,000 a year 38c in the dollar and it allows Packer and Bond--`Me mate Bondy' as far as Mr Hawke is concerned--to get bulkbilling and pay only $2.50, then all its credibility is shot.

I will give those opposite a very quick run-down on the difference between a State that bulkbills and one that does not. In Tasmania, where we do not have any of those entrepreneurial clinics, bulkbilling by general practitioners amounts to 55.9 per cent of services. In New South Wales, the figure is 74.6 per cent; it has the entrepreneurial clinics.

The cost of a doctor's fee per man, woman and child in New South Wales is $250, with 74.6 per cent bulkbilled. In Tasmania, the figure is $191, because only 55.9 per cent bulkbill. If the cost per capita in Tasmania, with our small population, equalled that of New South Wales, an additional $26.6m would be taken out of taxpayers' pockets through Medicare, all because of the Government's ideology. Imagine what the cost of that would be all over Australia. The Government will have to change. It will have to get rid of bulkbilling. For heaven's sake, the Government should have the courage to do it now and not fiddle around the edges, and for once let the Prime Minister show true leadership.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —-During Question Time, in a petulant answer to a question from his side of the chamber, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) implied that statements attributed to me in a Reader's Digest article were inaccurate. Let me say that those statements attributed to me were entirely accurate and that when the Reader's Digest representative came to me that person made it perfectly clear that any anecdotal stories or any information which could not be sourced would not be considered.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —-I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 10 October, from Senator Michael Baume:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The Hawke Government's failure to provide positive policies or hope for any significant reduction in September's disastrous official Australian unemployment rate of 10.2%.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The Hawke Government's failure to provide positive policies or hope for any significant reduction in September's disastrous official Australian unemployment rate of 10.2%
Today, Australia's highest level of unemployment was announced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. There have never been as many Australians out of work as these figures reveal.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And the Government benches are empty!

—-There are three members of the Labor Government here today to debate this issue. If one is looking for any symbolism about the lack of concern of this Government for the record levels, the disastrous levels, of unemployment in Australia, this is the symbol. The Government could not care less. It has done nothing about it and the situation is getting worse.

SPEECH.PARA: In Question Time today we saw how the Government had no answers and, in fact, no knowledge of what is happening to unemployment. I asked Senator Button whether he could give us any sort of guarantee, any sort of undertaking, that unemployment would not reach 11 per cent. I asked him that because we all remember the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), whom Senator Button represents in this chamber, giving one of his usual solemn undertakings a year ago that unemployment would not reach 10 per cent. He said, `The truth'--as if the Prime Minister would recognise it if he fell over it--`is this: unemployment will not reach double digits'. The only double digits that I suppose Mr Hawke was thinking of were those gestures made to him as a result of his growing unpopularity, as a result of his total inability to tell the truth. Mr Keating can attest to that. Deals done before witnesses are not abided by. How would we expect a solemn obligation, a solemn undertaking, that there would be no double digit inflation to be true? Here we have another recklessly made and readily broken promise.

Today, I asked Senator Button, as Mr Hawke's representative, whether unemployment would reach 11 per cent. Senator Button could give no undertaking, no guarantees. He was given plenty of opportunity to do so. Senator Alston pressed him about what he was doing, what plans the Government had, what action it would take and what response it would make to the dissidents within its own ranks, such as the Victorian Premier and the former Treasurer, who was discovered busily on the road to Damascus. Of course, Senator Button had no response, gave no undertakings and made no promises.

I suppose one could say that Senator Button was being sensible; after all, Mr Hawke's promises are worthless. Perhaps Senator Button did not want to discredit his own standing. He did not even relay any of Mr Hawke's attitudes on the present situation. The problem is that, if this Government does not know what is happening, has no idea what the unemployment level is likely to be--it clearly has no perception of how to deal with the problem--what hope is there for Australians, the Australians who are out of work, the 10.2 per cent of Australians who cannot get jobs, the close to 30 per cent of young Australians, when this Government, firstly, does not know what is happening and, secondly, has no plans to correct it, no plans to fix it up? The claim that it has no plans to fix it up is coming from the mouths of the Australian Labor Party dissidents themselves such as Mr Keating, who is calling for action because the Government is not being successful.

At this stage all we have in front of us--Senator Button restated it today--is the Budget forecast that unemployment would rise in the first half of the year to 10.75 per cent and ease in the second half to average about 10 1/2 per cent. It is the overwhelming view of economists and business people that this huge unemployment rate will remain for years. That is unlike the 1983 recession when the unemployment level was due to Australia's worst drought in 50 years. When it rained the level of unemployment began to fall. It will take a lot more than rain, or even Mr Hawke's tears, to bring about a fall in unemployment this time.

The current situation is not drought induced; this recession has been engineered by Mr Keating. He proudly said so. If this Government has the capacity to engineer a recession, maybe some people think it might have the capacity to engineer a recovery. I do not believe it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The whole Government is responsible.

—-As Senator Short says, the whole Government is responsible. We now find that, there having been governmental unanimity on the need to engineer a recession, we have division within the Government about the need, the capacity or the desire to engineer or assist any sort of economic recovery or any sort of lift in employment.
—-Policy paralysis.

—-As Senator Kemp says, there is policy paralysis because of division. We have already seen evidence of that in the matter of health. We have just discussed it. Throughout the central problems facing this nation--environmental problems; whether we should have new projects for job creation; how the health system should go; employment--everywhere we see division, lack of leadership, factionalism and, of course, policy paralysis.

SPEECH.PARA: Just how bad are these figures? Sometimes I wonder, when the Government seeks to defend them, whether it understands just how bad they really are. Given the way in which the Government just glosses over them, the way it says, `They are not really that bad', I wonder whether there is any real perception in the Government ranks about what is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Their mates have jobs.

—-Yes, their mates have got jobs and apparently, as we heard in Question Time, they are getting huge pay rises. Here we have a situation where there are fewer than two job vacancies for every 100 unemployed. The number of Australians out of work is 872,100 which, according to the official figures, is the highest in Australia's history. That is up 38 per cent in one year.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of all the official unemployed, there are the unofficial unemployed being hidden in job schemes and funded through various schemes. On top of that again there is massive underemployment. Over the last 12 months, despite this huge rise in the number of people unemployed, there has been an increase of 75,000 people who cannot get full time jobs and can only get part time jobs. These people have been saved from joining the unemployment queues only because they have been able to find part time jobs. So the figure for the total number of people who are employed, in a sense, does not give a clear indication of the collapsing job opportunities; the disaster that is facing so many Australians.

Over the last 12 months 243,000 full time jobs were wiped out. When a quarter of a million jobs are wiped out in a 12-month period, one has to look to see what the Government has done about it, what it is planning to do about it and whether it has any intention of doing anything about it. The main question is: does the Government understand the consequences of engineering that kind of job loss? That is what Mr Keating did.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is their new definition of social justice.

—-Yes, this is a new definition of social justice. The Government is prepared to weep about the unemployed but not prepared to give them jobs. Of the quarter of a million full time jobs lost, 100,000 were youth jobs that have been wiped out and 200,000 were male jobs that have been wiped out. It is now clear that it is not simply a question--as early in the recession it tended to be--of the majority of job losses being caused by employers not being prepared to put on new workers. We are now getting into the severe retrenchment end--the wiping out of jobs which takes place in a solid, severe recession.

SPEECH.PARA: The current huge unemployment rate--and the job loss, of course--is despite a slightly lower participation rate of 63.4 per cent than existed at the same time last year. In this place we keep hearing this phoney nonsense that the reason behind the high unemployment rate is a high participation rate. It is lower than it was this time last year but Government members still come up with this bunkum--all these excuses--and attempt to play down the reality which is, quite properly, worrying a large sector of their own Party. There are not simply 10.2 per cent of Australians who are out of work; those people looking for full time work represent 10.8 per cent of the Australian work force. Females looking for full time work make up about 11.6 per cent and males 10.5 per cent.
One can very clearly see how the Labor States continue to be the centres of economic and unemployment disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And the Green States.

—-I suppose that is a fair point. In Tasmania--a case in point--the unemployment rate is 11.4 per cent. In Western Australia it is 11 per cent. I suppose they are trying to stamp that out--they seem to resolve lots of things by stamps over in Western Australia. In Victoria the rate is 10.9 per cent; South Australia, 10.5 per cent; and, remarkably of course, in New South Wales it is 9.8 per cent, along with Queensland which, until relatively recently had a non-Labor Government. That State is staying alive, I suppose, because of the hollow logs where money was carefully put aside for a rainy day--or, in this case, a very dry day--and has the best result.

SPEECH.PARA: What is being done to resolve this disaster? This disaster, by the way, extends in a terrible way to young people. Tasmania has a 31 per cent youth unemployment rate, according to official figures. That is despite all the stunts and hiding that has been going on--all the shovelling of young people back to school which, for many, I support because it will give them greater job opportunities and develop their skills; but for many the paying of Austudy is simply keeping them out of the dole queues. Victoria--and this may explain why Mrs Kirner is so enthusiastic for the Federal Government at last to do something about it--has a 32.3 per cent youth unemployment rate. Naturally, New South Wales, the non-Labor State, is down at the bottom of the list. It is still very bad at 26.6 per cent, but much better than the rest.

Here we have a situation where the unemployment rate is awful. Senator Button would not rule out 11 per cent. Mr Keating is now determinedly changing his position saying that `the. . . ALP should return to its ``great charter'' of stimulating growth and employment'. There is no doubt that Mr Keating did stimulate growth and unemployment by plunging Australia into the greatest debt we have ever had--increasing our foreign debt from $25 billion to $135 billion, or so. As we can see, all those jobs were so vulnerable because they were bought on hire purchase. The time is up and those jobs are being wiped out. Mr Keating says that Labor was duty-bound to `look after working Australians--give them a job, a piece of the economy'. Of course, it was Mr Keating, with the support of his colleagues, who engineered the recession that wiped out those jobs.

Here we have a Government which Mr Keating himself says is on the wrong track. He knows all about being on track because the economy was always on track when he was Treasurer. Now it happens to be on the wrong track. Mr Keating is quoted as saying:
I think the balance has now swung back in favour of growth and employment.
The fact is the economy now has sunk too far down with too much attendant damage to confidence and psychology.
That is not the Liberal Party talking; that is Mr Keating, the man who engineered the recession and who is now asking to be trusted to try to engineer a recovery.

Here we have a situation where Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner say that the Government is wrong, that it has no policy and it offers no hope. It is so divided that it cannot act. It has no economic policy and no answers to these problems. It is leaderless and we cannot get any undertaking from it that the figures will not get worse and worse. We have no undertaking from the Government that unemployment will not reach 11 per cent. We never get any undertakings from Senator Button that the Government will resolve--or has any proposals to resolve--the disaster of unemployment which it has now pushed this nation into. It is a tragic situation. That is why I moved this urgency motion today and I urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Baume has just concluded his address on the urgency motion which he moved. The motion states that the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's failure to provide positive policies or hope for any significant reduction in September's disastrous official Australian unemployment rate of 10.2 per cent.

The operative words in that motion are `failure to provide positive policies or hope for any significant reduction'. I want to maintain those operative words at the front of the brain of the Senate for a few minutes. It is said that sometimes the worst place that anyone can have a serious debate about serious matters is in Parliament because participants in a serious debate will exploit arguments for political purposes, rather than go to any considered analysis of the issues and contribute across the chamber helpful or constructive argument in dealing with matters of great national importance.

There is no doubt that the level of unemployment is a matter of significant national importance. It is a level of unemployment that the Government takes no comfort in. The Government has no policy which intends to sustain that level of unemployment. In fact, the Government's policy settings are to reduce it. It is not to be a permanent feature of our economy. By the fact that it exists, it is a concern and a worry. This Government shares the concern and worry of those who are unemployed.

This is a debate put forward by the Opposition in words of its own choosing--`positive policies or hope for any significant reduction'. What did we get in this debate? Did we get any positive suggestions from the Opposition as to what it would do? We did not. Did we get any reasoned argument as to what policy settings should be put in place to resolve the problem? We did not. We got an argument about what Mr Keating may have said, an argument about a divided party and an argument about lack of leadership in the current circumstances.

I want to make this point quickly, because there are a lot of meaty things that I want to refer to. What the Opposition has said today is no substitute for debate. This is a serious question. If the Opposition wants to be regarded as serious, it should act seriously, bring forward serious argument and explain to the Australian people how a 15 per cent consumption tax and the consequence of super charged inflation will help the unemployed. It should explain that. The Opposition should explain how its unclarified policies on labour market change will help unemployment in this country. It should explain that.

These are policy issues fundamental to a consideration of where the Opposition stands and what the Opposition offers as a course out of these circumstances. The fact that no constructive Opposition policy has been put forward to deal with this matter indicates only that the Opposition has none. Therefore, it cannot be considered as a serious and earnest critic of this matter of significance.

The participation rate--those people participating in the work force--was referred to in Senator Baume's remarks. He took comfort in the fact that the participation rate is lower now than when it was at its peak--and certainly it is. The participation rate was at its peak in July 1990--which was a record for Australia--under the Hawke Government. The participation rate was 64.2 per cent; it now stands at 63.4 per cent. The participation rate in the last year of the Fraser Government was 60.3 per cent. If we had the same participation rate as in the last year of the Fraser Government, unemployment in Australia would not be 10.2 per cent; it would be 5.5 per cent. It would be 5.5 per cent if we had the Opposition's record of the number of people who are in the work force. The fact that we have enlarged the work force to near record levels means that the percentage of unemployment is higher. That is a criticism of success in getting people in work. If we were to rely on the performance of the Opposition, the unemployment level would now be 5.5 per cent. That is a significant figure in this context.

Dr Hewson recently went to the National Press Club. He never told the assembled press of Australia what his policies with respect to a consumption tax were, how it would adversely impact on the earnings of wage and salary earners and how it would supercharge inflation. He never told them any of that. One of the snippets that he dropped in his contribution to the debate there was that `an acceptable level'--his words--`of unemployment' is around 6 per cent, maybe 6.3 per cent. I make the point in passing that, on the performance during the Hewson years or the Fraser years, when Dr Hewson was the chief economic adviser to the Fraser Government, the level of unemployment now is lower.

I do not want to dwell on those figures because anyone can play with figures to make a case. We can make a case for far better performance than the Opposition, but that is not of any great interest to unemployed people. They want to know what is being done to deal with the situation. Many things that are important are being dealt with in the present circumstances.

I believe that we have the basic policy elements that will restore sustainable growth and thereby sustainable and secure job growth. We are now a low inflation country. Make no mistake: the maintenance of low inflation is critical to achieve sustainable job growth into the future. Inflation distorts investment decisions, significantly reducing the incentives for productive job-creating investment. Our inflation rate at present is 3.4 per cent. It now stands below the 4.3 per cent of our major trading partners in the OECD. We are doing better in terms of inflation than our major trading partners in the OECD. For the first time in a generation this country has the opportunity to make that low inflation outcome a permanent feature in the economic landscape.

The commitment we have received from our accord partners, to work with us in keeping Australian inflation at levels comparable with that of our major trading partners, is a key element in our strategy for sustainable growth. That is an important thing. Not only have we achieved a 3.4 per cent inflation rate, but the Budget Papers suggest an inflation outcome this year of 3 per cent and we have a commitment on the wages policy front--something that the Opposition cannot deliver--that we will keep inflation locked in at around that level. That will be a very positive achievement to ensure that job growth follows because of the non-distortion of investment decisions that that will bring.

This Government has made the Australian economy more competitive than the one we inherited in 1983. Restructuring has not just been talked about; it is being achieved now. The performance of our manufacturing sector, competing on world markets, attests to that. Over the period of 1983 to 1991 the value of exports of machinery, transport equipment and other elaborately transformed items increased by 220 per cent, involving growth in volumes of 149 per cent. Over the last two financial years, the volume of these exports has grown by an astonishing 57 per cent. The result has been a dramatically improved balance of payments. The balance on goods and services is forecast to be in surplus this financial year--for the first time in over 10 years.

These figures are a remarkable indication of the effectiveness of the restructuring that we have undertaken in the economy. The fact is that in the past 8 1/2 years the Government has instituted a program of economic reform unprecedented in the history of this country. Never has the pace been faster than in 1991 when, through the March economic statement and the processes set under way by the Special Premiers Conference and the Budget, we can see the evidence of fundamental changes that we are now working to bring about.

Our recent Budget served two fundamental purposes in setting the parameters for sustainable economic and job growth. First, the structural integrity of the Budget was preserved. The offsetting of all new spending initiatives with Budget savings will ensure that, as the economy recovers, public sector savings will again make sure that there are sufficient savings to fund new investment. Secondly, we increased expenditure on labour market and training programs by 50 per cent in real terms to make sure that those caught in this downturn can equip themselves for a return to employment. Because of the training component it is constructive employment, employment that does not just offer a job but a career. Such expenditure will help to ensure that skill shortages do not emerge during the recovery phase.

We have also strengthened our assistance for the unemployed by reducing waiting periods for rent assistance. For those in extreme financial crises we have allocated an additional $3.5m this year for emergency relief. We have both responded to the immediate problems created by the recession and laid the foundations for a sustained and durable recovery. Unlike the Opposition, our concern for the unemployed is real and, of course, we are doing something about it.

One point should be made clear; that is, the coalition's policies would lead to much higher unemployment than Australia experiences at present. What else could be the outcome of a policy package of a consumption tax while at the same time slashing government expenditure to obtain a balanced Budget? A balanced Budget, as demanded by Dr Hewson, would require spending to be slashed by $3 billion in key areas such as income support, education and training, health and other vital areas of government support.

The Murphy economic model, which is a model that the Opposition relies on, itself shows that the direct effect of such cuts would be a net loss of nearly 50,000 extra jobs. There would be a net loss on the economic model as a result of the Opposition policies amounting to an extra 50,000 jobs. We know one area where the Opposition plans to save money. We know that Opposition members intend to throw unemployed people off unemployment benefits after nine months. Even their own grassroots supporters in the Liberal Party are concerned about such a draconian policy. We have seen the impact of it in New Zealand where a permanent underclass has been created in society.

The Opposition's consumption tax would increase inflation. High inflation is not consistent with long-term sustainable job increases. The coalition has no way of bringing inflation down, no way of controlling wages, and no way of minimising industrial disputation other than through high unemployment. The obvious conclusion to draw is that a coalition government would mean higher sustained levels of unemployment than those endured currently.

Conversely, our policies are focused, and will continue to be focused, on a sustainable recovery in both the economy and employment. While the unemployment figures for September are disappointing--and we take no joy in them--trend figures show that the large falls in employment are now behind us. The Department of Employment, Education and Training's leading indicator of employment suggests that employment will soon begin to rise. We are confident that the pick-up in activity foreshadowed in the Budget is now becoming apparent and that we will see sustainable employment growth by early 1992.

There are signs as well that a recovery in employment is occurring. The trend employment level increased in September. The underlying movement in employment is no longer falling. Trend estimates for full time employed males continued to decrease, but the rate of decline has slowed in recent months. For full time employed females the trend estimates have been increasing since June 1991.

The signs that the recovery is under way, which is the key achievement of the settings that we have put in the economy, are manifold and I shall refer to some of them. The current account deficit for August was $575m in seasonally adjusted terms. This was the smallest monthly deficit since January 1988 and the second smallest deficit since April 1984. In August the balance on goods and services was $696m, the highest monthly result on record. This is in line with the Budget prediction that the balance on goods and services is expected to be in surplus this financial year--the first surplus in 12 years on that account. The trend estimate for the current account deficit was $848m, which was the ninth consecutive fall in the trend estimate and the lowest result since 1984.

The building industry is now showing signs of recovery. In July the number of dwelling units for which housing finance was provided increased by 8.1 per cent over June 1991 in seasonally adjusted terms and 36 per cent over July 1990. They are quite important upward movements in the amount of finance being approved for dwelling construction in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They do not cover up what you have done with housing.

—-That is the first indicator one looks to for signs of economic recovery. I have not addressed Senator Reid about the scaling down of interest levels in this country that we have managed over the last several years, but they too have been quite significant.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to another indicator, motor vehicle registrations. I find that it too is showing positive signs of improvement. In July motor vehicle registrations increased in seasonally adjusted terms by 3.6 per cent over June this year. That is a positive improvement.

I wish now to refer to some industrial relations reforms and how they are playing an important role in creating the foundation for further employment growth.
