The fundamental reforms that we have undertaken in pursuing award restructuring and the structural efficiency principle provide a strong basis for the creation of more secure and rewarding jobs in more efficient and productive workplaces in this country.

The focus has been on skills development, training and efficiency. We have moved from a task-based taylorist focus on workplace organisation to a wages system based on skills training and competence. The changes have enabled workplaces to become more efficient and more productive. This has been done in many cases by rewarding and recognising skills and training, and by the removal of the outdated work practices and restrictive work practices that have applied in the past. Demarcation disputes have been reduced, and union amalgamations have reduced the number of unions in the Australian workplace.

Multiskilling has enabled workplaces to be more flexible and responsive to change. Better training and multiskilling enable higher quality products and more efficient methods of production. Companies are thus enabled fully to utilise all the skills of their work force and the total sum of human resources. This includes proper recognition of skills of workers from overseas and the skills of women workers. The strategy enables companies to develop secure and long-term markets, to which they supply quality competitive products on time. This means more secure, rewarding employment and, more importantly, a strong basis for employment growth which will be sustained and secure.

This will be further assisted by the move to workplace bargaining, which will further encourage companies and their work force to develop arrangements which best suit their needs and will enable them to increase their productivity and profitability and create long-term, secure and rewarding jobs.

In a recent copy of the British magazine the Economist there appeared an article by a group of distinguished professors commenting on the labour market. The September copy of the magazine contained an article referring to a book entitled Unemployment: Macroeconomic Performance and the Labour Market. The authors are Richard Layard and Richard Jackman of the London School of Economics, and Professor Stephen Nickell of Oxford University. The point that the authors make in their survey of labour markets is that a highly significant result of this study is the relationship between wage bargaining, unions and unemployment. The study shows that for any given amount of union power, unemployment is lower if unions and employers coordinate their wage bargaining either across industries or nationally. What works worst of all is strong but uncoordinated unions, which is exactly the situation that the Opposition's industrial relations policy seems to invite. What we have with an accord is the coordinated approach which the authors of this economic study say works best to create employment.

Let me look at the record of employment growth, out of the 1982-83 recession, under the accord in this country. We found in a rapidly expanding economy in 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987 that wage outcomes were moderate, that employment growth was high and that industrial restraint and disputation were low. We had a coordinated accord approach. Living standards did not fall because tax cuts were given and Medicare was introduced as part of the social wage. We had a coordinated package through the accord which enabled investment to be created. Unfortunately, as the stock market crash in 1987 showed, a lot of the investment that had been created was lost in speculative takeovers and did not go to investment in productive industry in this country. We will again deliver that type of wage outcome. We have, through the existing accord, an ability to achieve high job growth coming out of this recession, moderate wages outcomes and a generation of income in the form of profits for investment. One hopes that the captains of Australian industry will have learnt from the experiences of being burnt in the speculative orgy leading up to 1987, and this time invest in productive areas of the economy which will generate long-term employment. That is our expectation and I believe that it can be delivered.

I conclude by saying that nothing has been put here this afternoon by the Opposition which shows an alternative policy. Questions on the consumption tax and how it will impact have not been answered by the Opposition. In the absence of that, this motion should be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand that Senator Lees and I will have 10 minutes each in which to speak, so I ask the Clerks to adjust the clocks. At lunch time today I went outside the ministerial suite and observed the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, addressing the media on this subject. He, like many other spokespeople on the economy and many economists, spoke as though the economy was a disembodied thing separate from the deliberations of this chamber and the deliberations of Parliament; as though it was something which went on quite divorced from the individuals who are properly elected by the people to determine the shape of and relationships in Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear expressions such as, `When the economy recovers we must be in a position to take advantage of it': `The economy'--something out there. During Question Time Senator Button was asked a question by Senator Kernot, and in the course of the reply said that he did not know what `interventionist policies' really meant.

What has happened to the Australian economy is that this Government has pursued deregulatory policies. It has gone back to the old idea of laissez faire--leave it to the market; let the market determine. It has deregulated banking, it has removed the limits on borrowing and it has allowed borrowing overseas to skyrocket. This has led directly not only to the very large level of unemployment which we are discussing this afternoon but also to a massive increase in foreign indebtedness. It has led to an enormous movement of capital from real productive enterprise into speculative paper shuffling. It has led also to a very significant and continuing shift of income from the poor towards the rich--a very significant increase in the inequity and injustice which that implies in this country. In addition, and partly as a consequence, it has led to the increase in unemployment we are discussing this afternoon.

Senator Cook in his speech said rather coyly that this Government, his Government, had been responsible for an economic reform program without precedent in Australia's history, to which I responded, `Hear, hear!'. That economic reform program which this Government has imposed on Australia is precisely the economic reform program which has produced all these adverse effects, one of which is the unemployment problem that we are discussing. It has led also to the use of extremely crude tools in an attempt to control the economy. The substantial increase in the interest rate not only has sucked into Australia more foreign speculative investment--and continues to do so--but also keeps the exchange rate high, and makes it extremely difficult for Australian industry effectively to produce the goods and services in this country which, again, would help the employment situation.

There is a shorthand term for this approach to economic management and it goes by the name of economic rationalism. Economic rationalism is neither economic nor rationalist. We as Democrats have to say that the Opposition no less than the Government is pursuing those same policies. The Opposition in power probably would have made the situation worse because it would have gone further and harder with precisely the same deregulatory policies. For those reasons, at the end of my speech I will move an amendment which simply adds the words `and the Opposition' after `Government'. The motion will read, `the Hawke Government's and the Opposition's failure to provide'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are not in government.

—-Nothing which we heard from Senator Baume today indicated that the Opposition has any policies at all which are different from the Government's which would address this problem. As Senator Baume's own motion reads, it is the provision of positive policies or hope that is lacking, and the Opposition is providing neither of those. It is one respect in which Senator Cook was absolutely right.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people have said that the one thing we learn from history is that we do not learn from history. We have been in this deregulatory situation before. We were in this deregulatory situation in the 1890s--100 years ago. Society substantially learned of the necessity for a hands-on approach to the economy--for the elected representatives to make the economy a creature of their activities and to make it an economy which serves the interests of the Australian people.

What we heard today from Senator Baume particularly made it sound as though Australia is in a unique situation with respect to this level of unemployment and the other economic problems which I have outlined. There is nothing unique about Australia's situation at all. If we look at other countries in the world we find that every country that has pursued these same policies of so-called economic rationalism is in the same situation--America, the UK and, of course, New Zealand. There are lessons to be learned, but neither the Government nor the Opposition is prepared to learn them.

The economist model of the market does not accord with the real world. The market does not accord with real human nature. It does not accord with the way real, decent human beings relate to each other or the way in which decent people in a decent society wish to behave and wish to relate to each other. Yet we hear from the Government and the Opposition, `Leave the economy to the market; let the market determine'. When the market determines that the economy will recover then we, as disjointed and disempowered spirits, will be in a position somehow to exploit that recovery.

The Opposition has proposed a consumption tax. The consumption tax is a direct extension of that same economic rationalist thinking. In addition, I would like to mention two specific objections to the consumption tax which relate directly to the motion before us this afternoon. The consumption tax, because it is a tax on goods and services at the point of consumption, implicitly means a tax on the labour component of goods and services. The Democrats consistently--

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is wrong, and you know it.

—-That is not wrong. Every good and service contains two components: the resource component and the labour component. Anybody with half a wit would understand that. I am sorry that Senator Knowles does not understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats would support a tax on resources and have always supported the idea of a resource-use tax. Putting a tax on the labour component of goods and services, which the consumption tax does implicitly, would simply drive down the ability to provide more employment. Moreover, the consumption tax is a tax on value adding. I simply ask the chamber and anybody else who is listening: does it make any sense, at a time when we need to encourage the maximum degree of value adding in Australia's production, to tax the very thing--value adding--that we want to encourage?

The Opposition and the Government have also been encouraging the fast tracking of industrial developments. Indeed, in the Minister's press release today we see those projects that he might encourage--the magnesium metal project; the aluminium smelter; the mini steel mill at Gladstone in Queensland; new port facilities; and a ferronickel project in Western Australia. All, by their very nature, are exploitative of natural resources; all, by their nature, are very capital insensitive; and all, by their nature, are not very productive of employment. They are not the sorts of things that are going to address the serious unemployment problem that we face.
Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:
That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Coulter moving an amendment to the motion.
I believe that both the Government and the Opposition stand condemned by this high unemployment rate, and it is appropriate that I have the opportunity to move that amendment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I, therefore, formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: After ``Government's'', insert ``and the Opposition's''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have all heard the figures today again and again from each speaker: 10.2 per cent now unemployed; some 100-odd people looking for every two jobs that are actually available; 872,100 officially unemployed; and 718,748 actually receiving unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: This is far more than just about statistics. Unemployment is actually about people. While travelling with the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, we heard in Queensland from the Queensland Department of Family Services. We were inquiring into the employment of people with disabilities. Something the Department said struck me as going to the heart of this debate. I quote:

The significance of employment in our society cannot be overestimated. It is frequently viewed as the primary measure of an individual's personal and social worth. For those who have the opportunity to participate, paid work can be an important source of self-esteem and economic independence.

Of course, that does not just cover those people with disabilities, but applies indeed to all Australians. The process of defining identity and self-worth in terms of paid employment is deeply ingrained in the Australian culture. Employment is not just about having a job, it is about fitting in. It is about the very fundamental right to actively participate in our society. If we accept that employment goes to the heart of our ability to function as human beings and to participate in society, then at least some one million Australians are now being denied that opportunity. That is the real tragedy of these unemployment statistics.

The tragedy confronts us with some fundamental questions about our notions of work and the way in which we organise our society. It confronts us with a crucial question: if we are not going to pursue and actually achieve full employment--a goal which I believe is both desirable and possible--how are we going to deal with the disastrous fall-out of continuing high levels of unemployment? That question throws up many challenges. One of the greatest of these is actually finding the jobs--of job creation.

The Australian Democrats reject the current hands-off approach, as Senator Coulter has outlined. We reject the view that the community, through government, cannot protect the interests of its members by ensuring that the economy serves the needs of the people and that we do not have effectively what we have now, which is a system working the other way around.

Just today, in response to these appalling figures, we have had John Dawkins arguing that there were inherent difficulties in forcing the pace of the job market. When the Government, under some pressure from within its own ranks, decides to dabble in job creation, it is apparently unable to come up with anything new or anything that reflects a community commitment to an economically and environmentally sustainable future.

The Democrats believe employment creation requires government commitment. But, first it requires denouncing the current irrational path of economic rationalism--zero protection, deregulation, level playing fields, these are all the buzz words of economic rationalism. There is no human face. There is no recognition--or, one suspects, no understanding--of the high economic and social costs associated with the relentless pursuit of economic goals. Community or government intervention in the operation of the market is seen as distorting efficient outcomes and is, therefore, bad. This, as Senator Coulter has already said, the Democrats reject totally.

The economic rationalists are happy to hand over the determination of national goals to the market. But the market is not some mythical, pure notion. It is, of course, full of unequal power relationships. There is no equal access, for example, to information and resources.

In Australia the financial market is dominated by foreign speculators. While we account for about one per cent of world trade, we have the fifth or sixth most traded currency in the world. Productive Australian companies and individuals are being manipulated by speculators moving hot money in and out of our country. Successful economies, such as Germany and Japan, have built their economic independence by controlling the flow of capital in and out of their countries, by restricting foreign investment and by boosting internal savings through incentives or regulation. The Government and the Liberal Party have abdicated their responsibility to manage the economy and have chosen the free marketplace to determine Australia's destiny.

I wish to deal briefly with the notion of the level playing field--the nonsense, perhaps I should say, of the level playing field. Rural families are at the moment experiencing the results of the economic rationalists' obsession with this notion. Not only is there little practical support for our farmers in the face of subsidised competition from overseas, but also the prevailing view is that we should press on with dismantling all our support systems. Protective barriers are being torn down, despite the fact that we already have the second lowest level of effective agricultural protection in the world. At 11 per cent protection, only New Zealand is below us. If we look at our major trading partners, such as Europe at 48 per cent, the United States at 30 per cent and Japan way up at 68 per cent, we certainly see that we are the agricultural odd couple.

The same forces which are destroying rural communities are now being set loose in our urban areas--set loose in suburbia. It is all very well for Senator Baume to come in here and condemn the Government's policies, but the senseless destruction of Australian jobs which has begun under Labor would continue under the coalition's plan to eliminate all industry protection by the year 2000. That is only eight years away.

Economic rationalism to date does not exactly have the runs on the board. From the perspective of ordinary Australians, the results so far have been massive job losses and an unprecedented transfer of national income--firstly, from wages to profits and, secondly, from the poor to the rich. The transfer of income and profits was agreed to by the ACTU in the original prices and incomes accord because it believed that would be used to finance productive long term investment that would mean jobs in the future. It was, unfortunately, sadly mistaken. What happened instead was that these profits were squandered in speculative investment--the boom made possible by financial deregulation. It seems that no mechanisms are going to be put in place to prevent that happening again. Rather than investment in long term productive enterprises, that portion of national income has been squandered by the same irresponsible people now clamouring for further deregulation and, indeed, further cuts in government expenditure.

While this destruction of future jobs was going on in the 1980s, there was also a massive redistribution of personal income. That certainly was not in the direction of the poor. Australians need to understand that the practical results so far for the economic rationalists can be summed up in one statement: the rich have got richer, the poorer have got poorer and unemployed.

The time has come to seriously challenge the prevailing theories and to start raising some alternatives and discussing them. It is time to start being creative about alternative approaches to unemployment--and here I mean investment in industry that actually is labour intensive, and not in some of those projects that have been suggested which are, in fact, capital intensive and provide very few jobs, if any, in the long term. Such approaches require a discussion of concepts currently not on the public agenda, concepts such as guaranteed minimum income, permanent job sharing, education and training guarantees for our young people. But there is a wealth of evidence around about the economic benefits of these alternatives, just as there is a wealth of evidence around indicating that, if we continue on our present course, we are heading for a dangerously divided society.

The evidence is clear. As a community, we have to spend in vital areas in order to reap the economic benefits later on. There is no doubt that we underspend in vital areas now, yet the economic rationalists clamour for further expenditure cuts. Unless we are going to permanently consign hundreds of thousands of Australians--indeed, at the moment, over a million--to the unemployment scrap heap, we need to take a good, hard look at some alternatives. We must start measuring the health and well-being of the nation by the health and well-being of the people. Economics is a means to an end, not an end in itself. It is time the Government and the coalition woke up to that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I did not quite fill my speaking time allotted earlier, because I understood I had only a quarter of an hour rather than 20 minutes. I will make a speedy response to the extraordinary contributions by the Australian Democrats and the quaint remarks by Senator Cook on behalf of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This pretence that the coalition has no response and has put up no proposals is one of the greatest farces of all time. The Government and the Democrats are so well aware of our package of radical reform that they spend most of their time in this place condemning it. To pretend that it does not exist is one of the most extraordinary bits of double talk, double standards, I have ever heard. They say it is a disaster and a disgrace. But today they have said, `The Opposition has put up no solutions to the problem'.

Our solutions are so well known, because they are subject to continual and irrational attack in this place, that it is almost unnecessary to repeat them yet again. But, for the benefit of the Australian Democrats and Senator Cook, let me restate them. The coalition is proposing radical reforms: total reform of the labour market; total reform of infrastructure, particularly transport and shipping; and getting rid of the inhibitions on development and on job creation that this Government has fostered, in most instances, at the insistence of and as a result of doing deals with the Australian Democrats, whose continual policies in this place have been to destroy job creation opportunities. We must have radical reform of the tax system by reducing the ludicrous concentration and unfair and excessive dependence on income tax from an unreasonably small proportion of the Australian population; that is, the people who have to pay it because they are paying pay-as-you-earn income tax.

It is not true for people to say that Australia is heavily taxed as against the rest of the world. The problem is the incidence of taxation--where it lies--and how so many people can evade it under this Government, which claims to have knocked off tax avoidance, tax evasion. The black economy is about $20 billion, according to many academic estimates, and others say more. It is unfair and unreasonable that so relatively few Australians have to carry such a huge burden as a proportion of the total tax bill.

Without these radical reforms, we have no hope. We have no hope under this Government. Look at what it is doing. Mr Keating says the Government is on the wrong track. What sort of hope would we have under the garbage we hear from the Australian Democrats? All their policy solutions are the policy solutions that sent Argentina down what Mr Keating refers to as the Argentinean road. The policy solutions of the Australian Democrats are those that destroyed South America and most of the tin-pot countries that at one stage were comparable with us. The Australian Democrats are the Argentinean road people, and it is intolerable for them to come here with this pious garbage.

Senator Cook should not pretend that we have no policy solutions, that we have the only answers. The Government has no answers and no leadership. The Government is a divided party that has no idea what it is doing or where it is going. Not even after its members stay up until 3 o'clock in the morning arguing amongst themselves to try to resolve the latest split can it come up with any coherent answer. I stress that the coalition does have the answers. It provides Australia's only hope. So long as the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party combine to ensure that those rational and coherent policies are not introduced, we will continue to have no hope.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the development of the Senior Executive Service. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows--

Mr President, I seek leave to table the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the Development of the Senior Executive Service. That report was tabled in the Senate on 18 October 1990.

As you will be aware, the report is primarily a review of the Senior Executive Service as a professional cadre and the structure of the senior administration of the Australian Public Service. It does not focus specifically on the issue of remuneration for the Senior Executive Service, although it has looked briefly at performance pay. However, I am aware that in the current climate almost any discussion of the state of the Australian Public Service will inevitably raise the issue of productivity based bargaining in the public service. Before proceeding any further, I would like briefly to affirm my strong awareness of the role of the Senior Executive Service in achieving ongoing commitment to productivity improvement.

Productivity bargaining is going to be a central feature of Australian industrial relations. I believe that it has important benefits for both workers and industry, and I believe that members of the Australian Public Service should, like workers in other industries, receive the benefits from demonstrated increases in productivity to which they have contributed. I am fully aware of the crucial role that the Senior Executive Service will play in changing the workplace culture in the Australian Public Service and achieving ongoing commitment to productivity improvement, both as a management corps and through the performance of its individual members. I am aware of the challenges it offers them as managers and leaders. I am also fully aware of the importance of ensuring that Senior Executive members receive a fair share of the rewards of productivity gains through an appropriate remuneration package. This will include performance pay, which will be introduced when the timing and details of the implementation are settled.

I am also, of course, aware that productivity improvement in both the Senior Executive Service and the broader Australian Public Service also depends to a very large degree on the opportunities available to individual officers to develop management expertise and to broaden their career experiences. Later in my statement, I will be spelling out in detail the new Senior Executive Service career development initiatives which the Government has agreed in the areas of inter-agency mobility, individual external development and executive search. In adopting these initiatives, the Government has taken account of the concerns and issues raised by the Committee's report. It has also taken account of the advice of the Public Service Commission, based on that organisation's research into and experience with the management and development concerns of the Senior Executive Service.

I should also mention that the issues and concerns surrounding productivity improvement in the public sector have been canvassed extensively in the discussion paper which has been prepared for me by a Committee of Heads of Australian Public Service agencies, and which is now publicly available. This discussion paper is an important contribution to ongoing consultations which will form a basis for Government decisions on how productivity and agency bargaining might be applied in the Australian Public Service. I commend it to your attention.

Having clarified my approach to productivity bargaining and the Senior Executive Service, I will now proceed to the main issue of the report which, as I indicated above, is the development of the Service as a senior management structure.

The seven years since the Senior Executive Service was set up by this Government in September 1984 have seen very significant changes in the management and administration of the Australian Public Service, and a study of the development of the Senior Executive Service is very timely. Let me begin by briefly reviewing the origins of the Senior Executive Service and the main features of the Government's administrative reforms.
The Origins and Philosophy of the Senior Executive Service

The Senior Executive Service developed out of the proposals of the December 1983 Government White Paper "Reforming the Australian Public Service." Briefly, these recommendations called for the establishment of a unified, cohesive senior staffing group with general leadership and management skills which could effectively be assessed and flexibly deployed in accordance with the requirements and priorities of the Service. Positions were to be open to outside competition.

An essential element in this concept was the centralised management and development of senior leadership. The former Second Division was managed more or less discretely by individual Departments and agencies. Under the new arrangements, the then Public Service Board was given responsibility for approving selection, redeployment and retirement of Senior Executive Service officers. It was also to take a greater role in managing their training and development.
The New Administrative Environment

Since 1984 the Government has instituted a number of administrative and organisational reforms to meet the changing economic and managerial environment in which the Australian Public Service operates. The main effect of these reforms has been the devolution of many managerial and operational responsibilities from central authorities to individual Departments and agencies. The reforms of the Australian Public Service announced by the Prime Minister on 25 September 1986 gave greater responsibility to chief executive officers in individual departments and agencies for the management of their human resources. The major changes to the structure of Commonwealth administration announced by the Prime Minister on 14 July 1987 were aimed at reducing the number of Commonwealth departments to achieve administrative efficiencies and savings, better policy co-ordination and improved budget processes. These changes incorporated the recommendations of the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit for the abolition of the Public Service Board and the creation of the much smaller Public Service Commission responsible for the policy aspects of human resource management.

In a separate development, the application in 1989 of the Structural Efficiency Principle has resulted in the replacement of the six specific levels of the Senior Executive Service with three broad bands within which Secretaries may determine the salaries attaching to individual positions to reflect their relative job weight. The overall effect of all these changes has been the establishment of a much more devolved and flexible senior structure in the Australian Public Service.

The period since 1984 has also seen the implementation by this Government of important management reforms designed to improve the effectiveness of the delivery of Government programs and Services. The Financial Management Improvement Program, which introduced Program Management and Budgeting, now enables managers systematically to link resources and programs to overall objectives and to measure their effectiveness and efficiency against these goals.

Finally, the Structural Efficiency Principle negotiations in 1989-90 also saw agreement on performance pay. Like performance appraisal, performance based pay is intended to complement the thrust of the other changes in Commonwealth administration over recent years. It would require managers to develop and negotiate performance agreements consistent with program objectives and key results. This will reinforce corporate planning and program management and budgeting. The link established between pay and performance would also enhance personal accountability. Performance based pay would also provide devolved wages flexibility consistent with the existing flexibility held by Secretaries to determine Senior Executive Service salaries within bands which I referred to above.
The People Element

I think it important to recognise and acknowledge that these significant administrative changes have placed considerable pressure on the Australian Public Service in general and on the Senior Executive Service in particular. People have had to adapt rapidly to change, and to take on new and increased responsibilities. I record here that the Government recognises the excellent contribution which the Senior Executive Service has made in difficult and changing circumstances. But while the intensity and complexity of work at Senior Executive Service level has increased, and while officers have shown a high level of dedication and professionalism, their personal development may have suffered.

The Government has supported reform packages such as the Financial Management Improvement Program which have given greater value for money, but it has also become more than ever aware that money management is only part of the equation. The Government is now looking at the development of a human resource management framework which, through providing Departments and agencies with a systematic approach to better training, development and personnel management, will enable our people resource to reach its full potential.

The release of this report has been a valuable and welcome stimulus in focusing attention on human resource management issues in the Senior Executive Service, and its conclusions and recommendations have been studied with care. I would like to take the opportunity at this point to emphasise the importance which the Government attaches both to the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and to reports of this nature which provide both the Government and the Australian community with a broader perspective on the state of Australian public administration.
The Main Themes of the Report

The report has reaffirmed the vision of the Senior Executive Service adopted by this Government in 1984. It believes that this vision remains a valid model for the senior management of the Australian Public Service. Its main concern, however, is that the model has been in practice eroded by the management changes of the 1980s, and that the practical initiatives identified in 1984 as essential to its realisation, particularly in the areas of career development, staff mobility and personnel management, have never been fully implemented. It envisages a greater role for the Public Service Commission both in reviving and pursuing the 1984 initiatives and in assisting individual departments and agencies in their management of the Senior Executive Service.

The report's specific recommendations for "fine tuning" the Senior Executive Service are grouped into three broad categories. The first group is aimed at improving the accountability of Departmental secretaries for personnel management of the Service. The second group of recommendations centres on developing the scope for common services provision in the personnel management area, and the third set aims at encouraging leadership and entrepreneurship in personnel policy development and implementation.
The Government's Response

Mr President, the Government agrees that the original vision of the Senior Executive Service as a unified leadership group for the Australian Public Service remains relevant. The particular characteristics and responsibilities of public administration at the federal level require senior management which shares a common administrative culture, which has similar generalist skills and competencies, which shares training and development experience, and which can be deployed across the Australian Public Service in response to changing Government priorities. The Government of course also recognises that the particular tasks and responsibilities of some agencies require the services of high level professional and specialist officers. The category of SES (Specialist) has been created to ensure an adequate career path for these officers. It is important to remember, however, that the SES (Specialist) category is a component of the broader Senior Executive Service, and its members need to share in the overarching administrative and management culture.

The Government also believes that the elements of central management of the Senior Executive Service established in 1984--selection, redeployment, retirement, career management--need to be retained if this model is to be preserved. However, to implement effective and practical strategies and programs for the maintenance and development of a Senior Executive Service, it is important to be sensitive to and take account of the realities of the devolved management and administrative structure of the Australian Public Service today. This structure is not a managerialist fad. The Government believes that it is essential to the effective present and future administration of Australia.

The 1983 White Paper, which established the concept of the centralised management of the Senior Executive Service, emphasised that this responsibility "should be used sensitively, both with respect to the interests of the individuals concerned and to the primary management role of Department heads." These considerations are even more important in the l990s, when the responsibilities of Departmental managers are much greater, and I have kept them carefully in mind in my examination of the individual recommendations of the report. In seeking leave to table the Government's response to these recommendations, I would emphasise that while it is happy to agree to many of them, it has had to look very carefully at those which would require a significantly greater degree of central control.
Career Management

A main element of the 1984 reforms was the requirement for a greater degree of management leadership in the career development of Senior Executive Service officers. In reviewing the progress of the reforms, the report emphasises the need for more proactive career management strategies for the Senior Executive Service, and notes that "The plans for greater central involvement in the career development of officers have mostly not been implemented or been abandoned" (para 3.36). Interestingly, the results of the 1989 Jans/Frazer-Jans survey of Senior Executive Service career perceptions, which have been published in the Public Service Commission Senior Executive Staffing Unit Occasional Paper number 10, Careers and Culture in the SES, make a similar point. While the Senior Executive Service officers who responded to the survey indicated a high degree of morale and job satisfaction, there was also a perception that career management and career development were neglected by management.

Effective career management is important not only for individual development, but is central to the maintenance of a unified, professional and flexible Senior Executive Service. In a devolved management environment, the development and dissemination of career management strategies, opportunities and programs which have demonstrable mutual advantages for management and individuals is probably one of the most effective means of encouraging Senior Executive Service officers to think of themselves as members of a unique professional group. While I have reservations about some of the specific proposals put forward in the report for the mobility, placement and training of Senior Executive Service officers, they have stimulated the Government to think carefully about career management.
The Public Service Commission

Some of the recommendations for strengthening the role and function of the Public Service Commission focus on the more effective monitoring of personnel management in the Australian Public Service (para 10.16). Some of these proposals can be implemented without difficulty, although it needs to be borne in mind that gathering statistics about, say, redundancies by agency (rec 9) may tell us more about the external pressures those agencies face than about their management failings. I am less convinced by the proposals (recs 7, 8) for a significantly more interventionist role by the Public Service Commission in Senior Executive Service selection and deployment. These are no longer consistent with the devolved management culture of the Australian Public Service today.

I welcome the proposal that the Commission "take a leading role in personnel management in the Australian Public Service and, in particular, develop strategies to deal with the issues of concern identified in the PSC publication APS 2000" (rec 36). Before the report's release, the Public Service Commission had been restructured to enable it to give greater attention to the provision of human resource management guidance and advice to Departments and agencies. This has involved the creation of a new First Assistant Commissioner position to head a Human Resource Policy Division and the establishment of an SES Career Management Branch within the Management Selection and Development Division. The Commission's work will be focusing in particular on the development of the human resource management framework. It is also reviewing the development needs of Senior Executive Service officers in the light of recent evaluations it has undertaken, and is making changes to its development programs to ensure their continuing relevance and quality. I have asked the Commission, as part of its human resource development work, to give particular attention to the development and provision of principles, guidelines and advice to managers of senior human resources to enable them to identify and assist with career planning and development strategies and opportunities for Senior Executive Service officers. I am also aware of the potential importance of effective performance appraisal as a means of identifying human resource development and career planning options, and I endorse the continuing role of the Public Service Commission in the development and dissemination of effective performance appraisal techniques. At the same time, I would emphasise that effective career management is more than simply a matter of the provision of opportunities. It is important that Senior Executive Service officers themselves give time and attention to their own development.

In endorsing the Public Service Commission's role in supporting care management the Government is, of course, aware of the excellent work already under way in several departments, particularly in the area of intra-agency and inter-regional mobility. I have asked the Commission to ensure that its work in career management is compatible with and takes account of these agency initiatives.
Mobility

Inter-agency mobility was a central element in the development of a management cadre as envisaged by the 1984 reforms. I agree with the report's conclusion (recs 1 and 2) that central to a discussion of mobility in any Senior Executive Service model is a data base which gives current levels and trends. The Public Service Commission SES data base established after the 1984 reforms already has most of the necessary information, and a review and upgrading aimed at facilitating, among other things, the better manipulation of this data is already under way.

The report also recommends that the Public Service Commission "reinstitute a program of temporary assignments of SES officers along the lines trialled in 1986" (rec 6). I agree that effective inter-agency mobility is a central element of Senior Executive Service career management. It broadens the skills and outlook of individual officers and facilitates the flexible deployment of Senior Executive Service resources. The relatively young average age of the Senior Executive Service today will inevitably restrict job turnover, and thus lessen opportunities for inter-agency movement through promotion. Improved lateral mobility will become increasingly important in the maintenance of job variety and experience. I have therefore asked the Public Service Commissioner to implement a new mobility program for Senior Executive Service officers. I have asked him to look carefully at the reasons for the failure of the earlier scheme as set out in the evidence to the Committee, and to ensure that the new program has proper selection processes and takes full account of overall service needs, the developmental requirements of participants and their long term career interests.

In considering the issue of more effective mobility, I have been aware that the report has made a number of valuable observations about the different cultures and experiences of the central and regional offices of the Australian Public Service, and has articulated the concerns of officers in the regions that their management problems and experiences are not fully appreciated at the centre and that promotion and development opportunities are fewer.

I would tend to agree with the report that the problem of inter-regional mobility may not be amenable to any complete solution, since it is to a large degree the product of the structure of Commonwealth administration and the different managerial and operational priorities in the regions. I am aware, however, that some Departments, such as the Department of Social Security, have adopted innovative regional structures which provide greater opportunities for Senior Executive Service regional experience. It remains an issue which needs to be confronted in the development of effective career management strategies, and I have asked the Public Service Commission to bear it in mind in implementing its mobility program.

The willingness of Senior Executive Service officers to move from region to region is closely related to conditions of service which ensure that they will not be financially disadvantaged. In response to the recommendations of the report, I have asked the Department of Industrial Relations, in consultation with the Public Service Commission, to undertake a review of relocation assistance and other conditions of service which affect inter-regional mobility.
Recruitment and Selection

A major initiative recommended by the report is the use of "team recruiting" to the Senior Executive Service. This arose from the suggestion (para 6.58) that "it might be possible to recruit for Senior Executive Service positions in an agency twice or three times a year rather than as each vacancy arises" so as to improve the efficiencies of the recruiting process but also to tap broad community skills and to make the composition of the Senior Executive Service more representative of society as a whole.

The bulk advertising and filling of large numbers of positions may attract broader fields and may facilitate the matching of the individual skills and experience of applicants with the varying requirements of particular jobs. Many agencies do advertise in bulk when setting up new organisations or undertaking new functions. However it is clearly an impractical option for operating agencies who need to fill vacancies as they arise to maintain their effectiveness.

On the other hand, the report canvasses the advantages of executive search techniques, and recommends (rec 19) the establishment of an experimental unit. There is an emerging interest in improving processes to supplement selection fields, for identifying officers for development opportunities and for finding jobs for displaced officers.

A modest Senior Executive Service executive search capability utilising the current data base, which might include people outside the Australian Public Service who have expressed an interest in being considered for senior executive service positions, and which would respond to requests by Departments and agencies, is an option worthy of further consideration. I have asked the Public Service Commission to develop this capability. I would emphasise that this system will be compatible with the principles of open competition and merit selection, and take account of privacy concerns.
Training and Development

The main new initiative in the area of training and career development suggested by the report centres on the requirement for increased access by Senior Executive Service officers to post graduate courses in public administration and public policy, possibly through a staff college. While I agree that formal post graduate study is one option for professional development, I think that the report's focus on it is a little narrow. The Government takes the view that there needs to be a range of development options available to Senior Executive Service officers, which are of high quality and relevant to dealing with contemporary issues. These options include the many management training courses now being developed and provided by tertiary institutions and other providers as well as the programs of the Public Service Commission which are continually being reviewed and upgraded.

One promising new Public Service Commission initiative is the Senior Executive Leadership Program (SELP) which first ran in September 1990, and which is aimed at meeting the development needs of Division Heads. Feedback from the first three courses has been most encouraging. However, I would emphasise once again that the development of a suitable range of options for management training is only one element in addressing this issue. The Human Resource Development Survey conducted by the Commission for 1989-90 revealed that the service-wide training rate for Senior Executive Service officers was only 3.59 days per person, which I regard as being somewhat on the low side. As with career management, effective training is dependent to a large degree on individual officers and their supervisors planning workloads to take advantage of career development opportunities, and the development by the Public Service Commission of career management guidelines should help here. In considering new directions in senior management training, I am also mindful that there is extensive and relevant management and administrative experience within the Senior Executive Service itself, and I would like to see this resource further developed and utilised.

With the need to broaden the range of training options in mind, I have asked the Public Service Commission to implement an external development scheme for individual SES officers. This will encompass a broad range of development opportunities which might include visits to or placements with academic institutions, short development courses at post graduate management schools or assignments to develop and conduct seminars on "case studies" of difficult policy, administrative or management issues.
Conclusion

Mr President, the issue of the development of an appropriate senior management model for the Australian Public Service in a changing world is a difficult and complex one. In its report, the Committee has raised a number of important issues and has made a number of interesting suggestions for reform. Some of these the Government has had no difficulty in accepting. Others, while not perhaps as practical in a changing managerial environment, have given us much to think about and have stimulated investigation of new avenues for the more effective administration of the Senior Executive Service. I will ensure that the new initiatives which I have announced in this statement are implemented as soon as possible.
RESPONSE TO SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS
Recommendation 1--Enhancement of PSC SES data base to provide mobility statistics
Recommendation 1 proposed:

That the Public Service Commissioner arrange for the existing database on the educational qualification of SES officers to be expanded to record basic information on work experience and that the expanded database be structured so as to allow easy access to aggregate data on staff mobility.
This recommendation is agreed. The PSC SES database already contains much of this information, and is being upgraded to enhance access to and manipulation of the data.
Recommendation 2--Introduction of procedures for monitoring and publishing mobility trends
Recommendation 2 proposed:
That the Public Service Commissioner establish procedures for routine updating of the database and for publication in his Annual Report of aggregate data on mobility trends drawn from the database.

This recommendation is agreed. The SES data base is constantly updated as a result of selection and placement action. As part of the data base enhancement program the PSC is developing strategies to enable agencies more effectively to advise it of internal movements. The PSC will publish data in its annual report on inter-agency mobility, but believes that it would be more appropriate for figures on intra-agency mobility to be included in the reports of individual agencies, and will propose that this be incorporated into the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports.
Recommendation 3--data base coverage of "feeder groups
Recommendation 3 proposed:
That arrangements be made for the coverage of the database to be extended to the feeder groups for the SES by the end of 1991.

This recommendation is agreed on the understanding that for the purpose of this recommendation the feeder group is to be defined as those non-SES officers who have demonstrated through the selection process their aptitude for the SES; details of these officers are currently maintained in the data base. It is not practical or realistic to maintain this data on all members of the Senior Officer group and its equivalents.
Recommendation 4--review of Interchange
Recommendation 4 proposed:
That the Public Service Commissioner review the operation of the interchange scheme by departments and publish the results of the review in his next Annual Report.

This recommendation is noted. However, given the current devolved nature of the scheme, it is more practicable for departments and agencies to review their experiences in their own Annual Reports. The revised Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports include a requirement to report on the Interchange Scheme.
Recommendation 5--PSC to facilitate Interchange activities
Recommendation 5 proposed:

In the event that the review shows a significant decline in activity under this scheme since responsibility for it was devolved to departments, the Committee recommends that the Public Service Commissioner become involved in the program to the extent necessary to ensure that activity returns to at least the former level.
This recommendation is agreed. The Public Service Commissioner will write to departments and agencies encouraging its development and maintenance.
Recommendation 6--re-institution of a TAP mobility program
Recommendation 6 proposed:

That the Public Service Commissioner reinstitute a program of temporary assignments of SES officers along the lines trialled in 1986. The program should be kept sufficiently small as to be manageable by the Commissioner's office. The Commissioner should consider beginning the program with projects under his own control in the area of personnel policy, including projects which might arise out of the recommendations in this report.

This recommendation is noted. The PSC will implement an inter-agency mobility program, taking into account current levels of mobility. The PSC is concerned to avoid the problems of the TAP by ensuring that suitable participants are properly selected, that their development needs are taken into account and that they are properly placed or reintegrated on completion.
Recommendation 7--nomination of mobility candidates for vacancies
Recommendation 7 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner use his power to nominate additional officers for consideration for particular vacancies where he considers that such action would meet the mobility objectives of the SES.

This recommendation is noted. However, before resorting to the Commissioner's formal powers, the Government would prefer in today's devolved environment to encourage Departments and agencies to approach the Commissioner to seek advice on suitable officers to supplement fields. The development of an executive search capability will assist this process.
Recommendation 8--PSC review of "spills"
Recommendation 8 proposes:

That each future decision by a department secretary to "spill" SES positions in any part of his or her department should be reviewed by the Public Service Commissioner with the outcome of the review to be published in the Commissioner's Annual Report.

This recommendation is noted. The PSC will ask agencies to include information on "spills" in Annual Reports, noting that there is already a general requirement in the revised Guidelines for Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports for departments to provide information about staffing including the requirement to provide a summary of significant developments in relation to staff management issues.

Any further PSC involvement in senior staffing arrangements within departments and agencies would not be appropriate in the current devolved management climate. The PSC already monitors merit and equity concerns through its involvement in approving recommendations for appointment or promotion, and redeployment and retirement action, which may result from "spills".
Recommendation 9--publication of statistics on redundancy
Recommendation 9 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner provide in his Annual Report statistics on all redeployment and redundancy action detailed to agency level and showing comparative performance of agencies over time.

This recommendation is agreed in respect of those displaced officers who cannot be placed within their own Departments or agencies. The PSC would, however, wish to make it suitably clear in the promulgation of these figures that redundancies occur as a result of a variety of factors, many of them outside the control of individual departments and agencies.
Recommendation 10--that agencies meet all costs of redundancies
Recommendation 10 proposes:
That the Public Service Commissioner charge agencies for the full cost of all redundancy and retrenchment action undertaken by his office.
This recommendation is noted. Agencies already meet the costs of benefits and advisory and counselling services to displaced officers. It would not be practicable to charge other costs to agencies.
Recommendation 11--outplacement counselling as a right
Recommendation 11 proposes:

That all displaced staff subject to redundancy action be entitled to counselling and related services as of right. Access to such services should be through the Public Service Commissioner with the full costs being charged to the agencies from which officers have been displaced.

This recommendation is agreed. The nature and extent of the counselling would be dependent on the particular circumstances of the officer involved. The full costs of counselling services are currently, and will continue to be, met by the agencies from which the officers have been displaced. The PSC has, however, no objection to departments and agencies arranging their own counselling for their officers provided that the officers themselves are agreeable and that the level and range of counselling is the same as that organised by the PSC.
Recommendation 12--increased specialist positions
Recommendation 12 proposes:

That the Department of Finance review the feasibility of allowing increased numbers of SES (Specialist) positions in agencies or parts of agencies that are competing for similar skills as private sector professional officers.

This recommendation is noted. Published SES (Specialist) guidelines already provide that "positions of SES (Specialist) should be established only where requirements for high level expertise in a particular field clearly justify a dedicated position for this purpose, having regard to labour market factors and the capacity of the APS to recruit and retain specialists in that field".
Recommendation 13--PSC block advertising
Recommendation 13 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner arrange for a simple, weekly advertisement in appropriate newspapers, listing all SES vacancies advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette during the week in question and providing contact information.

This recommendation is not agreed. This method was tested for some years, but departments wished to run their own advertising and recruiting campaigns. Block advertising would duplicate the efforts of individual departments and agencies at considerable cost with little advantage.
Recommendations 14 and 15--reduction of deadlines for SES recommendations
Recommendations 14 and 15 propose:

That, in the case of SES vacancies advertised in the press, the deadline for submission of recommendations for promotion or appointment to the Public Service Commissioner be reduced immediately from six to three months.
That the Public Service Commissioner investigate the feasibility of similarly reducing the deadlines for submission of recommendations on all other vacancies.

Recommendations 14 and 15 are not agreed. While the PSC will continue to encourage agencies to complete SES selections in a timely manner, it does not believe that three months is a realistic period for the completion of an effective and equitable selection. Agencies failing to meet the deadline would under current arrangements be required to readvertise, and this would ultimately increase both the cost and the time of the selection process. SES staffing decisions are of vital importance, their consequential effects are long lasting, and an adequate time needs to be taken in considering the judgements involved.
Recommendation 16--PSC guidelines for vacancy inquiries
Recommendation 16 proposes:
That the Public Service Commissioner develop and issue guidelines for procedures to be followed by departments in dealing with inquiries generated by press advertisements for SES vacancies.
This recommendation is agreed. The PSC will prepare a kit for agencies which covers the job advertising and customer information process.
Recommendation 17--revision of SES selection reports
Recommendation 17 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner be alert to the risks involved in permitting revision of the reports of SES selection advisory committees and that recommendations for appointments or promotions to the SES continue to be rejected in any case where the Commissioner is not satisfied fully of the integrity of the selection process.

This recommendation is noted. The Commissioner seeks and will continue to seek further information and advice from agencies where, on the basis of the material available to it, he is not fully satisfied with any aspect of a selection process. Any subsequent action must always be dependent on the information which is forthcoming in response to such a request.
Recommendation 18--publication of recruitment statistics
Recommendation 18 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner compile at least the following information on SES recruitment action and publish it in his Annual Report: for each agency, the number of SES vacancies by state; the average number of applicants by gender, state, and whether employed in the APS; the average time taken between advertising and filling of positions; and the number of successful applicants by gender, state and whether employed in the APS.
This recommendation is not agreed. The overall value of the provision of this information is not justified by the resources which would be needed to obtain it.
Recommendation 19--Executive search capability
Recommendation 19 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner establish a small, experimental executive search unit, staffed at SES level, to test the effectiveness of executive search techniques in filling SES positions. To the extent that the unit seeks candidates from outside the APS, it should be permitted to work through private executive search firms but should also seek to develop its own pool of persons inside and outside the APS who might wish to be considered for employment in the SES. Particular attention should be given in this regard to possible candidates currently employed in the non-profit and voluntary sector. If the unit operates successfully during a trial period, payment by departments for its services could be considered. The Commissioner should consider the establishment of the unit as a possible project under a revived Temporary Assignment Pool as recommended in paragraph 4.39.

This recommendation is noted. The Government is interested in executive search techniques for the more effective recruitment, selection and placement of SES officers. The Public Service Commission will establish a modest capability utilising data currently held by the Commission, which might include people from outside the APS who have expressed an interest on being considered for SES positions, which will respond on request to Departments and agencies seeking assistance in the recruitment and deployment of SES officers, and which will safeguard privacy.
Recommendations 20 and 21--promotion of team recruiting
Recommendations 20 and 21 propose:
That the Public Service Commissioner actively promote the concept of team recruitment for SES vacancies.

That in cases where the team recruitment approach is adopted, particular efforts be made to ensure that intakes are balanced as to skills and other characteristics and that these efforts be described in the selection documentation available to the Public Service Commissioner.

These recommendations are not agreed. While team recruiting may have advantages in matching the particular skills and experience of individuals to the overall corporate requirements of an organisation, to actively promote it would override and ignore the important practical requirements of Departments to fill vacancies as they arise.
Recommendation 22--funding for regional positions
Recommendation 22 proposes:

That each new SES position created outside the ACT during the next three years be counted as only half a position for the purpose of Department of Finance SES profile controls and that departments be permitted to fund fifty percent of the salary costs of those positions from outside the SES salary budget, subject to a reasonable cap on the total increase in positions.

This recommendation is not agreed. Ample opportunity exists for sympathetic consideration to be given to departmental proposals for augmentation of SES resourcing outside the ACT, without resort to special devices of the sort recommended. The status and quality of work offered by regional SES positions will, moreover, not be enhanced or even maintained by debasing their value through an artificial increase in numbers.
Recommendations 23 and 24--term appointments to regional positions
Recommendations 23 and 24 propose:

That departments which fill their regional SES positions on a term basis be prepared to negotiate with applicants on the initial term of appointment and provide for the possibility of renewal of appointments up to a total term of, say, six years. Allowance should also be made for longer terms in special circumstances.

That the Public Service Commissioner actively promote arrangements to facilitate transfers between departments of officers at SES and feeder group level within each region as a partial alternative to the present practice of filling many regional SES positions by ACT-based staff on term appointment.

These recommendations are noted. The Government has asked the Public Service Commission to keep them prominently in mind in its consideration of the central/regional aspects of mobility schemes. It is, however, important to remember that many if not most Departments already staff senior regional positions on rotation, and that any schemes to increase regional/central mobility will be dependent upon the work priorities, needs and structures of individual departments and agencies.
Recommendation 25--Commonwealth/State Exchanges
Recommendation 25 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner actively promote arrangements for an increase in opportunities for staff exchanges between the APS and State public services under the interchange scheme as well as under staff development schemes operated by his office, including the Executive Development and Senior Women in Management schemes.

This recommendation is agreed. As part of its action to encourage agencies to develop and maintain interchange, the PSC will emphasise movement between State and Commonwealth authorities. As part of its ongoing consultation and interaction with State Public Services, the PSC circulates information on its training courses and makes places available to State Public Services. EDS and SWIM participants may undertake rotations in State organisations, but opportunities may be limited by personal factors affecting inter-State movement (see response to recommendation 26).
Recommendation 26--development programs and the regions
Recommendation 26 proposes that:

. all appointees to ACT positions in the Graduate Administrative Assistant or equivalent programs be required to undertake at least one posting to a regional office during their training program and all appointees to similar regional positions be required to undertake at least one posting to the ACT;

. all participants in the Executive Development Scheme and the Senior Women in Management Programs who are employed in the ACT be required to undertake at least one posting in a regional office unless they have substantial previous regional experience and all regional participants be required to undertake at least one posting in the ACT unless they have previous substantial work experience in the APS in Canberra;

. all departments should examine the feasibility of promoting staff interchange between their central and regional offices through short-term postings to undertake particular projects or simply for development purposes.

This recommendation is noted. The Public Service Commission will continue to encourage regional movement as an element of developmental schemes, but it is impractical as a mandatory requirement, and of little relevance to those agencies or programs that have no or little regional presence. Officers with family commitments have found it difficult to move outside Canberra when interstate postings were introduced in these schemes in the past, with the net result that the number of participants, including female participants, in some schemes declined.

The Public Service Commission will write to Departments encouraging them to promote central/regional staff exchanges. The Commission will also be asked to keep regional mobility prominently in mind in its examination of assignment/rotation options, and encourage departments to recruit graduate administrative assistants directly to their regional offices.
Recommendation 27--relocation assistance
Recommendation 27 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner examine relocation assistance and other conditions of service that would assist in promoting inter-regional mobility and the recruitment of high quality people from outside the Service.

This recommendation is agreed. These conditions were reviewed and enhanced for the SES at the time of its formation, but an examination by the Department of Industrial Relations, in consultation with the Public Service Commission, is now timely and will be undertaken.
Recommendation 28--reporting on progress
Recommendation 28 proposes:
That the Commissioner report on the result of his examination in his 1990-91 Annual Report.

This recommendation is noted. As indicated in the response to recommendation 27, the Department of Industrial Relations will manage the review. Progress will be reported on in the Department of Industrial Relations' 1991/92 Annual Report.
Recommendation 29--reporting on performance pay
Recommendation 29 proposes:
That the Department of Finance publish details annually of performance payments made in each agency.

This recommendation is not agreed. The Government is strongly in favour of preserving confidentiality of individual performance payments, and neither agency nor DOF reports will allow payments to any individual to be identified, identifiable or capable of simple estimation.

The revised Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports include a requirement to report consolidated statistics on performance payments where they have sufficient eligible staff (three or more) to preserve individual confidentiality. The Department of Finance will report annually on Service-wide statistics aggregated across agencies, by SES Band and by the percentage of maximum permissible pay received. Consideration is being given to the addition of the aggregated statistics by gender.
Recommendations 30 and 31--verification and evaluation of performance based pay
Recommendations 30 and 31 propose:
That the Government response to this report specify verifiable targets for the costs and benefits of the introduction of performance based pay in the APS.
That the evaluation of appraisal schemes proposed by the Public Service Commissioner for 1992 be expanded to include an evaluation of the operation of performance based pay.

These recommendations are noted. It is agreed that agencies, when introducing performance-based pay, should identify the goals and objectives to be achieved. These goals and objectives will then be used and\or developed to evaluate the effectiveness over time of each scheme.
However, any such assessments will be largely qualitative. Therefore the setting of verifiable targets and attempting any detailed cost benefit analysis is not considered practicable.
Recommendation 32--outside participation in evaluation
Recommendation 32 proposes:
That the evaluation team include at least one representative from outside the APS and that its report be published in the Annual Report of the Public Service Commissioner for 1991-92.

This recommendation is noted. Such issues will be addressed leading up to the evaluation of performance-based pay schemes in 1992, with a view to results being published in or before the 1992/93 Annual reports.
Recommendation 33--evaluation of EDS
Recommendation 33 proposes:
That the next full evaluation of the EDS program include an assessment of the success of participants in the program in subsequently achieving promotion to the SES.

This recommendation is noted. The PSC has recently reviewed all its development programs, and the EDS 90 program has undergone evaluation by management consultants Ernst and Young. The evaluation confirmed the value and high standard of the program and the quality of the participants but indicated that it was not seen by agencies as a program aimed primarily at officers with SES potential within the relatively short term. The objectives of the program have been revised to remove the link to SES promotion but to continue to meet the need expressed by agencies for a high quality "experiential" mobility program for individuals of potential who need some broadening in skills, attitudes and experience.
Recommendation 34--professional development in the SES core criteria
Recommendation 34 proposes:
That the extent of an individual's recent efforts to develop and maintain professional skills should be included in the core criteria for SES appraisals and selection.

This recommendation is agreed. The recently revised core skills now include criteria that look at an individual's recent efforts to develop and maintain professional skills. The individual's ability to seek additional training or experience to overcome deficiencies forms part of the Self Knowledge/Management criteria. The PSC approach to performance appraisal includes assessment against the SES core skills for the purposes of providing opportunities for professional development and training.
Recommendation 35--post graduate training for the SES
Recommendation 35 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner explore methods of improving access by SES officers to postgraduate courses in public administration, public policy or other areas of likely benefit to the APS. The Commissioner should give attention to the possibility of making special arrangements for such training with existing educational institutions. Consideration should be given to funding increased levels of assistance for postgraduate study from reduction in funding for short courses by the Public Service Commission and by departments and agencies.

The recommendation is noted. The Government takes the view that there should be an enhanced range of personal development opportunities available to SES officers, and the Public Service Commission will take account of the accessibility and relevance of various post graduate opportunities as part of its external development of management training initiative. However, it should be borne in mind that the allocation of resources to post graduate study in specific areas of professional development is more one for individual agencies to consider in terms of their particular staff development strategies.
Recommendation 36--PSC role in personnel management
Recommendation 36 proposes:

That the Public Service Commissioner take a leading role in personnel management in the APS and, in particular, develop strategies to deal with the issues of concern identified in the Public Service Commission publication APS 2000.

This recommendation is agreed. The Commission has already been restructured on this basis, with the creation of a First Assistant Commissioner position to head a Human Resource Policy Division and the establishment of an SES Career Management Branch within the Management Selection and Development Division. The Commission's work will be focusing in particular on the development of a Human Resource Management framework for the APS and on the development of guidelines and procedures to help Departments and SES officers to take advantage of career management strategies and programs.
Recommendation 37--activities of MAB
Recommendation 37 proposes:
