That the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet provide more details of the activities of the Public Service Management Advisory Board in its future annual reports. Minimum reporting should include a listing of all matters considered by the MAB, of all decisions or recommendations made by it and of the outcome of any recommendations. The first full report on the operations of the MAB should provide such information for the period since its establishment.

This recommendation is noted. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, in its Annual Report, will continue to provide an account of the activities of the Management Advisory Board including a history of the key issues considered by the Board. Those issues will generally be the subject of a published paper--or otherwise will be the subject of an appropriately detailed report by the executive agency with primary responsibility for the issue concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Senator Cook) for tabling the Government response to the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the development of the Senior Executive Service. Most of the Committee's work on the report was undertaken in the last Parliament when the Committee's membership was different. In fact, I am the only current member of the Committee to have been involved in the evidence gathering or in much of the Committee's internal debate on the draft report. However, the other members of the Committee will join with me in welcoming a serious and well-argued Government response to a major committee report.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not to say that I welcome all aspects of the response. As the response notes, the specific recommendations in the Committee's report were largely directed to finetuning rather than fundamental change. However, as a package, the Committee's recommendations were consistent with an underlying philosophy that is quite sceptical of many of the claims of the so-called managerialists. By contrast, the Government response accepts those claims uncritically.

The pattern of acceptance and rejection of particular recommendations reflects a sizeable philosophical gap in the Committee's position. That is still accepted by the Government. The differences are most clear in relation to performance based pay. Despite the Committee's criticism of the performance pay proposal in two reports, the Government remains committed to the introduction of performance based pay for the SES, and equally committed to not setting verifiable targets for the change and to not evaluating formally its costs and benefits.

We are told on the one hand that the effectiveness of senior public servants in their policy advising and managerial tasks can be assessed with sufficient precision and objectivity to allow fine judgments to be made between individuals. But, on the other hand, judgments about whether performance pay as a system will actually pay for itself `will be largely qualitative' and the `setting of verifiable targets and attempting any detailed cost benefit analysis is not considered practicable'. There seems to me to be a fundamental inconsistency here.

The whole approach is inconsistent with the logic of the recent Public Service managerial reforms in general. The excuses for the foreshadowed decision not to evaluate performance pay would not be accepted in relation to any other expenditure proposal. I find it disturbing that senior executive pay alone is to be free from the intense pressure for reporting on every other aspect of public sector performance and from the requirement to justify in detail every item of government spending.

I note and endorse the comments in the response on the case for returning to members of the SES a share of the rewards of productivity gains. However, I believe that the Committee's two reports on this matter showed conclusively that performance pay is not an appropriate way of doing this. There are strong theoretical grounds for believing that the system will not work in the way intended because of a total absence of successful models elsewhere in the world, despite many experiments.

Performance pay is only one example that illustrates philosophical problems that many of us have with recent changes in the way in which the public sector operates and sees itself. The Committee's report noted in passing the risk that a particular ideological viewpoint might become dominant within the Public Service. The problem is not politicisation in the party political sense, but rather the pervasiveness of a particular view of the world--a view which is narrow and potentially destructive of much that we value in our Public Service.

The stress throughout the Government's response on the devolution of management responsibilities ignores this risk. Devolution of senior personnel decisions in the way still proposed by the Government is likely to strengthen the self-selection process that has entrenched particular viewpoints in the senior ranks of the Public Service. A crucial purpose of centralised career planning mechanisms, as the Committee's report argued, is to preserve diversity in the SES as well as to ensure that selections are made on merit. Central guidance and leadership are not the same as central control.

The Committee was told early in its inquiry that the form of SES adopted in the Australian Public Service was less managerial than that adopted elsewhere, especially in New South Wales and New Zealand. Subsequent developments have shown that to be no bad thing. The risks faced by governments that fall naively for the extreme managerial rhetoric are becoming clearer by the day throughout this country and New Zealand. The New South Wales case is particularly instructive in this regard.

But although I am disappointed at the extent to which the response reaffirms what I think to be a dubious doctrine, I am happy with the responses to many particular recommendations. The Government is proposing to produce better data on mobility trends in the higher Public Service, to experiment with executive search techniques and to encourage senior staff interchanges with the State public services and the private sector. More information will be available on staff redundancies and redundant officers will have an entitlement to counselling of the type that, until now, has usually been supplied on an ad hoc basis. The Public Service Commissioner will act to improve the quality of follow-up action to vacancies advertised in the media. Relocation conditions are to be reviewed. Officers' own efforts to develop and maintain their professional skills are to be included in the core selection criteria for SES positions.

More important than this finetuning, the Government has accepted that the Public Service Commissioner should take a leading role in Public Service personnel management. The Commissioner's office has been restructured with that in mind.

Many of the Committee's more wide ranging comments have been noted in the response in a way that seems positive. The effectiveness of action in the areas of concern flagged by the Committee will depend on the quality of the administrative structure that supports central personnel management. The response gives rise to some hope in that regard.

I read the response as indicating that the more extreme effects on personnel management of the 1987 machinery of government changes have been recognised. I hope that the next few years will see a greater recognition of the unique and important role of the public sector and of the importance of leadership in public sector management. At least the general tone of this response has not discouraged me in that hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Very briefly, though not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration at the time, and with deference to the honourable senator and his colleagues, I do have some reservations about the outcome of that Committee's report, particularly in the area of not encouraging incentives. The whole competitive system is based on incentives and providing carrots to encourage better performance.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take this opportunity to acknowledge that the Department has found the report to be a very useful document. I know that a number of the recommendations will ensure that there is an improved level in the quality of training. I thank the Minister Assisting the Minister for Public Service Matters, Senator Cook, for his enthusiasm in the manner in which he has received the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I shall be brief, as was Senator Watson, because I have yet to exercise my membership of this Committee. Nevertheless, I have read with interest this Government response. I find the recommendations to be most interesting and I hope to see some results brought about from them.

SPEECH.PARA: I found some extra information after I asked some of the staff of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Senator Cook) to explain part of the response to me. I was interested in some of the information supplied that relates to the section on recruitment and selection. While I was pleased to learn that 25 per cent of the women who apply for senior executive positions are now successful, it is still a disappointment that only 12 per cent of managerial positions are held by women.

Within the same section I found that, although attempts are made to recruit from outside the Public Service, only 10 per cent of those who apply from outside the Public Service are successful. This suggests to me that it is still difficult for those who have had some sort of career break--be it involved with raising children or, as I said to somebody earlier, to become an olympic athlete or to pursue a career in private enterprise and become a millionaire--to return from that break and re-enter or become eligible for a position in the Senior Executive Service. Obviously it seems to be a difficult path to follow. I am pleased that, from this response, we can see that the Department is taking seriously the challenge of recruitment based on merit and merit only and not necessarily being a career public servant, which has led to the sorts of criticisms which probably generated this service anyway.

I was not pleased to see in the response under the heading `Training and Development' that the service-wide training rate for Senior Executive Service officers was only 3.59 days per person. I agree with the statement in the response that that figure is somewhat on the low side. It is disappointing. If that is a description of the present situation, we hope that lateral thinking is applied to the methods by which that amount of time can be increased. We are told in the response that:
. . . effective training is dependent to a large degree on individual officers and their supervisors planning workloads to take advantage of career development opportunities. . .

I think that is a fancy way of saying that many people for whom training might be suitable consider themselves too busy to take advantage of it. That is probably a common fault of managers, whether they be in private enterprise or the Public Service. Planning to take opportunities for learning or updating skills is required. People suffer too readily from the `I am indispensable' syndrome.

The response gives a hint about what would solve this problem, the possibility being to broaden the range of training options. It is important to take note of the possibility that there could be options for external studies which do not have to be attended at a specific time and do not necessarily require absence from work during the day. I trust that this is the sort of option which this response was alluding to.

I was pleased to see the suggestion in recommendation 18 which, on the surface, proposed that the Public Service Commissioner compile at least a certain amount of information about the recruitment statistics. I will not quote the recommendation, because it is not important to do so. I am pleased that the principle was not followed that, because it seemed to be useful information, it would be compiled at all costs. The response said that the overall value of the provision of this information would not be justified by the resources needed to obtain it. While that is very interesting, it is obvious that that sort of information could be compiled from other sources and that to provide it as a matter of course is one of those good ideas which to me seem to be a waste of both human and financial resources.

Similarly, recommendation 13 suggests that block advertising be arranged for all of the SES vacancies to be placed in regular insertions in appropriate newspapers. It might sound efficient, but we can easily see that such a method would be wasteful; it has been tried before. Now that we have flexibility and individual accountability of departments, the departments are running their own advertising as and when it is necessary and in the areas in which it is most appropriate. This method is obviously less wasteful.

Although on the surface some of the recommendations seem to be reasonable, I am pleased to see that the response indicated that potentially wasteful practices would not be followed. I look forward to seeing the implementation of these recommendations and support the response that we have been given today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have just seen the Government's response, so I am not in a position to comment on it greatly. I notice that throughout the response terms are used which raise a number of questions in my mind. These particularly relate to human resource management frameworks. On pages 4 and 5, the response states that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is now looking at the development of a human resource management framework which, through providing Departments and agencies with a systematic approach to better training, development and personnel management, will enable our people resource to reach its full potential.

What does that mean? I invite the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Senator Cook) to look in on some of the Senior Executive Service courses that are being undertaken. He would see what the thrust of those courses is: whether they are simply a vehicle for the economic rationalists to promote their view of the SES, to promote their consideration of what ought to be the objectives for a particular department; and whether, inherent in that approach, is the evil of the suggestion that if people do not perform or happen to fit into the hole made for them we should get rid of them.

There is a real problem in the SES at the moment. Many honourable senators will have seen the responses given by a majority of SES officers who were interviewed about their economic views. It would be disconcerting, to say the least, if such a philosophy--an economic rationalist philosophy, which does not have a human face--were to be the norm which was pursued and promoted in SES courses.

I suggest that the Minister also look at whether sufficient attention is paid in these courses to the question of accountability or whether that just means money. One can count money, but that is not what accountability should mean in the SES. In terms of today's rediscovery of ethics in public administration, I support Dr John Uhr's view that:
The real heart of administrative ethics is the ethics of public accountability. . . accountability to the "authorised scrutineers", i.e. the elected representatives of the people.

Public servants carry a heavier responsibility, especially when they work on policy issues. They are accountable to the Minister, but they also carry a broader accountability to the Parliament and the Australian people. This is particularly the case where the policies have long term or irrevocable repercussions--
As many of the policies inevitably do. Dr Uhr goes on to say:
The Public Servants are clearly not employed to pursue their own narrow interests, in a policy sense or in any other way, at the expense of the human rights and interest of the people they serve.

I mention that because it is important for the Minister and, indeed, the Government to keep an ear to the ground to make sure that they know what is being promoted in the training and development programs for our Senior Executive Service.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows--
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS ENTITLED `UNAUTHORISED PROCUREMENT AND DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION'

On 5 June 1991 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs tabled a report entitled `Unauthorised Procurement and Disclosure of Information'. This report stemmed from a reference to inquire into `whether there are effective legal and administrative deterrents to prevent the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information, as discussed on pages 14 to 16 of the Privacy Commissioner's 1989-90 Annual Report.'

In its report, the Committee noted the concerns which had been expressed by the Privacy Commissioner, and stated that it sought to amplify those concerns. The Committee made the following recommendation:
That the government provide as a matter of urgency its response to the action it has taken, is taking or intends to take in relation to the matters raised in this report, in particular:
. sanctions against public servants who disclose personal information held by a government agency without authorisation;
. the criminal law as it applies to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency; and
. the coverage of the Privacy Act in relation to the Privacy Commissioner's power
(a) to investigate the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of personal information held by a government agency; and
(b) to award damages to those who have been harmed by the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency.
As indicated by this response, the government accepts this recommendation, and agrees to provide an outline of its activities and intentions in relation to these matters.
Sanctions against Public Servants

With respect to the first particular matter identified by the Committee, it appears that the Privacy Commissioner was essentially concerned about the range of disciplinary measures available against public servants who had been found guilty of disclosing--without authorisation--personal information held by a government agency. The Commissioner had stated that officers found guilty of misconduct may be fined up to $500, but then the next penalty is dismissal. He suggested that a wider range of penalty options would help to avoid the impression that corrupt disclosure cases are not dealt with strongly by tribunals.

It is worth noting from the outset that the range of penalties which are available in these circumstances is not simply confined to a $500 fine or dismissal of the officer. Subsection 62(6) of the Public Service Act presently provides for seven different classes of disciplinary measures, including admonishing the officer, deducting up to $500 from the officer's salary, reducing the salary payable to the officer, transferring the officer, dismissing the officer, or a combination of these sanctions. Prior to the commencement of section 51 of the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act in 1987, the maximum financial penalty which could be imposed under subsection 62(6) was $40. In addition, there are a number of criminal penalties which may be applicable under various secrecy provisions in Commonwealth legislation.

In terms of the action taken by the Government in relation to this matter, the Public Service Commission is presently conducting a review of the disciplinary provisions which are contained in the Public Service Act. In the course of this review, the Commission has circulated a discussion paper to Commonwealth agencies and has received a number of submissions in response to that paper. The Commission is now in the process of developing a strategy for the reform of the disciplinary provisions, and is preparing to consult further with the bodies which would be affected by such reforms. One of the issues being considered in that review is the adequacy of the disciplinary sanctions available for misconduct under the Public Service Act.
The Criminal Law

The second matter identified by the Committee concerns the application of the criminal law to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information. The Privacy Commissioner told the Committee that such persons are not always "easily able to be effectively prosecuted". The Government recognises this concern and, as was acknowledged in the Commissioner's 1989-90 Annual Report, the Social Security Act was amended in 1989 in order to enable the more effective prosecution of persons who solicit the disclosure of information concerning a client without lawful authority. Since then, similar amendments have been made to other legislative provisions governing the disclosure of personal information, including those contained in the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act.

As to the Government's intentions for future amendments to the criminal law, the question of applying criminal sanctions generally to the unauthorised procurement of personal information held by government agencies will be further considered following the receipt of a report of the Gibbs Committee on the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law on provisions of the Crimes Act which deal with disclosure of official information. As noted by the Senate Committee, the Attorney-General's Department is also undertaking a review of secrecy provisions in Commonwealth legislation.
The Privacy Act

The final particular matter identified by the Committee concerns the coverage of the Privacy Act. In both of his annual reports, the Commissioner had recommended that the Government consider amending this Act so as to empower him to investigate the entire circumstances in which unauthorised disclosures of personal information occur, and to impose liability in damages upon those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information. As recommended, the government has considered the desirability of such amendments. At this stage, however, such amendments are not regarded as being appropriate, for a number of reasons.

The main reason is that such amendments would not be consistent with the essential role of the Privacy Commissioner, which is to oversee the collection, handling, use and disclosure of personal information by Commonwealth agencies. That role does not extend to cover the actions of individual officers taken beyond the course of their official duties, except in so far as such actions may be attributed to the failure of agencies to comply with the storage and security standards set out in Information Privacy Principle 4 of the Privacy Act. This was recognised by the Commissioner in his evidence to the Committee, when he described the Act as "basically administrative law legislation designed to discipline the conduct of official administration. . . ".

Further, the current policy of the Privacy Act is that, where the Privacy Commissioner suspects that a tax file number offence against the Income Tax Assessment Act may have occurred, he must refer the matter to law enforcement agencies (s.49). There is no requirement for him to refer any matters concerning unauthorised procurement or disclosure of personal information to law enforcement agencies, although there is nothing in the Privacy Act that would prevent him doing so.

The Government considers that the unlawful disclosure of official information by individual officers is a matter which would be more properly dealt with by the appropriate law enforcement agencies or disciplinary bodies. Should the Commissioner become aware of such activities, he may advise the relevant agency under paragraph 27(1)(a) of the Privacy Act. In such circumstances, the Chief Executive Officer of the agency would have the authority to refer the matter for investigation by the relevant law enforcement agency.

Similarly, the extension of the Commissioner's powers to enable the award of damages against individuals, given his role with respect to the administrative practices of Commonwealth agencies in their handling of personal information, would create substantial problems. It is not supported. The awarding of damages for some activities which may under existing legislation be criminal offences would create problems of equity of treatment for alleged offenders as well as problems in determining whether a particular incident should be dealt with administratively by the Privacy Commissioner or instead, by the criminal justice system.
Apart from these policy considerations, there are constitutional limitations on the Commonwealth's ability to vest what may amount to judicial power in the office of Privacy Commissioner.
General

The Government remains sensitive to the concerns which the Committee has expressed in relation to the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of personal information, and is seeking to address those concerns in a sensible and consistent manner. On behalf of the Government I thank the Committee for its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to say something about the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information and the pertinent and quite brilliant speech that Senator Harradine has just given, which has provided a context in which to make my remarks. The report to which the reply is given looked at the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information and it arose from a motion moved in this place by Senator Patterson on 7 May 1991 which read:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report on or before 30 September 1991: The question of whether there are effective legal and administrative deterrents to prevent the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information, as discussed on pages 14 to 16 of the Privacy Commissioner's 1989-90 Annual Report.

That matter was considered by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, which showed concern for the unauthorised leaking of information, and the Government has replied. The reply comes from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), who is a man very much noted for his concern not only for privacy but also for the civil liberties of people generally.

Terrible disasters can happen and great unfairness can be done to people when information is wrongly leaked. There is a need for the public servants to be accountable, as Senator Harradine was saying, not only for financial affairs but also for other matters. I thought it most apt that this matter should come on in light of an article I read this week in the Sydney Morning Herald where a Mr Phillip Smiles, who is the Assistant Treasurer in New South Wales, had to face a leak about a matter with which he was concerned and which had been sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

The Sydney Morning Herald report concerned a person who, as I understand it from the report, had a most legitimate difference of opinion from that of the Australian Taxation Office, and which difference of opinion he intended to test in the usual way. However, it was leaked that the matter was being given to the Director of Public Prosecutions, without any notice or warning of what was to be done. Of course, the first that the person heard about it was when it appeared in the media.

Reputation is a thing that we all value very much. We might value our reputations in different groups in the community but, nevertheless, there would be very few people who do not value the reputation that they build up. To have that reputation hurt in the way in which Mr Smiles's reputation was hurt on this occasion through a leak is, in my view, very reprehensible.

We, in this place, have discussed the right to privacy over the years. I think that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as chairman of a committee that dealt with the proposed Australia Card, had much to say about the right to privacy. The sorts of statements that you have made since then indicate your attachment to that principle. It is a principle that I think lies very much at the heart of things and, indeed, imprisoned in the hearts of us all, no matter how cynical we might be at times, is the feeling that there ought to be a right to privacy. Fortunately, more and more of that feeling is becoming liberated and more and more people are expressing the need for that right to privacy. Unfortunately, that appetite, that feeling, for the need for the right to privacy is coming at a time when the build-up of information by more and more agencies is becoming a matter of considerable concern.

It is often said, particularly by the media, that there is a right to know. I am not quite sure what that means. Is there a right to know about everything that everybody does or should a right to know be confined to those matters which have a legitimate public interest about them? I think that the right to privacy is very much akin to the right to silence. That right to silence is something that has been treasured in our system for many generations. The right to silence is there to preserve the proposition that no person should be found to be guilty out of his or her own mouth. No one should be subject to imprisonment because of what he or she may be forced to say.

The right to privacy protects that reputation that, as I said before, we all treasure. It would be my proposition that nobody's reputation should be taken by their being forced, either physically or as is done through leaks, fraud or otherwise, to surrender that reputation or any part of it. It is in those circumstances that people very much want to preserve that right to privacy.

If the laws we make, as we do in this chamber, are circumvented, in the terms of this inquiry, by people who have access to information through their position within the Public Service, if they give up that information about others to the media or elsewhere, much harm can be done, as was the case in Mr Smiles's situation. There are many situations in which privacy should be preserved, whether in the confessional or in what we tell our doctors, our social workers or even those we associate with in this chamber. In my view any system which allows those sort of confidences to be betrayed should be very much circumscribed.

The leaking that goes on, the revelation as to what we do, is put out on the basis that if we have nothing to hide why should we mind what is said or what is revealed about us. The simple answer is, of course, that it may be one thing if those facts that we may want to keep private are interpreted by somebody who is all knowing and all powerful--the only person who fits that description is the Almighty--but it is another thing when those facts that we want to keep private are revealed and are usually interpreted most wrongly, most unkindly and in a much biased fashion by people who take possession of them.

The difficulty with things leaked about people is that they are interpreted by those who publish them in a way that is all too often untrue, unfair and most harmful to people's reputations. Those who reveal facts, those who want to tell us all about other people, and those who want to take on board--only in the proper sense--the facts and revelations about others do so on a basis that is very suspect.

It is often said that truth is all; that everything should be done in the name of truth. I wish to quote from a High Court judgment in the case of Bunning v. Cross and in particular from the judgment of Mr Justice Stephen, who later became a most eminent Governor-General of this country, and Mr Justice Aickin, who unfortunately has since died. They quoted another case called Pearse v. Pearse. The judge in that case was Vice-Chancellor Knight Bruce, who had this to say:
The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of courts of justice;

I might add to the words of Vice-Chancellor Knight Bruce the media and bodies like ICAC, the NCA, parliamentary committees or royal commissions that investigate us all and the community in the name of truth. The judgment goes on:

. . . still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination . . . Truth, like all other things, may be loved unwisely--may be pursued too keenly--may cost too much.

I think we are in danger in this modern age, with the advent of all sorts of technology and the advent of all sorts of committees which investigate us and our neighbours, of our pursuit of truth beginning to cost too much.

As we go around pursuing those who we say do or act wrongly, there is a proposition that everybody is in need of the redemption that was proclaimed 2,000 years ago. It was right then and I think it is right now. In any decent society there is a give and a take, an expectation that we will be able to preserve our liberties, our reputation, and our right to face our friends and those with whom we associate without what can only be described as a sneaking, snide revelation being unfairly given to others so that it may be published.

May I finish by expressing my sympathy with Mr Smiles, who seems to be the latest victim of this sort of action. If, as it seems to appear from this article, it was leaked by the Australian Taxation Office--which is what Mr Smiles seems to think happened--we do have a problem. Therefore, the motion moved by Senator Patterson, the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and the reply of the Government are most timely. Senator Harradine talked about the economic rationalists in terms that were not altogether flattering. May I also talk about the `truth seekers' who would go to any length--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Including interviewing people's children.

—-I take the honourable senator's point but I will leave it to her to raise that matter in her speech. These `truth seekers' would go to any length to reveal matters which should not properly be revealed in a decent society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I regret somewhat that Senator Cooney did not address in detail the Government's response to the report entitled Unauthorised Procurement and Disclosure of Information made by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I would have appreciated the benefit of his advice much as I enjoyed the erudite rendition of matters that are of concern in the privacy area. The response is an extremely disappointing one.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters that were addressed by the Committee, and which the Committee requested the Government to address, included:
sanctions against public servants who disclose personal information . . .
the criminal law as it applies to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information . . .
the coverage of the Privacy Act in relation to the Privacy Commissioner's power
(a) to investigate the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of personal information held by a government agency--
and, incidentally, to refer directly to law enforcement agencies any transgressions that are discovered and, finally:
(b) to award damages to those who have been harmed by the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency.

I accept that there are constitutional difficulties on the last point. However, that is about the only valid excuse which the Government can offer for the total lack of action on the matters of concern that were raised by the Committee.

On the matter of sanctions against public servants, the Government does set out a more detailed gradation than witnesses made available to us. However, there is clearly further reform work to be carried out. We are told that the Public Service Commission is presently conducting a review of the disciplinary provisions which are contained in the Public Service Act. I would have appreciated receiving information on when that review was started and, perhaps more importantly, on when that review is expected to be completed so that some decisive action can be taken.

We then have the matter of criminal law and the application of that law to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information. We have heard from the Privacy Commissioner that persons who transgress these provisions are not easily able to be effectively prosecuted. The Government has taken some specific action in the Social Security Act, the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act. However, no attempt has been made so far to consider the application of the criminal law in general terms. Very clearly, the disclosure of private information potentially covers a very wide area and is not limited to those particular Acts.

We are told that the Government's intentions for future amendments to the criminal law will be considered further, following the receipt of a report of the Gibbs Committee on the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law on provisions of the Crimes Act which deals with disclosure of official information. Once again, the Government shirks its responsibility and shoves off to yet another inquiry any decision to take effective action. Once again I, and I am sure Senator Patterson, would like to know when that report will be available and when the Government actually intends to take action.

The next matter relates to the power of the Privacy Commission to investigate the entire circumstances of disclosure of private information. This is perhaps one of the most important matters on which, once again, the Government has decided not to take action. The specific matter that the Privacy Commissioner asked to have addressed is the circumstance where a person outside the government agency bribes a public servant to provide private information. Obviously, such a person, in many ways, is the real culprit, yet the Privacy Commissioner is prevented from following through and investigating fully that particular transaction.

In the same vein, we have the failure of the Government to address the question as to whether the Privacy Commissioner may, in individual instances of transgressions by public servants and, of course, by people outside the government agencies, refer them directly to law enforcement agencies. I believe that section 27(1)(a) of the Privacy Act does nothing of the sort. The section states that the Privacy Commissioner may:

investigate an act or practice of an agency that may breach an Information Privacy Principle and, where the Commissioner considers it is appropriate to do so, to endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of matters that give rise to the investigation.
These words do not, in my view, give the Privacy Commissioner the power or authority to refer the matter for investigation by the relevant law enforcement agency. These words do not read that way.

It is a matter of great regret that the Government has seen fit to duck the issue of adequate enforcement provisions in our privacy legislation. Heaven knows, as Senator Cooney has demonstrated, it is very necessary and not before time that the Government decided to take some action to remedy the obvious shortcomings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am moved to speak on the Government's non-response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That is all that I could call it--a non-response. First, I register my appreciation to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for the time and effort it put into investigating the issue that I put forward in the Senate, addressing the matters of concern and putting forward its report. I am not as grateful to the Government for the answer that it has given.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Spindler has outlined some of the concerns, and I will reiterate some. My concern was precipitated by a number of events where information about people, held by Government agencies, was being made available for a purpose other than that for which it was obtained. That is the issue that we are looking at--information that is held by an agency being given for a purpose other than that for which it was obtained.

One of the concerns that the Privacy Commissioner expressed was that there were not adequate financial penalties that could be levelled against a person or a public servant who gave out unauthorised information illegally. The response from the Government says that there is a range of penalties other than the $500 fine. It refers to subsection 62(6) of the Public Service Act, which provides for seven different classes of measures, including admonishing the officer, deducting up to $500 from the officer's salary, reducing the salary repayable to the officer, transferring the officer, dismissing the officer or a combination of these sanctions.

In a case where the information has been embarrassing or damaging to the person, it seems to me a rather puny punishment. That is what the Privacy Commissioner said--that there were not penalties which were sufficiently severe to deter public servants from disclosing information for their own financial gain. It is a very serious misdemeanour or crime. The disclosure of information has the potential of, in fact, damaging someone for life, yet the deterrent is not very great. But we get no answer, cold comfort, for the Privacy Commissioner in the reply that we got from the Government.

The reply says that there have been changes to, for example, the Social Security Act, the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act to prevent the solicitation or the procurement of information by third parties. As the Privacy Commissioner has pointed out, those third parties cannot be investigated by him. In fact, some of the information which is held by government departments has enormous commercial value and there is pressure upon public servants by people who want to procure that information for insurance purposes, for the purpose of blackmailing or whatever else.

The amount of information that the Health Insurance Commission holds would be useful for a company wanting to know of, for example, all young men under 30 years of age who were taking a drug for hypertension. That has enormous potential for a company involved in actuarial projections and wanting to know whether someone is a risk. Perhaps someone has had an HIV test. There is a huge amount of information with commercial value. The Privacy Commissioner cannot investigate a person who bribes a public servant. He has asked for this power to be reviewed and the Government is saying no. I am sure that the Privacy Commissioner will be interested in the response to this report.

The report says that the Social Security Act, the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act have been amended, as I said. But there are other Federal agencies which have been implicated in the New South Wales ICAC investigations. They include the Immigration Department, Customs, the Australian Taxation Office, Telecom and Australia Post. There would seem to be an overriding need to amend the legislation which governs these agencies, as well. Senator Cooney referred to one instance recently where an agency--it may have been the Taxation Office--released damaging information. I do not think the Government can rest on its laurels by saying that it has amended the Social Security Act, the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act. It needs to redress these other Acts as well.

I would be very interested to know what is happening with respect to the Gibbs Committee on the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law and what it is doing in relation to breaches of the Crimes Act, which deal with the disclosure of official information. I think that many of my colleagues in the Senate would be very interested to see a copy of that report. In fact, I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) whether it would be possible for us to see the terms of reference of the Committee and be advised when it will be reporting.

The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has been undertaking a review for four years and still it drags on while technology increases and while the amount of information stored on Australians increases. I would have thought that the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs may have stimulated the Attorney-General's Department to at least get on with a report--if not a final report, an interim report--on what it has been doing.

Considering that the Government has rejected all of the Privacy Commissioner's recommendations in relation to strengthening his legislation to allow him to deal with the unauthorised procurement of Government information, it seems appropriate, if he had the opportunity under the Privacy Act, for him to furnish a report to the Parliament in response to the Government's response to the Committee.

I shall be interested to hear what the Privacy Commissioner has to say. I think that it would be appropriate for the Senate and for the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee to have an official response from the Privacy Commissioner to the Government's response. More and more I am convinced that the Privacy Commissioner needs to be independent of the Government. He needs to be appointed independently so that he is not gagged or restricted in what he says. There is more and more evidence to suggest that the way in which the Privacy Commissioner's role was set up needs to be reviewed, so that he can be appointed much more independently and therefore can protect our privacy.

I had the opportunity of meeting M. Foveaux in France in the middle of this year and I spoke to him about privacy issues. France has had a privacy commissioner for 15 years and he is appointed independently. An independent body is appointed from which the commissioner is elected. The commissioner is totally independent of the government and is able to comment freely without fear or favour. I believe that public interest is served much better because of that independence.

As I said earlier, it would seem that in Australia the Privacy Commissioner's role is to investigate any breaches of people's privacy that relate to information that they have provided to government agencies which has later been used for purposes other than that for which the information was originally supplied. It seems quite ludicrous that no breach of the Privacy Act occurs simply because the information is unlawfully disclosed by an officer of the agency when acting outside his or her normal duties.

The Privacy Commissioner in his annual reports has raised a number of issues that should be of great concern to all colleagues in this House and to members of the public. Some of us are concerned about privacy issues and we will pursue them. I believe that this will become a greater issue as technology changes and as the ability to store information in greater amounts is integrated in very different ways. This requires us to be eternally vigilant to ensure that it cannot be abused or misused. As Senator Cooney said, the ends should not justify the means in terms of the way in which information is gained. We shall need to address this issue into the 1990s and, indeed, into the next century. We want to ensure that socially we are on top of this matter in our ability to examine it. We must not leave a mess for the next generation. We do not want that generation to say, `If only they had been more aware at the time of the problems associated with information storage and retrieval'.

This response by the Government does not satisfy the Committee's concerns. I shall be interested to hear what the Privacy Commissioner has to say, and it is to be hoped that we shall have access to his comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia, during January and February 1991. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This is a report of the delegation's visit to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia and includes a report on our visit to East Timor. Unfortunately, there is not the time today to go at length into the various issues I want to raise on the report, but I wish to make some comments about the few days that we spent in East Timor. The delegation spent three days in East Timor from 7 to 9 February inclusive. Two days after our visit to East Timor, we also had the opportunity to visit Nusa Tenggara, which is commonly known as West Timor.
First, I wish to thank the Indonesian Government for its courtesy, for the arrangements it made and for the general itinerary that was organised in cooperation with our Government.

In respect of East Timor, I wish to draw the Senate's attention to some of the good points that I noted on my visit. For example, it was very clear that since 1975 there has been some significant improvement in a number of areas in East Timor. For example, there has been a significant increase in the number of medical personnel. In 1983-84 there were 63, and there are now 2,376. The number of high schools has increased from the figure of seven in 1975 to a figure of 33; the number of high school teachers has increased from 105 to 675. The number of high school students has increased from 1,713 to 11,828. The number of asphalted roads has increased from 20 kilometres in 1975 to 680 kilometres. Those are the sorts of statistics that we were presented with, and at face value there appears to have been a significant improvement in those areas, including the area of agricultural production.

However, there were a number of matters which I consider to be the bad side of the visit. In terms of the economy as a whole, East Timor is the most underdeveloped of the Indonesian provinces. There is little private sector investment at all, let alone any jobs in any industry outside agriculture. There have been disputes about land ownership due to the significant shifting of the population during the military actions of the Indonesians. There is a general fear that East Timorese are becoming second-class citizens in their own province.

The Indonesian Army presence is heavy, obvious and overbearing. It was with very great regret that I obtained the view that it is an army of occupation. This contrasts particularly with the situation in West Timor, where the military presence was negligible. If we are to accept the Indonesian Government's assertion--and I have to say that I do not--that it is not an army of occupation and is simply there on manoeuvres and normal duties, I simply pose the question: why is there such a heavy military presence in East Timor and not in West Timor?

Regarding human rights, I draw the attention of the Senate to a number of paragraphs in the report including our recommendations in paragraphs 3.10 and 3.12. I would like to quote very briefly from those sections of the report. Paragraph 3.10 reads:
The Delegation is aware of a number of international reports outlining human rights abuses in East Timor. A majority of the Delegation believed that some or all of these can be sustained.
Paragraph 3.12 states:

It became evident that Timorese, even if they could, did not feel secure enough to talk freely. Many members of the Delegation were struck with the sense of sullenness of the local people. On the few occasions some members took the opportunity to walk in the streets of Dili, when passing, people rarely engaged in eye contact and it was only when contact was initiated with a smile or hello did they respond themselves, often with open and warm smiles.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is part of Asian culture--eye contact is just not on!

—-It is not part of their culture. If Senator Watson had a gun shoved in his face, he would have his head down as well. That is absolute nonsense. I also draw the attention of the Senate to recommendation 3.19 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Delegation, in noting the widespread Indonesian Army presence throughout East Timor and the effect its presence has on the local people, considers the East Timorese People would be encouraged to become more active in their own affairs if there were fewer soldiers and the number of combat to civil construction soldiers reduced. The Delegation was concerned that the heavy concentration of combat troops could lead to the inference that they were necessary for the central government to maintain control.
It is with regret that I draw the attention of the Senate to those features of the military's presence.

We indicate in our recommendations that we believe there should be very careful handling of the economic development of East Timor; that there should be an encouragement of private sector investment; that the air link with Darwin should be re-established; that, hopefully, some sort of special economic agreement will be developed in order to foster economic development in East Timor; and that, hopefully, the benefits of the Timor Gap Treaty that was signed at the end of our trip will accrue to the people of East Timor. Also, there should be a significant increase in aid to the education centre.

I have already contrasted the situation in East Timor with the situation that existed in West Timor. In terms of the future, I draw the attention of the Senate to a minority report signed by three members of the delegation which appears on page 140 of the report. There are only two minority recommendations which were endorsed by me, Mr Garrie Gibson and Mr Allan Morris, members in the other place. The first reads:
That a conference, convened by the United Nations, consisting of all parties involved in the current dispute including the Governments of Portugal and Indonesia, be held as soon as possible.
The second minority recommendation, entitled `Australian Government', reads:
The Australian Government should directly pursue the recommendations as outlined in this report with the United Nations and the Indonesian Government.
I owe it to my two other colleagues to give a brief explanation as to why we presented a minority report on our visit to East Timor. It will be a brief outline of our reasons.

I believe that if we are to endorse such ventures as our military presence in the Middle East, as we did earlier this year, we need to be consistent in our approach to military aggression wherever it occurs. It is no good Indonesia claiming that East Timor is simply its own internal affair. Hundreds of years of history of a different culture and of ethnic, social and economic divergence deny Indonesia that claim. There are special and unique problems in East Timor that require special and unique solutions.

Other countries around the world have had, and continue to have, a solid working relationship with Indonesia despite strong differences on the issue of East Timor. I believe that Australia can have a solid relationship with Indonesia. However, if we are to be consistent in our foreign policy approach, the issue of East Timor and the various resolutions in the United Nations that have been passed on this issue need to be addressed. Australia needs to be at the forefront, as it has been in other areas, of ensuring that those United Nations requests are complied with.

I want to see a strong and effective working relationship between Australia and Indonesia. Certainly, Indonesia is a country that cannot be ignored. It is probably one of the most important countries for our future. It has a population of some 285 million. It had an economic growth rate of 8 per cent last year. Only last week, an Asian studies conference which I attended in Tasmania concentrated on Indonesia. After attending that conference and visiting Indonesia I believe that, clearly, much of our future lies with that country, so it is with regret that I make my remarks about the Indonesian presence in East Timor.

Finally, I would like to thank the other members of the delegation who accompanied me. It was my first delegation. I enjoyed their company greatly, and they were of great assistance to me on this trip. I also thank the secretary, John Dyer. I have already mentioned the Indonesian authorities, but I would also like to thank the officials in Singapore and Hong Kong who assisted us during the trip, particularly our Australian Embassy staff.

I would like to give considerable credit to the Governor of East Timor, Mario Carrascalao, and the military commander, Brigadier-General Warouw, with whom we spent quite some time. There is no doubt that these two individuals have made a very determined and conscientious effort to improve the situation in East Timor under their jurisdiction. I give them considerable credit for their openness and frankness in discussing with us the problems in East Timor. Obviously, we saw many other people in East Timor.

It is very important that the issue of East Timor is addressed and that the improvement in our relationship with Indonesia continues, despite this outstanding very serious problem. I hope that we can look forward to an improved relationship with Indonesia in the coming years. There are a number of other aspects of the report, such as the education office, our visit to the ship HMAS Success and other aspects of the delegation's trip to Hong Kong and Singapore that I will speak on another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It was my privilege to be a member of the parliamentary delegation to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia earlier this year. I am also privileged to be part of the majority which has tabled the report, the balance of the majority being the Hon. Leo McLeay, the Speaker of the House; the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, MP and Mr John Riggall, MP.

SPEECH.PARA: This was my first parliamentary delegation. It is appropriate that it was to our near Asian neighbours coming, as I do, from north Queensland. Where I live, I am much closer to the almost 200 million Indonesians than I am to the balance of my fellow Australians who live down in this part of the world. It is obviously a very important part of our world, and I was privileged to be part of that delegation. The people on the delegation were fine travelling companions and, generally speaking, we got on very well. I thank them for their courtesy and kindness as we went around.

I also pay tribute to the Australian Consulate-General in Hong Kong, the High Commission in Singapore and the Ambassador's office in Jakarta and Indonesia for facilitating our visits to those particular places. I also pay particular tribute to the governments, officers and officials of the three nations we visited for their very considerable assistance in facilitating our delegation.

Time is too short to comment at any length on any parts of the report. It is quite a lengthy report. I commend it to anyone who is interested in those particular affairs. The report goes into some detail on various recommendations--there are quite a number of recommendations--and there are also quite significant facts and reports that support those recommendations.

I briefly mention a few parts of the report and of our particular delegation. I was terribly impressed with Hong Kong as a vibrant, bustling city, one where the inhabitants are keen to work. They have a real initiative and incentive to work. They get out, and they have a sparkling, bustling economy that we in Australia could learn much from. I was terribly impressed with the way Hong Kong, without any natural resources, has progressed as much as it has. There is some concern about the 1997 reunification, or re-incorporation, with the People's Republic of China. My general impression was that people in political life were a little concerned about it, a little hesitant, but that the business community was generally looking forward to it. The business community was welcoming reunification and was certain to cope with it very well. As I say, the business community was looking forward to coping with it.

Another aspect of the Hong Kong trip that particularly struck me was the Vietnamese boat people. Hong Kong, a very small and not terribly wealthy nation, is making an enormous contribution to the Vietnamese boat people. It is not getting a lot of support from any of the major Western countries or any other countries at all, but it is doing a marvellous job itself in looking after the Vietnamese boat people at their first port of call. It is an enormous strain on the Hong Kong economy. In an economy where the inhabitants themselves are pushed for land and pushed for resources, Hong Kong has set aside quite a substantial part of land and resources to look after the people who are trying to escape.

I draw the Senate's attention to paragraph 1.17 of our report in which we urge the United States and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to reconsider their opposition in principle to involuntary repatriation. That is a matter we could talk about at length, but it is something I draw the Senate's attention to.

In Singapore, we were again privileged to meet with many government officials. We spoke with the Institute of South-East Asian Studies, a vibrant academic organisation, one that Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Liberal Party in Australia, has spent some time at. One cannot help be impressed by the vibrancy and the free economic thought of that particular study group and of its leader, Professor Sandhu.

It was interesting to see that, although we Australians at times think we are fairly good, the Singapore people shook their heads with dismay that a country as wealthy and with all the resources that Australia has did so little with them. The people made it very clear to us that if we are to succeed in Asia we have to be competitive in quality and prices but, more particularly, in reliability of delivery dates. There was quite a lot of talk about our unreliability and the trouble we have on our waterfront and in getting trade moving to those areas.

Because of the Gulf war, we were prevented from going to Thailand and Pakistan, which was originally part of our itinerary. But it did bring one benefit; that is, we were in Singapore when HMAS Success, one of the ships from the Australian Navy that had been in the war, was returning from the war zone for the first time. We were very fortunate to be able to meet up with the ship in Singapore and to go on board. We spent a very pleasant afternoon on board as guests of the ship and its captain. We had a very interesting time there.

Time does not permit me to recount at any length. But I was pleased to meet Oscar, who happened to be the ship's dummy but who is someone who I had been corresponding with. I had been requested through this Parliament to write to our sailors in the Middle East. I had been writing to this ship and had been getting a response from a person named Oscar. When I asked to see Oscar, and when we coincidentally and quite by accident ended up on the ship, there was some embarrassment, but eventually Oscar was brought out to meet me. It was the ship's dummy that was thrown overboard to practise lifesaving techniques. That was quite an interesting aspect of the tour. It is recounted in more detail in our report.

The Indonesian experience was enormously beneficial to me. I was particularly impressed with the sincerity and high regard of the Indonesian officials whom we spoke with. I was particularly impressed with its national creed of Pancasila by which the country operates. Pancasila is five principles which are very important. I mention briefly the five principles of Pancasila which all Indonesians are familiar with and are made to learn as young children. They are: firstly, belief in one god; secondly, a just and civilised humanity; thirdly, unity; fourthly, democracy; and, fifthly, social justice. The tenets of Pancasila are what guide the country and impressed me very greatly.

We were fortunate enough to have an audience with President Suharto, a very wise and worldly and very experienced world leader. As I say, we were particularly privileged to have an audience with him. The President mentioned that Indonesia loves peace and independence and it does not want to do anything to jeopardise the independence and sovereignty of other nations in its region. The President--I am fairly certain it was President Suharto--did also, very politely though, indicate that, whilst he did not want to interfere in anyone else's affairs, other nations should adopt the same sort of principle. I must say, particularly as it relates to some of the things that some of my colleagues spoke about in Indonesia, that I supported the principle and the gentle urging by President Suharto of us in that particular way.

I found Indonesia, what I saw of it, to be a vibrant, bustling country; an economy where people want to work, where there is incentive, where they want to get ahead. I feel that in the not too distant future Indonesia will be one of the major trading nations of Asia and, in fact, the world. It is working very, very hard to get to that category.

We were one of the first foreign delegations in recent times to enter into East Timor. There had been some prohibition on free access into there, but it had been lifted. We were fortunate to be one of the first groups there. When we went into East Timor there was, again, an abundance of Australian press. There was certainly no indication that it was an area under military rule or an area where there was censorship or inhibitions on freedom.

I do not particularly agree with all the recommendations in the report. Senator Sherry mentioned some; I also wish to refer briefly to some of the recommendations and make my own comments on them. One recommendation that I certainly agree with was that there should be more bilateral exchanges between Indonesian parliamentarians and Australian parliamentarians. I hope the Government will take up that recommendation and introduce a scheme whereby there is much closer and more regular contact between Australian parliamentarians and Indonesian parliamentarians.

I was particularly pleased to be able to raise the question of Garuda Airways coming into northern Australia. I am pleased to say that in recent times the Indonesian airline, Garuda, has announced plans to fly into Townsville and Cairns. The report talks about the armed forces and urges greater cooperation between the Indonesian armed forces and the Australian defence forces. I agree with that and ask the Government to pursue it further.

There are recommendations on aid, particularly in East Timor, and the water supply for Dili. I support those recommendations and urge the Government to consider them seriously. There is a series of recommendations on human rights in East Timor. There were some that I did not agree with. My impressions of East Timor were that it was a country that had had an internal problem since the Portuguese left the area many years ago. But by a lot of hard work and positive and committed action, the Government had increased the infrastructure, schooling, health services, water supply and roads.

There is a large military presence but I disagree that it is overbearing. At one of the outstations we visited I was approached by a number of the military people. I did not understand what the different uniforms meant but many of the people in uniform under the control of the Army were territorials. I spoke to a lawyer and a doctor who were in uniform and who were students from the Jakarta University; they were working to assist the people in these more remote areas of East Timor. One was doing medical work and I think the lawyer was doing farm work. They are part of the territorial forces which are there to benefit the East Timorese people.

Our report says that many members of the delegation were struck with a sense of sullenness on the part of the local people. There may have been many members of the delegation who gained that impression, but I was not one. I thought the people were very friendly. They were shy, but there are many indigenous peoples around the world who are shy in the presence of strangers. I did not take that to be sullenness.

There is a comment about the delegation visiting a local market, the delegation's visit not being pre-arranged and the sudden appearance in the market having the effect of stopping all activity with people nervously standing around. I do not agree with that aspect of the report. I walked through that village, through the markets. I bought some things. Again, the people were shy and hesitant but when one talked to them, when one got to know them and when one smiled at their children, they were no different from people anywhere. They were interested in the delegation, which in their eyes was obviously high powered. But I did not perceive that in the way that some of my colleagues did.

There were some comments in our report about the widespread Indonesian Army presence. I agree that as soon as the Indonesian Army can remove as many of its people in uniform as it can the local people will feel a little happier. But I did not think the presence was overbearing.

I emphasise that we spoke with Brigadier General Warouw, the military commander in Dili. We were all impressed with his sincerity, his understanding of human rights problems and his absolute commitment to deal with abuses that he was made aware of. Undoubtedly there are human rights abuses in East Timor, but there are human rights abuses right around the world. Even our nation is not free from human rights abuses.

At times I was concerned that as a delegation we were not seen as three-day experts; we had walked into what has been a very difficult situation in East Timor and did not want to become three-day experts and then presume to go out and give advice to the military commander and Governor Carrascalao, whom we were also privileged to meet.

The Governor was a well-educated, humane and compassionate man who comes from that part of the world and was doing an absolutely mighty job in East Timor in difficult circumstances. The whole delegation was impressed by his commitment to the people and by his wish to make their lives better. He was especially concerned about unemployment and the lack of employment opportunities. That is something we are all very concerned about.

My colleague Senator Sherry referred to the increases in health, welfare, roads and education facilities in East Timor since the arrival of the Indonesian Government. East Timor has received a disproportionately high per capita amount of money from the central government compared with other areas in Indonesia. This has all been part of a deliberate attempt to try to lift the lives of the people in that area.

The Governor explained the history of East Timor, where some years ago the Portuguese simply walked out and left the locals and different groups to themselves. Civil strife then occurred where people were killed and rival factions fought with each other. There was a real threat of a full-scale civil war and the Indonesian Government entered that vacuum. Whilst some people think that East Timor should be independent, it seems to me ridiculous to even suggest that; it is a small nation, it has no inherent wealth and it simply could not exist as an independent nation in the world.

We are a near neighbour of East Timor. One of the local villagers told us when we were in the mountains that from the top of the mountain one could see Darwin on a clear day. I think there was a bit of local rumour in that. Still, it is very close to us. I should like to see the Australian Government and the Australian nation put a special effort into increasing contacts with East Timor. There is already a lot of contact between parts of Indonesia and Darwin and Western Australia. I should like to see closer and more regular visits to East Timor from Australians so that we can try to get some industries going. I am not sure what could be done. Those sorts of things would be particularly beneficial.

Overall the visit was especially helpful and beneficial to me and all members of the delegation in getting a closer contact with all of those areas we visited. I again thank the governments of the other nations that we visited for their courtesy and congratulate all of them on their attempts to increase the welfare of their own peoples. I thank the Parliament for giving me the opportunity to participate in that delegation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This document contains the resolutions of the sixth meeting of the Australian Soil Conservation Council which was held at Nelson in New Zealand on 15 February 1991. Three items were on the agenda and there were three resolutions to these items.

SPEECH.PARA: The first item considered by the Council involved options for improving the coordination and integration of natural resource management policies and programs. The second item referred to the implications of sustainable agriculture in the decade of the Landcare program. The Council resolved that the decade plan should focus on the control of land degradation, but should also remain responsive to developments in the areas of sustainable development and sustainable agriculture. The last item considered by the Council at this meeting was a review of the progress of the Decade of Landcare plan. This is the most important section of the report as it provides information about the actual progress and action taken to date.

A body called Landcare Australia Ltd has been established. Its role is to raise public awareness of and encourage corporate support for Landcare activities. Landcare has increased the demand for soil conservation advisory and technical services and although the rural recession has reduced the scale of soil conservation work, it has not reduced the commitment of land holders to Landcare. However, resources available to soil conservation agencies remain limited, so it is necessary to give priority to servicing existing Landcare groups, rather than the establishment of new groups.

The review of the Decade of Landcare plan also notes that the plan will have to be flexible so that it can respond to changing needs and priorities. In order to do this, it is proposed that the plan will continue to be reviewed throughout the decade. The Australian Soil Conservation Council must be applauded for these resolutions, but I am concerned that the Council, the responsible Ministers and the Federal and State governments continue to pass motions in Australia and review plans but fail to take urgently needed action before it is too late.

Since the mid-1980s, Government experts have been warning that agricultural production in the Murray-Darling basin, for instance, was in peril unless hundreds of millions of dollars were spent to control the risk to the soil posed by the salinity problem. At risk then, and now, is the salad bowl of Australia--a one million square kilometre basin covering one-seventh of the land area of Australia. It is the most valuable one-seventh because it produces almost half of the nation's agricultural products. It supports half of Australia's sheep and a quarter of its cattle. Directly or indirectly, this area supports two million people.

In 1986, Dr Alastair Grieve of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture reported that this valuable area of Australia was dying. He said that a quarter of the region was already affected by salinity; trees and crops were dying in approximately 5 per cent of the region; and many farms were reaching only 50 per cent of their potential output because of salinity. He went on to warn that:
In another 20 years, the problem will have become very much worse and will be virtually beyond our control.

It is now five years since this warning was given and if there are only 15 years left before the problem of salinity is beyond us, then the time for talking is over. Now is indeed the time for urgent and immediate action.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
