SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Senate is considering the Australian National University annual report for 1990. It is a very comprehensive report of all the activities of the two parts of the university: the Faculties and the Institute of Advanced Studies. I will mention only those sections of the report which I feel the Senate should be concerned about.
Page 4 of the report refers to recurrent funding for the university as a whole. It states:

Since 1978, the purchasing power of recurrent funding has declined . . . expenditure on buildings and . . . salary increases . . . have increased to the extent where total staff numbers funded from recurrent grants have declined since 1977 by 19 per cent.

This reduction in the purchasing power of funding has serious implications for the academic integrity of the university which is trying to cope with a very large increase in the number of students and a declining number of staff.

Page 8 of the report refers to the very serious problem which faces the university as a result of the relative funding model. Changes in funding under this model will have their full impact in 1995, by which time the faculties will be teaching 500 more students with $2.1m less in funding than they have in 1990. Despite these difficulties, the faculties of the ANU have undergone a major restructuring, including the inauguration of a campus-wide graduate school with over 30 graduate school programs covering nearly all of the university's research and teaching fields. The graduate school is forming a bridge between the two parts of the ANU: the Faculties and the Institute of Advanced Studies.

Page 11 of the report refers to the review of the role and standing of the Institute of Advanced Studies conducted under the chairmanship of Sir Ninian Stephen. The Committee broadly endorsed the role of the institute and found that:

. . . in most respects the Institute of Advanced Studies has met outstandingly well its charter of engaging research and providing advanced training at the highest international standard and in areas of national importance to Australia.

The Committee recommended that the institute remain a constituent part of the ANU and that it continue to be funded by a block grant and be responsible for establishing its own priorities. I take this opportunity to inform the Senate that, since the publication of the ANU report for 1990, this recommendation by the Stephen Committee has been totally disregarded. The Federal Government is determined to involve the Australian Research Council in the review process and funding recommendations for the Institute of Advanced Studies.

In response, the institute has made very strong recommendations to Minister Baldwin that the involvement of the ARC will signal a further erosion of the independence of all Australian universities. The institute has argued that the ARC should not make recommendations on levels of funding for the institute, nor should the Government specify allocations to individual schools within the institute.

The Stephen Committee made a specific recommendation concerning the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It recommended that it should become a separate institution with its own governing body, wholly funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council and affiliated with the ANU for academic purposes. In the report which we are considering this evening, the ANU indicated that it disagreed with the proposal to excise the John Curtin School from the institute. The institute is opposed to any transfer of funding from the John Curtin School away from the education portfolio because it threatens the autonomy of the ANU by reducing its power to manage the entire university.

Such a move would make strategic planning involving the John Curtin School and other parts of the university more difficult to administer and would centralise the funding of medical research in Australia to an unacceptable degree. The threat of forced amalgamation with the University of Canberra continues to haunt the ANU. The latest development in that saga is a resolution by the ANU that it does not consider it appropriate to contemplate the Minister's proposal for a federated model of amalgamation. The Hawke Labor Government is destroying the academic integrity and autonomy of our universities. I urge the Senate to take careful note of all reports relating to higher education and to take every action to prevent this erosion of integrity occurring.
Sitting suspended from 6.31 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are discussing the Australian National University annual report for 1990, and Senator Tierney has spoken to the motion that the Senate take note of the document. I also wish to speak briefly to that document. Mr Deputy President, you might also wish to do so, being a distinguished member of the ANU Council, but are perhaps precluded from doing so because of your present position.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Tierney pointed out, the document refers to the funding arrangements for the university over recent years. He, too, referred to the pressure on staff--I think that was the phrase he used. While the document is totally comprehensive about the financial matters affecting the university and the implications for the students because of their numbers and the reduced number of staff, it does not, in a sense, deal with the personal impact that this has.

On this occasion I wish to pay tribute to those members of the staff of the Australian National University who over these recent years--which I regard as very difficult years for them--have remained totally dedicated and committed to their undertaking to teach students at the university. I believe that they have been placed under great pressure not only from the financial implications which are apparent from the document but also by reason of the fact that at the same time they have had to put up with the determination by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) almost to destroy the institution, it seemed to me, through his insistence upon amalgamation with what was the Canberra College of Advanced Education and is now the University of Canberra. This has gone on for some years.

Senator Tierney referred to the review conducted by Sir Ninian Stephen. I want to remind honourable senators of the subsequent document that was produced by Professor Chubb. It was said at the time that Professor Chubb was appointed that he was to look at the ways of implementing the review of Sir Ninian Stephen. But it seemed to me that the report that Professor Chubb finally produced bore no resemblance whatever to the recommendations of the Stephen report which preceded it. So the saga has gone on.

Although amalgamation no longer seems to be pressing, it seems to me even now that there is still a tax on the university, and that is destabilising for the students and the staff. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This document contains the report prepared by the Schools Council for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on the operation of resource agreements for both the government and non-government school sectors. However, because of the development of a process of annual national reporting on schools in Australia, the public sector area has really been subsumed in the operation of resource agreements in a separate way. The report that we are dealing with today focuses on the operation of resource agreements for the non-government sector.

The report is really just a letter from Ms Lindsay Connors, the Chairperson of the Schools Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. Ms Connors claims that her report on resource agreements for the non-government sector is based on data on outcomes received and analysed by the schools and curriculum division of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and its summaries of those outcomes provided for the Council. That is where any useful information in this report comes to an abrupt end.

This report is, sadly, all too typical of reports on education matters provided by or for this Government. It is very short--four pages in all--and totally devoid of any useful information. There is no information on the data of outcomes received and analysed by the Department, there are no details about the summaries provided to the Schools Council and there are no particulars about any of the resource agreements. Yet this document claims to be a report on the operation of resource agreements for the schools sector as required under the Employment, Education and Training Act.

The four relevant paragraphs in the report contain vague and generalised information which is virtually useless. The first of these paragraphs indicates that there are initiatives to achieve objectives under the agreement. The second paragraph merely states that there are programs and initiatives to achieve the objectives and there are methods to evaluate their effectiveness. Paragraph 3 proposes that further consideration be given to the development of a comprehensive and cooperative national system of monitoring and reporting on schools. One wonders what the Schools Council has been doing if it has not been doing this already. The final paragraph notes that the National Board is undertaking a study of cross-sectoral resource allocation which includes consideration of accountability and how this might best be linked to resource mechanisms.

Where is there any information about resource agreements in the non-government sector in this report? Where is the analytical or statistical information--or any information--about what is contained in the summaries of the outcomes? This report reveals two things, both of which I find very disturbing. Firstly, schools are providing information to DEET on resource allocation, but that information is not being processed to provide precise and detailed data for this Parliament. It appears that either DEET is not processing the information which it receives adequately or this is just another attempt by Minister Dawkins to conceal information in an excess of generalities which reveal nothing at all.

Secondly, there is the disturbing hint in this report that non-government schools are about to be subjected to the increasing administrative burden of providing even more information to the Government under the proposed national system of monitoring and reporting--more information from DEET which it will probably fail to process.

It is typical of the Hawke Labor Government to provide resources to educational institutions with the one hand, and then demand that the institutions waste their meagre resources on providing information to the Government which is never properly processed or passed on to users or to the public. This report is one of the worst examples of a waste of resources on totally inadequate information. I cannot recommend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am a member of the Advisory Council on Australian Archives, as a representative from this Senate. There are two or three matters in the report which I wish to specifically draw to the attention of honourable senators. On page 8 of that report there is a paragraph relating to electronic records. The purpose of retaining records is that in the future people will be able to have some understanding of their history and their heritage and the way things have developed in this country.

The number of records which are now being kept in electronic forms of one kind or another is a new development in the area of record keeping. We are faced with the dilemma of knowing how these records can be preserved. We may in fact keep a whole lot of floppy discs or such other things, but in many years to come how will we play them back if we do not preserve all the relevant hardware to do so? That is a very simplistic way of referring to what I am talking about.

The Australian Archives has reported to us that it has commenced a long term project to develop and implement guidelines for the management by Commonwealth agencies of the increasing volume of electronic records being generated by those agencies. There is the question of records and records which have been changed with updated information. If they are on paper, we would have the original copy and the subsequent copies. In some instances, they themselves would tell a story about how they developed and emerged.

The report of the Archives Council states that the longer term aspects of access and preservation in particular are major issues which need to be addressed. It may even mean that funds need to be made available to see that adequate research is able to be undertaken to see that we can keep records. There are splendid records of this country available now from many years gone by and they are of great interest. It would be a pity if we did not get right the current electronic use for storing records. I urge the Senate and the Government to take note of that as a very important issue for the future.

Related to this is the question of preservation and the use of permanent paper. So much paper that is used now is loosely referred to as `acid paper' which will deteriorate. Some records even now are deteriorating. In my own family photograph albums, I noticed recently that some photographs taken in 1973 have significantly deteriorated, whereas photographs discovered in my mother's house, when it was packed up a couple of years ago after she died, which were many years older than that--from the 1920s--were in very good condition.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As long as you don't have an ageing painting in the attic, like Dorian Gray.

—-No, I do not have an ageing painting in the attic, as far as I know. It might be ageing, but not in the attic. The question of acid paper and the impact on records is important. I really believe that these records are part of the national heritage. It is important that we leave our history to Australians who will be here long after we have gone. I urge the Archives to take these matters seriously, as they are doing, and I urge the Government to listen to the recommendations it hears from the Archives relating to materials and practices.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, as you will have heard often before, the Archives wants its own building in the Parliamentary Triangle. I totally support this. I hope the building will be there long before the centenary of Federation. I will be a bit shattered if it takes that long. We will have a place in the old Parliament House, but that does not replace what is needed for the display of the material which the Archives has. Referring to the centenary celebration, the Archives should play a very significant role in plans for that because of the material it has and is able to present. I hope the Government will increase its interest in setting up the necessary mechanisms to see that the centenary is celebrated as it should be and that the Archives will be a very important part of that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate--

(a) notes that the Government is considering the creation of a special committee of Ministers to speed major projects as a result of the disastrous situation Australia has reached in the development of mineral resource projects;

(b) condemns the Government for its ineptitude which has allowed so many mineral projects around Australia to be either totally stopped or delayed, and for eight years of lost opportunity on these projects; and
(c) calls on the Government to ensure that projects already cleared by mining and environmental authorities proceed immediately.

As part (a) of my motion indicates, this Government is considering the creation of a special committee to fast-track certain projects. I consider this to be a total admission that these projects have been slow-tracked all along. I will leave it up to the imagination of honourable senators whether they were slow-tracked or were allowed to be slow-tracked. I believe they have been sidetracked at a remote siding and forgotten about.

Australia has reached the bottom of the pit in economic terms. Even this Government, which is responsible for putting us in this position--as well as putting one million Australians out of work--is obviously starting to see some daylight. The time we spend on the bottom of that pit depends on how quickly we can get Australia's export earnings going again. Those increased export earnings will not come from the agricultural and manufacturing centres in the short term, let alone in the long term. In fact, the agricultural sector export income has halved in the past 12 months: it is down to a figure of $3.2 billion.

That leaves only one sector--the mining sector--to assist in our economic recovery. We would not have reached such depths in economic terms, even allowing for the recession that we had to have, had the mining sector not been so fettered since 1983 or frustrated at every attempt to get new projects off the ground. In some cases even extensions to existing projects were not given approval.

I am afraid that Australia has been living on the developments that were put into action in the 1960s and the 1970s without starting new ones to replace them. We now have to mortgage the next generation to be able to get ourselves out of the problems that we are in. The Government did this by selling out to the radical groups in the environmental sector and in the Aboriginal sector time and time again. This was most evident in the 1990 election when the Government bowed to every lobby group in existence to secure the very few votes to enable it to hang onto power. But what has it cost the average Australian for Mr Hawke's grab to remain in power? We will never be able to work it out.

That figure could be calculated by dividing the amount of revenue and capital investment that has been forgone by the population of Australia to obtain a per capita figure. We will never be able to calculate that figure. Not only have we forgone the revenue and capital investment of each program but we also have to look at a lot of the downstream advantages obtained from developing resources. The only tangible evidence that we have of the fettering of those industries is the Government's policy which has brought about one million unemployed Australians, the death of country and remote towns, discouraged people, record bankruptcies and idle machinery that could be producing export income.

The most outstanding fiasco was the precedent that was set at Coronation Hill which was used by other lobby groups around Australia. This Government allowed Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to spend $13m on exploration but then denied BHP the fruits of its labour to the detriment of the Jawoyn people and to the rest of Australia. At least at Coronation Hill the Jawoyn people have now elected a leader who is more interested in mining. Hopefully, we may see a reversal of the Hawke-Green sell out at the time.

As alluded to in my motion, at long last we now hear Senator Button and Mr Griffiths speaking of fast tracking some projects in an attempt to reduce unemployment. Or is it the case that these two Ministers and the whole Government are preparing their Green mates for the big letdown of promises that is about to come? Even this Government has seen fit to try to turn around the unemployment situation which has been created in the life of this Government.

I ask: where were those two Ministers when the coalition was calling for the opening up of these projects? I do not know where they were. To Senator Button's credit, a secret letter that he sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which finished up in the Sydney Morning Herald, shows that he has probably had some concern for quite some time but, unfortunately, he was not able to convince others in the Cabinet to do something about the problem.

The Government was able to carry on with this sort of sell out to every Green lobby group, black lobby group, come what may group in Australia while we could afford the luxury of doing so. The primary industries--the wheat and wool industries--and, to a certain extent, the manufacturing industries were supporting Australia. Unfortunately, the Government thought that would last forever and that it would be able to remain in power forever. We then had the downturn in the agricultural sector, with the wool industry reaching the worst position it has been in for about 30 years. On top of that, we have taken a hiding in the grain industry from the trade war between the United States and the European common market. We may see a slight turnaround in the wheat industry, but we will not see it in wool for five years.

The Government's luxury of tapping into every lobby group has now passed. So it is back to basics. The only basic principle we have in Australia is to start developing mineral resources and to get them producing. The Government stands condemned for sitting on its hands while project after project has been delayed. Let us look at Western Australia's forgone opportunities. There are at least 10 projects that could have been under way but have suffered significant delays.

The first is the rare earths project proposed by Rhone-Poulenc at Pinjarra which was delayed by difficulties in gaining EPA approval for the project. The project has been deferred indefinitely. The cost to the State, and to Australia, in lost investment was $150m; the revenue loss would be $100m per year. The silicon smelter development advanced by the Barrack Group, now SIMCOA, was delayed because of the location being changed several times for political reasons. The cost to the State was the delay in a $100m investment. The coal mine and related power station proposed by Canning Resources at Hill River--I remember that one very well--was initially delayed by sectional groups and the Government's indecision. It is now proposed that part of the resource be quarantined in a national park. Detailed exploration and feasibility studies cost the company $30m. The proposed investment was $1.5 billion, which is one-third of the amount that went into the gas project on the north-west shelf.

The Yakabindie nickel mine, proposed by Dominion Mining, is subject to continuing delay because of disputes over Aboriginal heritage matters within the project area. Feasibility studies to date have cost $10m. If the project does not proceed, capital investment of $350m as well as revenue of $250m per year will be lost to the State. The Marandoo iron ore development proposed by Hamersley Iron is subject to continued delays because of disputes over Aboriginal heritage matters. If the project does not proceed, a capital investment of $500m will be lost to the State and, of course, also to Australia. The Beenup mineral sands project undertaken by Mineral Deposits Ltd has been delayed because of lobbying by the environmental community over road and power supply routes. The project has now been deferred for 12 months with a cost to the State in deferred investment of $135m. I suggested that the road should link up with the nearest railway line.

In addition 900 applications for exploration licences--497 on private land, let alone public land; 173 on conservation estates and 235 on Aboriginal land or on land considered to be environmentally sensitive--are currently delayed. Some applications have been pending for five years. The total cost in lost capital investment amounts to $2.5 billion. The total annual revenue of these projects would probably be about $1 billion per year. And that is only in Western Australia.

The two Western Australian resources that stick out most in my mind are those at Marandoo and Yakabindie. I will expand on those two projects. I visited Marandoo only about two weeks ago in the company of a few of my colleagues. The idea at Marandoo is to produce 10 million tonnes of ore per annum by the year 1994. The mine is not a stand alone project. It is being developed to supplement the depleted iron ore deposits at Mount Tom Price. Mount Tom Price, which works in conjunction with the mine at Paraburdoo, is running down. We have had to have a secondary deposit to replace the grade of ore at Mount Tom Price so that in 1994, when the mine at Mount Tom Price runs down, it will be able to use the ore at Maran
doo for blending. Otherwise the whole concept will fold

It will cost $500m to get the project up and running, with $400m to be spent domestically. During the construction phase 4,000 jobs will be created which, incidentally, is 5 per cent of WA's current unemployment level. If we get 20 of those sort of projects going, we will wipe out the current unemployment in Western Australia.

It will also lead to further development of other deposits which go down to Mount Newman in the Pilbara area. Mount Tom Price is railed into Dampier; Mount Newman goes into Port Hedland; and Robe River goes to Wickham. That part of the mighty Pilbara forms a big triangle which is actually about the size of Victoria. Anyone who has not seen the Pilbara area, which has put so much into Australian pockets since 1966 or thereabouts, should go and visit it. So that honourable senators can see the layout of the Pilbara in Western Australia, I seek leave to have a locality map of the Pilbara iron ore industry incorporated in Hansard. I have spoken to the Minister about it.
Leave granted.
The map read as follows--
[THE MAP IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; PLEASE SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 1841]

TALK.START.PARA: —-The point about Marandoo is that the objections are not spiritual in an Aboriginal sense but archaeological. It is not like the Bula at Coronation Hill. This deposit, which is the subject of so much worry, lies in Hamersley National Park. It is actually part of the old Mount Bruce cattle station, which was abandoned in 1946 because it could not make a pound. At that time the station went back to the Lands Department and, for want of something better to do with it, the Department turned it into a national park. It had nothing to do with its beauty. The fact is that the Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia visited the area and asked the people of Hamersley Iron what was so great about this national park. He was told that the only thing great about it was the iron ore body they were standing on. I can tell the Senate that it is certainly not an area of great beauty.

SPEECH.PARA: That area was also cleared by a tribal elder by the name of Jerrywing whom I had the pleasure to meet. Jerrywing is now aged 92. The day we were there he was on site with three jeep loads of Aborigines who were having another look at the site and watching the archaeologists who were trying to find more sites. It is quite a funny story. Here were those 30-odd Aborigines all sitting around the jeeps and the only person working was the archaeologist who was climbing up and down a gorge. Jerrywing, this 92-year old, was actually helping a little. In 1977 the site was cleared as having nothing to do with the Aboriginal culture. Jerrywing said, `You can have them' and other colleagues were with me as witnesses to that.

Hamersley Iron employs 3,000 people in Western Australia. It has constructed three Pilbara towns--Tom Price, Paraburdoo and Port Dampier--and has also initiated the regional town of Karratha. All told about 22,000 people live in the area and rely on this project. It will take two years to build Marandoo. As I said before, 1994 is very important because it must be done on time or the whole concept dies.

I will give the Senate some brief details on the economic impact of Hamersley Iron, which is the company seeking permission to proceed with this project. I will outline what that crowd has done since the inception of this project. In 1990 alone, Hamersley has earned $1.2 billion in export income; paid $190m in taxes--Federal, State and local; paid $64m in royalties to the Western Australian Government; contributed $262m to CRA; directly employed over 3,000 people; indirectly employed a further 12,000; and exported 41 million tonnes of iron ore. I heard Senator Coulter say today that iron ore mines do not create very much employment. I wish that he and the other Democrats would go up there and take a look for themselves.

I just want to expand on the Yakabindie project at Wiluna, which is another opportunity going begging. Yakabindie is a nickel project that is proposed by Dominion Mining. It requires capital investment of $350m and annual revenue of $250m. It is the subject of continual Aboriginal heritage matters, even though it was cleared by three reports as way back as 1974.

The hold-up here is caused by two people. The first person is Robert Bropho, an Aborigine who lives in the city and who has never had any connection with that area. Even the local Aborigines have told him that he has had no connection with them. In fact, he was born in Queensland, whereas Yakabindie is 800 kilometres from Perth. That is the situation. The other person is a `white Aborigine' called Peter Muir, who calls himself an Aborigine, who lives in a two storey mansion in Leonora and has made a fortune in pegging and selling off mineral leases. But he then stirs up trouble to prevent mining companies from getting a fair return on their investment. That is the hold-up in Yakabindie, Mr Deputy President, and let no-one tell you anything different. That is the story of opportunities which have gone begging in WA. Later on my colleagues will no doubt speak about other projects and other mineral deposits around Australia.

The major problems in Western Australia are Aboriginal related problems. However, there are other factors outside of the Aboriginal heritage problems and the environmental green problems which tend to hold projects up. Briefly, these factors include Federal departments being slow; State departments being slow; even local government departments being slow to a certain extent, although I doubt that because local government usually gets to work on the projects much more quickly; and, of course, the Foreign Investment Review Board and other such bodies. Even the Premier of Western Australia, Dr Lawrence, said on 18 June last--and it is not very often that I quote her:

It was totally unacceptable to the Government that important new projects representing hundreds of millions of dollars and thousands of jobs were being delayed, sometimes by vexatious claims made on behalf of Aboriginal groups.

She did not say `by Aboriginal groups' but `on behalf of Aboriginal groups'. I normally do not read too many articles written by Labor members of either House but I did read Senator Walsh's Cassandra article in the Australian last week about where opportunities have been lost. I certainly thank him for being the only one on the Government side in either place who is game to tell his mates and his colleagues where Australia is selling out and going backwards because of that reason.

It is a fundamental principle that minerals belong to all Australians--that was built into legislation so far back it does not matter--and should be harvested for all Australians. The Australian Government is paying out some $2 billion a year to the Aboriginal people. It is time those people appreciated that and allowed industry to proceed and help pay some of the bill. There is no better way to help an Aborigine--for that matter, no better way to help anyone who is not employed--than to give that person a job. That is the way to go.

In a recent survey in Western Australia it was found that 90 per cent stood for the principle that no individual or group should have greater control over land use than other members of the community. In other words, the survey showed that those minerals are there for everyone. No-one should have greater control than anyone else. The Government has to stop sitting on its hands in this matter and get these projects going. If it is to jettison the radicals that it sopped to during the last election, the sooner the Minister does it the better. The future of Australia is greater than the whims of those self-righteous, self-indulgent, self-smug econocrats. I hope that the Democrats will support us later on this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-In a recent address, Dr Hewson referred to the red tape, the green tape and the black tape that was tying up Australia. I think the comparisons that Dr Hewson drew on that occasion are very apt for consideration in the debate tonight. Senator Panizza's motion puts forward a number of very salient points. Firstly, it notes that the Government is considering--I emphasise that word--the creation of a special committee of Ministers to speed major projects. After eight years in office we have a Labor Government that is now coming forward thinking that it might need to do something about speeding up something.
—-Eight years of inactivity.

—-Eight years in inactivity, as Senator Knowles said. Senator Button in Question Time today accepted the fact that the special committee of Ministers that was supposed to have been set up after the 12 March industry statement--six months or so ago--has not yet got itself into gear. He was not even able to acknowledge whether it had met. He said that there had been some activity around the fringes. The fringes of what, I would like to know. Probably the curtains in some boudoir somewhere, because it certainly has not carried through to anything meaningful in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday Senator Collins stood up in the Parliament and said that the North Australian Development Unit of the Department of Social Security had been taken out of that Department and seconded as a new and special vamped-up organisation to be put into the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet appears to be nothing more than an octopus, spreading out with great new tentacles into new areas--whether it is the environment, Aboriginal reconciliation or, now, a special unit to sustain Senator Collins as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia.

We hear that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is about to establish a branch office in Darwin. Why has that happened after eight years in Government in a re-organisation? It is because the Northern Territory Government for the last five years has established new and special relationships with its near-neighbour Asian countries and has been far more successful than has anything done by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Suddenly that Department thinks it has to catch up on the action and get involved.

The second part of Senator Panizza's motion condemns the Government for the ineptitude which has allowed so many mineral projects around Australia to be either totally stopped or delayed and, in effect, has resulted in eights years of lost opportunities. Senator Panizza very aptly illustrated that particular argument. I will return to it soon with respect to other areas in northern Australia.

Thirdly, Senator Panizza called on the Government to ensure that projects already cleared by mining and environmental authorities proceed immediately. How many of them are shelved? How many of them have been approved by the processes? The best example that we have had in recent times is, of course, Coronation Hill--a project in which this Federal Labor Government encouraged the mining development companies to spend some $14m on all of the stages of exploration and advance planning, following which at the last minute, it castrated the entire project.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Prime Minister even gave them a letter.

—-The Prime Minister certainly gave them a letter of commitment as to where they were going. Today Senator Macdonald and I met with some executives of Mount Isa Mines Ltd who were in this building. Some very salient points came out in the course of that discussion. The executives told us that, of the current exploration activity of Mount Isa Mines, 45 per cent was now to take place offshore. Seventy per cent of the exploration activity of BHP is now to take place offshore.

SPEECH.PARA: If we took a broad-brush approach to many other companies, we would find that 50 per cent of Australian-based mining and resource companies are now aiming their exploration activities offshore. Why? Because, essentially, there are three criteria by which those companies have to judge how they are going to carry out their activities. What are they looking for? They are looking for a stable government, for an economic climate and, of course--and probably I should have said this first--for mining prospectivity.

All of these companies can establish that in Australia and its close waters there is mining prospectivity. It is only on the other two issues that all of these companies are now judging their involvement and their criteria and are having to move offshore. That is, there is not a stable political environment or government in place that can give them the guarantees that they want, and there is not an economic climate in which any of these companies can operate with any confidence.
I refer to recent reports of major resource companies in Australia. The Comalco report was tabled on 22 February 1991. In the Chairman's statement to that report, Mr J. T. Ralph states:

Despite the urgent need to devote more of Australia's resources to the tradeable goods sector, this remains difficult to achieve. Established and prospective exporters face continued constraints in the domestic operating environment, particularly those relating to an inflexible labour market, poor productivity, excessive Government charges, inefficiently operated infrastructure and uncertain and cumbersome regulatory approval processes.
What a damning statement from Comalco. I turn to the CRA report of 19 March 1991. The Chairman, Mr Uhrig, stated:

The present methods of gaining community approval for new projects tend to be slow, cumbersome and unpredictable. They vary from state to state and are subject to a growing level of federal involvement. For companies like CRA they can be a threat to much needed new investment.
I turn to the 1991 exploration report by the Directors of Renison Goldfields Consolidated, which states:

The Group has previously reported that the discovery of new orebodies is becoming more difficult, particularly in Australia, due to the increasing importance given to alternative uses of land and to environmental considerations.

They are three very major and significant companies. Add to that the known factor relating to exploration activities where the major companies of Australia are now having to find their investments to protect their shareholders' interests, who are Australian citizens in the main.

We have a Government that is now preoccupied. Anyone who closely followed the discussions in the consideration of the estimates of DASETT and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet would find that reams and reams of paper are now flowing with regard to the studies of ecologically sustainable units. Some 11 working parties are reporting to the Prime Minister's Department and it is doubtful whether, after almost a year of operation and millions of dollars in consultants' reports, they will have an agenda that can be presented to the November Premiers Conference.

Anyone who carefully read the barometer of what is happening in that area would note that the Labor Government is succumbing to the radical green agenda and the radical political agenda. There will be no decisions in the November Premiers Conference because the Prime Minister will ensure that no decisions are taken and that it will be another ongoing talkfest so that he can attempt to bring it back, probably, to another special meeting next March or the routine May Premiers Conference next year. Then, of course, it may get bogged down in next year's Budget as well.

If we go back to 25 February 1991 and look at the Industry Commission Report entitled Mining and Minerals Processing in Australia, we see some very interesting statements. Let us look at the area with which we are very familiar--the red tape that constantly ties up these matters. I quote from that report:

Lengthy delays in gaining approval for mining, particularly once exploration funds have been committed, represent a costly burden on the mining industry. Delays in gaining government approval arise for two main reasons. One is procrastination over whether mining or environmental interests should have access to land. The other is overlapping responsibilities between government agencies.

Many commentators attribute the decline in mining activity in Victoria to the regulatory process in that State. However, there is hope for a better system as the changes in the South Australian approval system illustrate.
I certainly hope that we see a concentration in that area.

The report of the Industry Commission goes on to illustrate amply the dilemma that is facing not just mining companies but also so many other agencies in our community. I refer to the exploration budgets and how they are put together. For example, in referring to the BHP gold exploration budget of about $10m a year, I point out that about four years ago the company began allocating about $1m a year to Victoria but found that the regulatory system imposed a two and a half year wait before a company could drill a test hole. Four projects were drilled with results that were technically interesting, but the company declined to begin any new work because of the delays. I quote from a company officer:

The straw that broke the camel's back was a project where we wanted to test some Creswick tailing dumps. Everyone was in agreement, the landowner, local government and all the State departments. In November last year we planned to use Ballarat students during their Christmas vacation, but getting the exploration permits signed took us five months, and by that time the students were back at college.
So much for helping youth unemployment in this country.

The Industry Commission report has also highlighted the need in so many other areas. The situation that is familiar to me in the Northern Territory is the area relating to Aborigines. Again let me quote from the Industry Commission report of 25 February 1991:

Granting land rights to Aborigines may well have restricted exploration and mining in the Territory, relative to levels which would otherwise have occurred. Nevertheless, it would be wrong to conclude from this that, as a consequence, land and sub-surface resources are not being devoted to their socially optimal use. However, current arrangements for distributing royalties (strictly speaking royalty equivalents) from mining to Aborigines in the Territory reduce the incentives for any one group of traditional Aboriginal owners to agree to exploration/mining on their land. This situation represents an impediment to the efficient development of mining and mineral processing in the Territory. The efficiency objective would be more effectively served if the share of royalty equivalents received by traditional owners were to be increased. In the Commission's view, the share of royalty equivalents currently earmarked for the administration of Land Councils should be paid to the Aborigines on whose land mines are established. This would increase their share of royalty equivalents from 30 to 70 per cent and the Commission is confident that this would go a long way towards providing more appropriate incentives for traditional owners to make the `best' decisions from their own and the nation's point of view.

The Commission can see no reason why the ability of Land Councils to fulfil their statutory obligations--such as identifying who the traditional owners of particular tracts of Aboriginal land are, and assisting in land claims--should depend on the level of royalty equivalents (which in turn reflect the level of royalties paid by mining companies in the Territory). Land Councils--as statutory bodies with functions and responsibilities conferred under Commonwealth legislation--should be funded from the Commonwealth Budget.

We have seen time and again those sorts of situations constantly arising. There are substantial costs and inefficient allocation of resources where the inevitable outcome of this uncoordinated, inconsistent and sometimes outdated confusion of regulation is so apparent. Time and again--whether it is the Green agenda of the current Labor Government, whether it is the objective of many radicals in the community who do not wish to participate in a forward-looking environment that creates jobs for our community--we really need to look at the detail.

Earlier I mentioned Coronation Hill--a very sad saga in the decision making processes of this Parliament, and particularly of the Labor Government in this past year. The capital injections that would have stimulated the economy and flowed right throughout Australia are inescapable to any decent person who is reviewing that area. I refer to the hundreds of jobs that would have been provided on site and the effects that would have flowed to many Aboriginal families who want to see that project proceed. The environmental considerations and Aboriginal considerations have been addressed time and again. But no, for a political agenda, the Labor Government stood back, put on the brakes and changed things because it was courting the votes of marginal seats in Sydney and Melbourne where Labor believed that its seats were at stake. Therefore, Labor was not considering the national economic agenda or the development of remote and rural Australia, which are so very important. There are many projects that attach to this.

We can also look at Jabiluka and Koongarra uranium projects that have been begging for development in the Northern Territory for 10 years or more. But the Federal Government has been jellybacked, a phrase used earlier today. Those developments have been held back because of market changes, and opportunities may well have been lost because of delays.

I mentioned earlier the bureaucratic delays that often arise from Aboriginal considerations. In the Northern Territory we are particularly constrained by the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, which imposes heavy and detailed bureaucratic considerations. Let me illustrate that by saying that, since the introduction of that Act in 1976, there have been 472 applications for exploration licences in the Northern Territory. Of these, 104 have been withdrawn, refused or amalgamated prior to the appropriate consent of the Northern Territory Minister. Eight are still pending the Northern Territory Minister's consent. Therefore, 360 have been issued with consent to negotiate by the Northern Territory Minister.

Where are they today, statistically, relating to those 360 applications for exploration licences? Well, 22 relate to applications to lodge a proposal with the relevant Land Council; 76 have been withdrawn or refused subsequent to the Northern Territory Minister's consent; and 122 of them have been vetoed by the land councils. Furthermore, 108 of them--and this is going back to 1976--are currently being considered by the land councils. They are bogged down in the bureaucracy and bogged down in black tape. Six are pending a grant to be consented to by the Federal Minister, and 26 have been granted by the Northern Territory Government; I emphasise 26 out of 472. The statistical appraisal of the sort of obstruction that totally frustrates the exploration activities in that area is similar to what I described earlier. Because of the political and economic climate, we see a disastrous situation when we consider the proper national agenda of Australia.

Several years ago, when Senator Evans was the Minister responsible in the resources area, he agreed to make amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in order to facilitate certain changes that would help this process. The Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, who has since taken over that portfolio, made very positive statements following the recommendations of the Industry Commission last year.

What has happened to the recommendations now? They are bogged in a joint consideration by a special working party of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which Minister Griffiths administers, and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Goodness only knows how long it will take for that working party to report to the Government--and then what sort of process will we see? Again, the chicken-hearted, lack of decision resolve of this Labor Government will mean that consideration will be bogged down in so many of those areas.

I notice that Senator Panizza outlined earlier a number of projects in Western Australia. There are so many projects on the prospective or proposed lists. We need to ask why many of these projects are not proceeding and why they are bogged down. The proposed Stuart oil shale plant near Gladstone could possibly cost $100m. Alpha oil shale, Condor oil shale, Rundle oil shale and Yaamba oil shale are other proposed projects. The list goes on.

In the Northern Territory, prospectivity was firstly highlighted by the possible advantages of Coronation Hill and the El Sherana area. Why were those projects taken off the rails? At Jabiluka there is the largest low grade deposit of uranium in the world. At Koongarra there are reserves of 14,500 tonnes of uranium oxide. Why is that project bogged? It is because of Commonwealth uranium policy. McArthur River has the world's largest reserves of zinc, lead and silver. At Mount Wells there are tin reserves.

Various gold projects have not got off the ground. Where is the prospectivity in north Queensland? I have a list of at least six major goldmines that cannot proceed. There is copper in many areas. In base metals, there is a wide number of projects. North-west of Mount Isa there is the Century project run by CRA, where a vast infrastructure will be needed. In the last year we have seen that this is one of the projects that are very questionable because of the activities of government, radicals or other people trying to stop it.

There are many areas of mineral sands reserves, including Byfield, Shoalwater Bay and Rocky Point. The projects that the mining companies have identified go on and on for pages and pages but, either because of the economic climate or because of the bureaucratic constraints of a government that is preoccupied with a marginal seat strategy, they cannot be developed.

Yet we have a government that in the Budget this year put $100m on the table for bigger, brighter, more beautiful and better cities somewhere between Newcastle and Geelong. What a front! When we dig deeper into the Budget, what do we find? We find about $50m in this year's Budget--and probably the same for next year. Given that the Labor Party knows that it is out the back door at the next election, that $100m will not go to any major projects for bigger, brighter, more beautiful and better cities in Australia; it will be going to shoring up the marginal seats of the Labor Party in Newcastle, Sydney, Wollongong, Melbourne and Geelong--a hundred million dollars worth of wasted taxpayers' money that should be used to facilitate jobs and major projects and programs, particularly in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and north Queensland. There dozens of projects are waiting to go and there are job opportunities for thousands of young Australians who want to live a different lifestyle, participate in the economy of this nation and not be statistics--part of the 30 per cent figure that we saw presented today of youth unemployment, youth being those people under 25 years of age.

We can address environmental problems; we can address Aboriginal problems. They are just administrative issues. The challenge is to work with the companies that can develop and participate in international trade and get this country back to where it should be. I thoroughly commend Senator Panizza's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The attitude expressed in and the assumptions behind Senator Panizza's motion are about what one would expect from the coalition--that is, the attitude that resources are there simply to be exploited for profit, to be dug up and shipped away, and that all mining is good by definition. It seems that the coalition is particularly anxious to encourage this mining. It cannot wait to get its hands on anything that will bring profit to the exploiters. Why is that? Why is there this anxiety? Is the Opposition afraid of a realistic appraisal of the value of Australia's resources, something which is long overdue and which would bring an enlightened approach to the use of our resources? While that appraisal would not guarantee the wise use of our resources, it should assist in the careful appraisal of projects before they are eagerly undertaken. This eagerness would be discouraged by such an appraisal of the value of Australia's resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps these people are concerned about the concept of a resource rental tax. They want to get into mining before the people of Australia receive a proper return for the exploitation of what belongs to everybody. Everybody has a stake in resource development, and it is about time that the profit seekers recognised that the community which provides--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I didn't mention the word `profit' once. You are the only one preoccupied with profit.
—-I did not interrupt Senator Tambling once. I would appreciate some consideration.
—-Yes, but he was talking sense.
—-Senator Panizza will not know what I am talking about if he does not listen.
—-Senator Bell, continue your speech. There will be no more interjections.

—-I am very pleased about that, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is about time that profit seekers recognised that the very community which provides consumers of resources provides the very means by which profits are made. It follows, of course, that without the community there would be no profits to be made from resources or any undertaking. Therefore, the community deserves recognition for its role in this process. The community deserves to be richly compensated for that role.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have in the motion in front of us? There is no mention of the potential community benefit to be derived from this. We heard much made of it during the speeches, but within the motion there is no mention of any community benefit to be derived from rushing into the projects that the motion mentions. Perhaps that is because it is embarrassing to consider what little real community benefit we will derive from `dig it up, ship it out' developments. That can be development only in inverted commas, because digging it up and shipping it out cannot be development in a real sense. Such activities are notoriously capital intensive, with limited labour input. That means very few jobs per dollar spent. The dollars spent are of little value to Australia, with most mining equipment being built overseas and a considerable amount of the profit being expatriated.

It might be a different matter if we saw in this motion some mention of the concept which seems to have unanimous support in this chamber and throughout Australia--that is, the concept of value adding or further processing of our resources before we send them over the horizon, selling them not as raw materials but rather as processed products. Such production would be of real benefit to Australians. Selling our raw materials in an unprocessed fashion is tantamount to selling Australian jobs overseas.

I can guess why there is such anxiety to stoke up this little job exporting exercise and so little enthusiasm for establishing any further processing in Australia. I can guess that the real reason is that the coalition proposes to tax value adding. That is its stated proposition. It wants to discourage value adding and further processing. Here we have an anxiety to get into a few mining projects, dig a bit of stuff up and flog it off overseas before the coalition's very own tax could apply. It wants to discourage further processing. It wants to tax value adding. Here we see a proposition to stoke up the mining industry.

The coalition's proposition is entirely inconsistent with any incentive to develop employment. Senator Panizza mentioned the export of 41 million tonnes of iron ore and the employment of some 3,000 people. I do not dispute those figures at all. What I suggest is that it is self-evident that this activity cannot be described as development. It is depleting, it is spending, it is squandering our resources.

Let us have a look at those figures which sounded quite big. The export of 41 million tonnes for 3,000 people employed equates to 13,500 tonnes for one person employed. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you are reminded, as I am, of the traditional song which captures the spirit of those people who realised the futility of digging up and shipping out. That old song--which I will not sing because I know Senator Macdonald would probably join in and then we would all have to leave--has the lines: `. . . sixteen tons and what do you get? Another day older and deeper in debt'. The refrain of that song continues: `I owe my soul to the company store'. In terms of the traditional song, 16 tonnes a day for 365 days a year works out at around 5,840 tonnes a year. I am not even impressed by the productivity of the mining industry which Senator Panizza quoted because it has only doubled what would be derived from the traditional method, the hand method, of mining. It is exploitative at the best and inefficient at the worst.

I was very pleased to hear Senator Panizza say that minerals belong to all Australians and that they should be harvested for all Australians. The demonstrated history, of course, of the sorts of projects that Senator Panizza mentioned is that a few people prosper, other Australians receive a pittance when their minerals are spent. If we valued these resources properly, we would not be so eager to dig them up and ship them out. We would see more propositions for integrated projects to process our materials and our resources here to create things of necessity.

Whatever we do, however huge the resource is, as soon as we have mined it, we have lessened it and we become the poorer for that. The nation then owns less. Surely it is obvious to all people that the only wise thing to do is ensure that we extract the maximum value from every resource we exploit. We can ensure that by discarding the concept of taxing the value added and by understanding the commonsense behind placing a realistic tax on resources. Such a tax would discourage the cavalier anxiety that Senator Panizza has to dig it up. Such a tax would also increase the value of waste material. Waste recovery, secondary resource utilisation--or recycling, to redefine either of those previous terms--could shed the wimpish image with which the big tough guys of the mining industry have liked to label recycling. They have tried to saddle it with that image. Let us face it, miners have a vested interest in resource wastage. The more we throw away, the more they can flog.

It is time to stop this nonsense. It is time to treasure our resources and cynically evaluate each and every proposition to deplete them. In doing that, we should reject any proposition that we need to proceed immediately with the sort of undue haste that is suggested by Senator Panizza.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not often take much notice of what Paul Lyneham says, but I must say, having listened to Senator Bell talk about the Democrats' economic policy, how much I appreciate one of Paul Lyneham's definitions in his book called Political Speak, which is about to be released. He defines astrology as being `the art of drawing up the Democrats' economic policy'. That is what Senator Bell and the rest of his crew do when they talk about economics. They are pure stargazers. They have no idea of the realities of life.

SPEECH.PARA: They often criticise us for having no policies. Quite rightly, this afternoon the Government was roundly criticised for its policies which have brought about the massive unemployment in Australia at the moment. We do have policies to correct that sort of thing. Dr Hewson will, very shortly, be announcing one of the most radical rearrangements of the Australian direction with our policies of what is needed to get Australia going. Some of those policies include giving the incentive to people to work, the incentive to Australians to produce and to export overseas. One of the ways we will be doing that, contrary to Senator Bell's understanding, is to take away taxes on inputs into anything that is to be exported. We will be encouraging exports and, in doing that, creating a better Australia and providing better jobs and better job prospects for the almost one million Australians who are currently out of work, principally as a result of the actions of this Government.

On a day when the unemployment figure has passed the 10 per cent mark for the first time since 1983, and when almost one million of our fellow Australians are unemployed, the motion moved by Senator Panizza tonight could not have been more appropriate. Senator Panizza's motion notes that the Government is considering setting up a special committee of Ministers to speed major projects which is indicative of the disastrous situation Australia has reached in the development of mineral resource projects. The motion goes on to condemn the Government for its ineptitude in allowing so many mineral projects to be either totally stopped or delayed right around Australia and calls upon the Government to do something, to take control of the situation, by giving the immediate go ahead on projects right around Australia.

My colleague Senator Tambling has mentioned just some of the many projects that are waiting to go ahead and which, if they do go ahead, will provide enormous job opportunities for our fellow Australians. Yabulu, the nickel refinery project near Townsville where I come from, is a perfect example of a major project in jeopardy. That particular project employs about 1,000 people. But if this Government continues on its way and does nothing, as it is so prone to doing, then there will be one million plus one thousand people out of work because that project will have to close down unless the Government is prepared to take some leadership role in it.

The nickel from Greenvale just in the hills beyond Yabulu runs out in about 18 months' time. Queensland Nickel Pty Ltd, the operators of the project, which I might say is 30 per cent owned by the Queensland Government, wanted to import nickel ore through Halifax Bay adjacent to the Yabulu refinery. That nickel ore was to come in from New Caledonia and Indonesia because we have run out of high grade ore in Australia. But the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the local Green movement vetoed that proposal and now the company is forced to waste months and money with an appeal against that decision in the AAT.

I understand that apart from diverting the attention of that company to keeping the jobs and getting things going, it is also costing that company in total more than $1m in legal costs to argue about these sorts of things. This situation has the potential to put Queensland's second biggest export earner and the second largest nickel refinery in the world in jeopardy.

Because of that, I was pleased to see that Senator Button had included Yabulu on the so-called secret list of projects he hopes to fast track, a list that is supposed to be secret but so secret that it has been widely circulated for publication in the press gallery. If something is not done soon, this company may have to downgrade its activities, consider lesser grade ore or close down completely, and none of those options is acceptable.

I wrote to Senator Button on 20 September asking him to clarify what he meant by including Yabulu in the fast track proposal. I asked him to outline what he intended to do to fast track the problems that were being experienced in that area. It might surprise honourable senators to hear that I have got no response. I have not even had so much as an acknowledgment. So much for putting these projects high on the priority list!

Either Senator Button did not know what he was going to fast track or he is afraid to tell us. Perhaps he is proposing something that Senator Richardson's Green people might not like. He is very reticent about what he proposes for the projects that he wants to fast track. Maybe he is waiting until the Government's major projects group, which was established as part of the 12 March industry statement, meets for the first time before he tells me what is proposed. The group has not met for some seven months. As I understand today's press, the Government is now toying with yet another committee of senior Ministers to look at the same sorts of proposals.

All these committees on committees are typical of what is wrong with the Australian economy and the way the Government is attempting to manage it. The Government never does anything. It just sets up more committees, gets more bureaucrats involved and throws around a lot of ideas. Nothing happens. I look forward to seeing how the views of Mrs Kelly, on the one hand, and Senator Button and Mr Griffiths, on the other hand, will be resolved, particularly when it seems that their views are diametrically opposed.

Although I could not get a response from Senator Button, I was, fortuitously, able to read in today's Australian what Senator Button is proposing. I am grateful to the Australian for telling me what Senator Button would not tell me. According to the Australian, Senator Button says that the Queensland Government has sought Commonwealth funding for the project to use the Townsville Port Authority, that the matter has been the subject of correspondence between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Queensland Premier and that we are still waiting for a response.

We do not know yet whether the New Caledonian and Indonesian ore is to come in. We are still waiting while the Labor Premier and the Labor Prime Minister write back and forth to each other and see what they can do. Of course, Mrs Kelly has some views on it. She says that the ore cannot come in through Halifax Bay because of environmental problems. She talks about the appeal to the AAT. Then she says that maybe a Commonwealth decision needs to be made in relation to the upgrading of the port of Townsville.

What the Queensland Government is proposing is a pretty simple solution. It is saying, `Well, Dallhold Nickel or Queensland Nickel, the way for you to get your nickel ore is to bring it through the Townsville port, but we do not want you to use the existing facilities; we want you to spend $90m to build a new outer wharf at the Townsville port so you can bring the ore in there'. For the privilege of keeping the refinery going, keeping people in jobs, the companies have to build another wharf at a cost of $90m. That is the ridiculous proposal that the ALP is part of at the moment.

There are numerous other projects where the Commonwealth should be doing more to get moving. The Queensland Metals Corporation's magnesium metal project at Gladstone is an example where a decision by the Government would prevent any further delay in the start to the project. The initial stages of this project await Cabinet consideration on a proposal from the company, and that is the last hurdle.

This project could see the eventual development of a world standard magnesium metal plant which would have enormous benefits for Australia in the medium to long term. Currently we import all of our 10,000 tonnes of magnesium metal each year and the development of the appropriate technology by the Queensland Metals Corporation would almost certainly lead to a complete replacement of magnesium metal imports and create exports of up to 60,000 tonnes of magnesium metal each year, worth something like $220m.

The market for magnesium metal is not huge at the moment, but, with the increasing importance of lighter metals in cars, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the potential for the use of magnesium in cars in the next 20 years is massive. Furthermore, value adding to these industries, particularly in die casting and alloy production, is almost certain to follow in central Queensland, especially with the presence of the aluminium industry in that central Queensland region around Gladstone and the supply of natural gas to that region. The starting gun for this project is in the Government's hands. I would encourage it not to hesitate in making a decision but to get on and do something about it. I read in the Australian today that Senator Button also seems to be urging for something to be done about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where was he 12 months ago?

—-I do not know where he was 12 months ago. Obviously he has at last come to the conclusion that we must have jobs here in Australia. He sees these things, quite properly, as the way to get jobs and the way to get Australia going.

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately, Mrs Kelly's confidential response to Senator Button's confidential letter was also printed in the Australian. Mrs Kelly talks about a magnesium project, but she has the wrong project. She is talking about another one at Kunwarara, which is north of Rockhampton, not in the Gladstone area. I only mention that because recently I inspected that plant. It is a very fine plant that will do a lot for Australia's export industry. When showing me around, the project manager said that he had to get some 67 separate government approvals from State, Federal and local governments and authorities to get that plant operating. I am telling some secrets that I should not, but at the time I was talking to him he said that he got to 64 and gave up. He said that if they wanted to they could shut him down then. The plant was almost built then, and I am sure by now he has the rest of the approvals.

I repeat that he had to get 67 separate approvals before getting a very fine export plant going. People ask what is wrong with Australia, why we cannot create jobs and why there are one million unemployed. Requiring 67 separate approvals is the sort of attitude that creates lack of confidence, lack of investment and the resulting lack of employment.

The $600m Byfield mineral sands project, also near Gladstone, could also use some swift Federal government action. The company, RZ Mines, has put in a mining lease application to the Queensland Government, but it could use a coordinated approach between the Federal and State governments so that it could prepare an environmental impact statement which satisfied the requirements of both the State and Commonwealth rather than wasting time and money, as so often happens, in duplicating work on two separate environmental impact statements.

This sort of rationalising of environmental regulation would be of great assistance to numerous projects and would not require much work on the part of the Commonwealth. The Byfield mineral sands project has faced continuing opposition from extreme radical sections of the environmental lobby who have not even waited to see the environmental impact study. The project was delayed for over a year by the Queensland Labor Government's coastal study, even though the obstacles to progress on the coastal study related to Aboriginal and environmental concerns on Cape York, whereas this project is in central Queensland. This project offers some 400 jobs in the region and there would be a natural flow-on effect. The Federal Government must do all within its power to see that the process is not unduly long.

There are numerous similar examples of where the Federal Government could assist. The Shoalwater Bay sandmining proposal is one. Negotiations between the company and the Government have proceeded smoothly to date. However, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories must take care that when it receives the company's environmental management plan it is not hijacked by the attitude of the ACF, which has pledged to wipe out all sandmining in Australia, regardless of individual circumstances. I hope there will be no repeat of Coronation Hill, where the Government sponsored the ACF to prevent a project for its own shabby political reasons.

I read in the Australian in relation to the Shoalwater Bay project that some leases and the Commonwealth's part of the project are now the responsibility of the Department of Administrative Services. If we have to wait for Senator Bolkus and his Department to do anything about those matters, we can be assured that there will be no progress on that project for many years to come.

The list goes on. I am again indebted to the Australian for pointing out some other projects in my State of Queensland which are related to the mining industry. Senator Button has proposed that something be done about the Boyne Island power station, which the Queensland Government proposes to sell to Comalco. But the Queensland Government is haggling over the price and holding back an enormous project which could provide a lot of jobs. The Queensland Government has said to the Commonwealth, `Give us the extra money that you'll get because we are going to privatise this power plant. You will get tax revenue from the private company that runs it and we want a share of that tax take'.

Senator Button seems to be a little in favour of that proposal. Apparently a precedent has been set in the State Bank of Victoria case, so maybe it will proceed. But it needs to proceed now because the one million people are unemployed now. We have to do something about those jobs now, not in two or three years time. Mrs Kelly's confidential response to Senator Button in relation to this matter says--and the first two words worry me a bit:
To date, there has been no Commonwealth environmental involvement in the proposal.
I hope that does not mean that at some future date there will be because, if that is the case, this project is also likely to founder.

I am again indebted to the Australian for information about another Gladstone project. I might add in passing that Gladstone in central Queensland is a community which encourages development and industrial projects. In that city and in that community there is a culture of encouraging development and encouraging jobs. Unemployment in that area is lower than it is elsewhere because Gladstone has embarked upon this project to create jobs and to create wealth for Australia. The $750m special steel project is proposed for that area and it could be announced early in 1992, according to Senator Button's letter. I wonder whether that means that there will be an election in early 1992. Maybe Senator Button has learned from the old Bjelke-Petersen days that when an election is due one starts announcing such projects. But I do not mind if he wants to do that because it would be good for Australia and good for Gladstone.

According to Senator Button, we are waiting for some Australian Industry Development Corporation assistance. I urge it to get on with making some decisions. Again, I am a fraction concerned by Mrs Kelly's confidential response to Senator Button's confidential letter. The Australian tells me that Mrs Kelly has said that, `the project has not been designated at the Commonwealth level as yet'. Again, I worry about the words `as yet' because maybe she will somehow be able to stick her nose into that, and if that happens we are in for a long wait. As I have said, the list goes on and on.

I will mention in passing a couple of other instances where the Government could show some leadership and get some projects going which would create jobs and wealth for this country, and in the process create a better Australia. Although it does not involve mineral matters, I bring to the Senate's attention the space base proposal for north Queensland. With a bit of leadership and some infrastructure support and encouragement from Senator Button and this Government, that project could go ahead and supply the north of Australia with some 3,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —-High-tech jobs.

—-Senator Parer is quite correct. They would be good jobs, jobs for the future, in an industry with a technology that would take Australia into the next century. But what happens? Again, the Government vacillates, dillydallies and shows no leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: Then I refer to the Tully-Millstream hydro project, which could go ahead and create many jobs in north Queensland. If it were developed, it would also supply power that would ensure that industry in that area could continue to operate efficiently and effectively for many decades. But what has happened with Tully-Millstream? The Queensland Government instigated a report to end all reports--the ultimate report--to incorporate environmental matters, economic matters and every other matter. After a lot of money and a lot of time the report came out. It was in favour of the project, so one would think, `You beaut, away we go. Let's get some development going. Let's create some jobs and reduce the unemployment lines in north Queensland'. But what happens then? It has to go to the Commonwealth Government. It then dillydallies around. I will say in the Commonwealth's Government's favour that it claims to have been stalled on that project by the ALP Government in Queensland. But here we have two governments fiddling around and stalling each other, and sending it to another group of bureaucrats for another report. So the story goes.

In Gladstone there is a sodium cyanide plant. It is a tremendous plant, built by ICI, which is replacing imports of that material. What does this Government do about it? It does not help. That plant, which was so expensively built and has produced an excellent product which we will be able to sell to the world, has been attacked by overseas interests dumping the product into Australia in competition with the local product. They will ruin that industry if something is not done about dumping.

The money has been spent and an effort has been made to pass anti-dumping legislation but, because of the antiquated and almost irrelevant anti-dumping rules and procedures which this Government continues to promote and protect, that plant is in real danger of a difficult future. If this Government had any leadership it would do something and fix up the anti-dumping rules so that that plant could continue to compete, and compete fairly.

Today it has been revealed that the Government's own industry Minister, Senator Button, has told the Prime Minister that he doubts that our tax system is internationally competitive. I do not know that that is such a profound statement, but it is profound coming from someone on the Government side.
