His so-called confidential letter, which I have quoted from at some length by kind favour of the Australian, is like all that seems to happen in the Government at the moment: it plays out its internal factional differences on the front pages of the newspapers via leaked documents. In that letter, Senator Button is asserting that the antiquated tax system is holding up development almost as much as environmental and Aboriginal concerns.
Senator Button also told the Prime Minister in this secret letter that:
. . . Australia is investing too little to sustain adequate growth and that unless manufacturing and mining output increase substantially, the country faces a prolonged current account deficit.

The Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, has similar concerns. This was pretty well illustrated in his speech to the Labor Party's annual talk-fest, which was held in Mount Isa recently. He said that people were sick of projects being tied up in the bureaucracy and the paralysis of analysis. He went on to say:
We need a philosophy of how projects should proceed rather than whether they should proceed. This is what integration of environmental and economic objectives was supposed to be about.

But, in yet another display of the complete disarray in which this Government now finds itself, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly--or at least some of her departmental mandarins--rejected out of hand the notion that environmental considerations were holding up resource projects. It is no surprise that the confidential letter and the confidential reply to the confidential letter have ended up emblazoned all over the front and middle pages of today's Australian. It is an absolute joke.

I return to where I started by saying that we need look no further than the Yabulu nickel project to see that the Commonwealth environment hurdles are holding up that particularly major and important project. The Government has consistently failed to encourage investment in this country by streamlining the development procedures for major projects. It has been tinkering on the edges with all this rhetoric about fast-tracking committees and major project groups, and it deserves the condemnation of the Senate for its continuing failure to act in the national interest.

Today's unemployment figure has passed 10 per cent and a million of our fellow Australians are out of work. If this Government fails to act now, as Senator Panizza's motion calls upon it to do, it will further squander the future of ordinary Australians. I urge all honourable senators to support Senator Panizza's motion and to give Senator Button support to try to do something towards getting these projects on the way, so that we can create jobs for our fellow Australians who are currently languishing on the unemployment heap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will be very brief. I have a great deal of pleasure in joining Senator Macdonald in supporting the motion moved by Senator Panizza. In doing so, I congratulate Senator Macdonald on his very articulate, erudite and clear argument, which really goes to the heart of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that I part company with him in respect of one matter, in that a generous interpretation of his words could lead one to believe that he thinks Senator Button has a strong, long-lived view which has now simply surfaced in the mayhem of this Government. The truth of the matter is that this recession has been with us for two years; the economic indicators have been with us for 18 months; the misery index has been present and obvious to ordinary, decent Australians for a very long time; but it takes Senator Button to find a new reason for disagreeing with his colleagues and to be seen to be expressing a view which has been known to the rest of the community for the better part of a decade.

Where was Senator Button two years ago? Where was Senator Button with his confidentially leaked letters on Coronation Hill six, eight or 12 months ago? Where was Senator Button and his three-mine uranium policy? He was well hidden behind the door, unlike Senator Collins, who understood the absurdity of the situation and was not simply prosecuting an argument for his Aboriginal constituents.
This Government is not and never has been a government for all Australians. From day one it has been a government of compromise and expediency and a government for minority radical groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And for rich mates.

—-And for rich mates. There are two ways of doing business. At one end of the spectrum one worries about the lobby group because it has the votes and at the other end one worries about the lobby group because it has the dough. But anyone with any obvious, tangible, apparent sense would realise that neither of those components coagulates. In other words, people who happen to be mainstream, good, decent, blue-collar workers of Australia or middle class white-collar workers of Australia do not fit into either category and just miss out. This Government has never cared for ordinary, decent Australians. All that the talk of consensus by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) really means is accommodating those who are most noisy--doing a deal that satisfies those who make the most noise, cause the most trouble and are most faithfully reported by the media. If one happens to be a modest, ordinary, white, Anglo-Saxon, heterosexual, suburban fringe dweller who goes to work between nine and five--
—-What about the Catholics? Are they all right?

—-The Catholics do not fit into all the categories. As I have read in the last couple of days, in their own way they have a couple of pressure points. The tragedy is that, like most God-fearing Christians, they have suffered a terrible price as a result, in some cases, of supporting a Prime Minister who does not believe in a God.
—-He believes in Bula.

—-Yes, that is absolutely right. I was going to come to that in about 45 minutes. I will make a quantum leap in my observations. The Prime Minister has no deference, care, sensitivity, acknowledgment or respect for Christ, but if one happens to be Bula, or a new-found mythical figure created, invented and perpetuated by socialist anthropologists coming out of the hills of Kakadu, one then develops a new but fundamentally intrinsic relationship with this Prime Minister. I have to say that there is only one moment of comfort for me in all this: this Prime Minister will have to account to my God and not to Bula at the end of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that Lazarus has come into the chamber. I see that the deathbed repentant is actually here, by way of physical being or apparition. Six months ago he did not have the courage to say that Coronation Hill ought to be a goer; two years ago he did not have the courage to say that the three-mine policy is a nonsense; and he did not have the courage to hold hands with Senator Gareth Evans when he talked about clapped out buffalo country.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Has he repented?

—-It is an interesting thing about political life: as politicians get older and approach not their zenith but their final days, they develop a sense of melancholy, a sense of honesty and integrity and a sense of public awareness which they did not have the courage to admit to previously. Frankly, Senator Button is going through that cleansing stage so that he can leave this Parliament and this chamber with a sense of righteousness, and a sense of indignation should anybody suggest he has not always been an upstandingly honest leader of the Government.
—-The scales have fallen from his eyes.
—-No, the scales have always been off his eyes, but he has just been so strapped into the straitjacket of this Government that he has not had the courage to stand up and disagree with it.
—-What about the front page of the Australian this morning?

—-There is a difference between having the courage to stand up and be counted and sign one's name and, in some squalid and squatty way, leaking a document out the side door hoping that some journalist will scribble down one's notes in the media the next day. There is a distinction between those two things.
—-Say it outside, Senator. Say it outside and see how you get on!
—-I never thought Senator Button would offer me outside. If Senator Button was on his bike and I was in my joggers, he would still never catch me.
—-You'd run though, wouldn't you?

—-I would. The truth is that we have a million unemployed, rising by the day--rising by the hour. The truth is that Australian society does not exist on statistics; it lives in reality. Every single day new people are being retrenched. Seven per cent of workers were retrenched last year. Seven per cent of the Australian work force found a green notice in their pay packets last year. Every day this figure is increasing and compounding.

SPEECH.PARA: When the situation gets into the political red, when the lights go on that say it is politically dangerous, that is when the Government changes its mind--not when it matters socially, not when it matters economically and not when it matters compassionately. When the barometer moves into the politically dangerous area, then we find a government of this colour that is prepared to dump its previously welcomed, squalid little radical minority groups. The truth of the matter is that this Government has always been subject to three colourful votes, as we all know--black or red or green, never true blue Australians. This Government has always been prepared to do a deal with the Aboriginal leaders. It has not cared about the overwhelming majority of Aboriginals; it has been concerned with doing a deal with the radical Aboriginal leaders.

One project that it knocked off that Senator Collins would know all about was the Koongarra project. That project would have provided revenue of $256m in royalties to the Aboriginal community. The Government could not even treat that community decently. The ratbag lunatic left-wing fringe has held the Government to ransom while it has been paralysed for the past week over its health problems. It is not the ordinary, decent, caring Australian who has an understanding of and empathy with the environment, but the fringe lunatics who use the environment as an excuse for having absolutely no development, no growth, no improvement in wealth, no improvement in standard of living and no improvement in quality of life. The sadness is that whenever these minority groups hijack a government, those who are hurt first and those who are hurt most are the good decent blue-collar workers who are the traditional lifeblood of the Labor Party.

The reason that those on the other side of the chamber are now panicking--and paralysis is moving into panic--is that they know their traditional base is being hurt most and being hurt first, and it is going to move away from them. If there were an election tomorrow, those opposite would be dead ducks in the water. Of course, we all know that, whenever the election is going to be, they will be dead ducks. Does that worry Senator Button? He will not be here. He will retire as a member of the Government, having cleansed his soul at the last minute.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He should have gone to London when he had the chance.

—-Senator Hill is quite right. Senator Button should have gone to London when he had the chance; I am sure it looks more attractive every day. He could have ridden his bike around Green Park, or Hyde Park if he wanted to mix with the ordinary people.
—-Is this a debate about anything in particular?

—-As Senator Collins is locked in an internecine conflict with his colleagues, he has probably not been keeping up with the motion I am discussing. This debate is about the billions of dollars of resources that are locked up in Australia because of the myopic, blinkered, bigoted attitude of Senator Collins' Government and the attitude which Senator Collins, from time to time, with respect, has had the courage to stand up and disagree with. The three-mine policy in the Northern Territory is a very good example.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to argue whether it is $30 billion or $70 billion locked up in Kakadu. We can pick whichever we like. It is a substantial figure. It represents tens of thousands of jobs. It represents an improved standard of living for a lot of Australians. Why is it locked up? Could somebody on the Government side of the chamber stand up and give me a cogent, coherent, intelligent explanation, which is logically compelling, as to why we should have two uranium mines in this country, plus one that produces copper and gold? There is absolutely no explanation whatsoever. We only have that because, if I remember rightly, that was in the days of Don Dunstan in South Australia, and we had to get up Olympic Dam before the election; that is why we got it.

There is not an economically rational Minister who seeks to justify that policy. Why do we have it? We have it because prior to the last ALP conference, when this matter was likely to come to the surface, to bubble up as an issue, the Prime Minister was paralysed with fear and opposition and paranoia. He said, `I will diffuse this by selling out logic and rationale and ordinary decent Australians by saying that I will take it off the agenda so I do not have to deal with those ratbags from the Left and the few lunatics that belong to the Centre Left'. The tragedy is that that is the price that Australia pays for having this Government.

I am tempted to be deflected from this matter by saying that one cannot blame these minority groups for exerting their muscle. They have been able to do so simply because they have had a compliant and weak government. It is no good blaming the Aboriginal Legal Service that blows tens and thousands and millions of dollars a year of decent taxpayers' money up against the wall when the instruments it uses were created by the Government.

I was looking back through the Hansard a few moments ago at the speech I gave on the Aboriginal heritage legislation. I am reminded that I quoted the Minister who said that the Bill had been prepared in response to requests from Aboriginal people and following consultation with them. What is absent from that comment? There was no consultation with the mining community or with the wider community; just consultation with the Aboriginal community. Of course, the Government has given the Aboriginal community enormous muscle. The injustice of its compromise is perhaps best articulated by the penalties which apply. Entry onto declared land is now constituted an offence. The penalties are up to five years gaol or a $50,000 fine for entry onto what might be perceived as an Aboriginal site. That is five years in the Johnny slammer. If a person desecrates a church of my faith, the penalty is $500. Is there any doubt as to why these groups have muscle when they can get legislation of this nature through this Parliament?

In reality, nothing has changed philosophically or economically or socially in recent times that provides for a change in the judgments the Government is making in respect of these projects. The political climate has changed and this Government is in political trouble. If this Government believed it was certain to win the next election, we would not have Senator Button's leaking of letters. We would not have talks of fast tracks or high tracks or low tracks--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Or side tracks.
—-Yes, or side tracks. We would not have talk of panic and compromise. We would have the blind dogma of this Government going on and continuing to do its deals with Garrett.
—-Minorities.

—-The minorities would be leading the Government by the nose. The political environment has changed; not the economic environment. This Government understands that to continue to hold hands with these minority groups is tantamount to getting AIDS. The Government knows it is terminal. It knows that if it sticks with the loonies from the greens or the reds or the blacks, it is terminal. It knows it is dead. It has jettisoned these groups to try to resurrect its political opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: That comes, essentially, from the fact that one million people are unemployed. As has been said before, the only job that this Prime Minister worries about is the job that goes with a bed at the Lodge. He is not worried about a million workers. He is not worried about those white collar, 55-year-old, middle class, suburban accountants whose skill and qualifications are the knowledge that they have gained from the company for which they have worked for 20 years. He is not worried that if they are taken away from that environment that skill falls to zero, and that if they walk out of that building because they are retrenched they cannot get another position anywhere else because that knowledge and skill cannot be transferred and translated.

The Prime Minister does not care about those people who might have a mortgage and three children at a private college, or even high school, and who are paying for the second car. The Prime Minister is not worried about the fact that they will never recover from the emotional and social scars, and that they will probably never get a job commensurate with that which they have been ignominiously dumped from because the boss can no longer afford, not them, but this Government.

Perhaps I ought to look at some figures. These relate to investment projects which are subject to environmental constraints. That is a nice way of saying that they are dead in the water. In respect of paper and pulp mills, the investment lost thus far is $5.1 billion, with an estimated foreign exchange earning of $1,500m.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How many jobs does that represent?

—-I cannot be certain about that, and I do not know that I can even give a projection. In the mining industry a project that has an investment value of about $350m usually has about 350 or 400 jobs in the construction stage and a not dissimilar amount in long term employment. In mining and minerals processing, $1,220m is locked up, whether it be in Byfield minerals, Brockman rare earths, Clinton mineral sands, the rare earth plant at Pinjarra or the titanium oxide plant. That group accounts for lost foreign earnings of $500m.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at uranium. The figure I have before me is terribly modest, I think. It talks about holding up $1,000m. The figure for other minerals is shown at $2,473m--$2,473,000,000. One has to think of the number of noughts to get the dimension of it. We talk about billions without understanding how much that is. My dear colleague Senator Macdonald talked about the Cape York space station. That investment is, what, $600m? I ask Senator Button whether that is wrong. It has a foreign exchange earning of about $170m. Is that an unfair comment to make? Other projects are worth about $40m. That is about $8.2 billion--about $8,000,000,000. It is a lot of noughts. The total foreign earning loss would be $2,920m. I conclude by saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —-No, don't.

—-I am sorry, I will not conclude by saying. Senator Button has provoked me a little further. Does he want to hear about Shelburne Bay, Coronation Hill, Yeelirie or the Kintyre deposit? He knows about all these. Or Jabiluka. Jabiluka is a good project. Senator Collins knows about that. It requires about $300m to develop it. Several hundred millions of dollars in royalties would have gone to the Aboriginal community. Of course, there are jobs there--jobs for Aboriginals, like there would have been at Coronation Hill. The last time I inquired, about 50 or 60 Aboriginal members of the community had applied for jobs on the site.

SPEECH.PARA: The leaders--Jatbula, and I cannot remember the names of the others now, but I think Sandy Barraway was one and Nipper Brown was another--gave evidence before a committee that I was on. Under oath, in a very relaxed, discreet and private environment, with no harassment, no pressing, no cameras, no physical intimidation, they said two things: one was that they did not believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Were you there?
—-I was there in my normal, shadowy, retreating, barely visible way.
—-Self-effacing.

—-Self-effacing, stumbling over a couple of inarticulate questions. I asked what their attitude was towards Coronation Hill. First of all, two were alleged to have signed the application for the sacred site, and neither of them had the slightest memory of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Jatbula did--he was the fourth witness. I will talk about Nipper Brown. He is the best example, because he is the leader. Nipper Brown, who was the senior custodian, did not believe that Coronation Hill was a sacred site, had ever been a sacred site or had ever had intrinsic spiritual value.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yet he signed it.

—-He signed it with a cross. It could have been a cross of the devil. He certainly did not own up to having signed it. The only person who owned up to that was a fellow called Cooper from the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority, and he knew all about it.
—-The signature was a bit suspect.

—-I thought it was a bit suspect, as I said in the report. All those Aboriginal leaders were happy for mining to take place at Coronation Hill. They knew it would give them jobs, it would give them security. They knew that it was not likely to bring this mythical Bula down on their heads. They thought it was a whole bunch of nonsense, to be quite honest. Because of white advisers, because of minority groups, the leases for Coronation Hill were frozen and we had the inquiry by the Resource Assessment Commission. Ultimately, this Government, like the Nazis, has appropriated the mining leases and put them into Kakadu National Park. No compensation; no reward; no justification. I think it had spent $40m--I cannot remember the figure.
—-Sixteen.
—-Perhaps I am thinking about the money the mining company wanted to spend, but could not.
—-On the basis of the Prime Minister's letter.
—-Yes. The Prime Minister wrote to Arvi Parbo, `Trust me, Arvi'. Paul Keating is not the first, I can tell this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other cases--we saw the $1 billion Wesley Vale pulp mill project--and so they go on. I see Peter Laurance from the Pivot Group is in this sling too. They go on and on--Yakabindie and Marandoo. Perhaps it is exemplified most by what is happening in the Northern Territory. Of the 360 exploration applications forwarded to the land councils, 113 have been vetoed, 116 are being considered and 32 have been granted or are pending. Of the 116 under consideration, all but 26 have been under consideration for more than 12 months. That is what I call fast tracking. That epitomises this Government.

I understand that somebody wants to speak after me. I conclude by simply saying that I believe that Senator Button and others in this Government are absolute phonies when they talk about fast tracking. It is transparently obvious that they see a sea change in the political fortunes of this Government and, at the last minute, they are trying to get out. At the end of the day--

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is just rhetoric.
—-That is what I am saying. At the end of the day it will remain hot air, it will remain rhetoric, but nothing of substance--like this Government--will change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am not usually very sensitive on these issues, but when allegations are not only pernicious but also stupid I seek to correct them. Senator Crichton-Browne has said on several occasions that I leaked the letter to the Australian which I had written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is totally incorrect; it is a lie. Not only is it totally incorrect but also it is not a sensible allegation to make because it does not make any sense for me to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Crichton-Browne had read the context in which the letter was published, he, who has claimed to be astute on a number of these matters, would have worked out the motivation for that letter being published in the Australian. Perhaps he is incapable of doing that. I am seeking to correct that issue in terms of the Hansard allegation, which I would not like to remain unchallenged in any form on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to make a brief statement in respect of the same matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I intended to say, and I understood I said, that a letter of Senator Button's was leaked. If I said that Senator Button had himself deliberately leaked it--
—-You said I leaked it to the papers.
—-I was not implying that he personally leaked it. If that is what I said, I withdraw that allegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Panizza. The motion refers to the creation by the Government of a special committee of Ministers to speed up major projects. The implication there is that they have slowed major projects; hence a special group of Ministers is needed to speed them up. The Government has suddenly learnt what fast tracking is about. It has all the elements of what happened to the former Labor Government in 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: The mineral industry contributes over 50 per cent of the revenue that is obtained from Australia's exports. I would like Senator Bell to listen to this because he got up before and flippantly said, `They dig it up and ship it out'. If only it were so easy to find the darned stuff in the first place. I see Senator Collins nodding; he knows about this. Senator Bell says that we need more value added; everyone agrees with that. That is an idea I have been promoting since the days I was heavily involved in the resource industry. I pushed and pushed it.

Every time a feasibility study was done--the position has not changed because of the economic conditions imposed upon us by this Government; in fact they have got worse--it was found to be uneconomic. Senator Bell might say that that occurs because people are seeking a profit. He is still living in the days when `profit' was a dirty word, not recognising the fact that decisions are and always will be made in shareholders' interests. If they are not, the management of a company which does not use that as a guide is not looking after the interests of its shareholders. If Senator Bell has a superannuation investment or he has a share in a company, that is what he would require the operators of that company to do.

As I indicated, I was in the resource industry for many years. It is an area in which I am very proud to have been involved. Right from the word go, I was involved in the major developments in the Bowen Basin. Senator Bell asked, `What is the return to Australians?'. Just let me give the Senate a little example. During the period from 1968 to about 1983, in Queensland we built four major ports and six towns, all with underground power, sewerage, primary and secondary schools and all the other things which go with it. We provided water, power and telecommunications. We built railway lines and purchased the locomotives and rolling stock at not one cent's cost to the taxpayers of Australia. Having done all that, the railway lines and the rolling stock were then taken over by the Queensland Government, and a charge was made back which, in fact, represents a royalty. The claim is made--it has been made for many years and I think it is still the case--that the charge made was extortionate. I believe it was extortionate because all governments went through a phase of saying, `Let's jump on the band wagon'.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is because of the National Party.

—-Let me tell Senator Sherry the background to this. A Labor government in Canberra, when it could not take over the industry and when it stopped projects, decided that it would impose a tax on exports, and that tax still exists. At that time it was $6 a tonne and it nearly put the industry in New South Wales out of business. The tax was subsequently amended.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, I was involved in the early days. I can recall being bogged in four-wheel drive vehicles in dry dust in the Bowen Basin as we drove around areas that previously had been virtually untouched. I would presume that we would be prevented from doing that today because someone would decide that brigalow country should not be touched, notwithstanding the fact that the clearance of brigalow was essential for the development of the cattle industry in that part of Australia.

We built a mine in 1968 at Blackwater; in 1971 at Goonyella; in 1973 at Peak Downs; and in 1974 or 1975 at Saraji. The then Labor Government--the present one has all the same earmarks; we have different people but they are of the same tribe--decided that it would stop some additional projects. The reason the Government gave was that there was an oversupply.

What is the Government--that same tribe--now saying about uranium? The reason the Government will not move from its stupid three-mine uranium policy is that some clowns on the other side are saying that there is an oversupply. After the Whitlam Government was thrown out in 1975, the mines took off again. We had the development of Norwich Park, Oakey Creek, Newlands and Gregory. If the Labor Government had remained in power, there would be some $600m or $700m of coal not now being exported out of the Bowen Basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How many jobs is that?

—-Not only does that represent some thousands of direct jobs, but what is often forgotten is the multiplier effect of the number of jobs created in a capital intensive industry, which Senator Bell criticised but which, if this industry was not capital intensive, would not have got off the ground. A resource is only a resource if it can be mined economically.
—-You have two minutes.

—-I thank Senator Collins. I just conclude by saying that I noticed an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Griffiths, the Minister for Resources, in which again he just uses words. He says that the most important ecologically sustainable development issues are `access to land for exploration and mining'--what has he done about it?--`increased value-adding in Australia', which we agreed must be economic; and `ensuring world environmental management of mining operations'. We already have world-class environmental control of mining operations. If those opposite do not believe me, then let them go and have a look.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Beahan:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to comment briefly on the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters relating to the Aboriginal and Islander electoral information service. I particularly wish to comment on the minority report tabled by Senator Kemp and Mr Cobb. I note with some concern that the dissenting report suggests that the program was commenced due to a perception of low turnout and high informal voting amongst Aboriginal people. The minority report states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence that informal voting is not statistically different in Aboriginal communities than in the broader population. The Committee chose not to adequately consider this evidence.

That concerns me. I am also concerned that this program apparently involves some 13 officers and support staff and support facilities. The report does not seem to contain any details of funding for the program, but my guess is that the cost of that program would easily be $1m. I wonder whether it is necessary to have this Aboriginal and Islander electoral information service in existence.

In raising that question, I refer to some of the Aboriginal and Islander booths in the seat of Leichhardt in the last two elections. When one sees these figures one would wonder why the Aboriginal and Islander people need any assistance, any education and any help on how the electoral laws and the electoral and voting system work.

My experience with these communities is that they are very well listened--not read so much. They follow the ABC very closely, they listen to radio reports very closely and they watch television news. My impression has been that they are very articulate and very well aware when it comes to matters of public interest, matters of electoral interest and matters that affect their community.

I will cite some statistics, Mr Deputy President, which I am sure you will find interesting. On Coconut Island in 1987, there were 21 votes for the ALP, 37 votes for the Liberal-National Party and one informal vote. With one informal vote, one would not think that they need much tuition. Three years later, in the 1990 election, in the same booth, the majority that the Liberal-National Party had--37 votes to 21 votes--had changed and there were 70 votes for the ALP, only 13 for the Liberal-National Party and four informal votes. These people had had the benefit of the electoral information service in that time. There was one informal vote prior to the introduction of the service and four after it was introduced. The voting had turned around quite remarkably so that the ALP had about 90 per cent of the vote. You, Mr Deputy President, would be the first to agree that people voting like that probably do not need any extra assistance; that they are already voting fairly well.

I refer to Darnley Island. In 1987, the ALP got 32 votes, the Liberal-National Party got 67 votes, and there were seven informal votes. Three years later, with the benefit of this program, that had also changed around, surprisingly. There were then 77 ALP votes and only 34 for the Liberal-National Party, but the informal votes had, I must confess, fallen from seven to three. That is still not a large amount.

On Mabuiag Island in 1987, there were 78 votes for the ALP, only seven for the Liberal-National Party and five informal votes. In 1990 there were, would you believe, 92 votes for the ALP, only two for the Liberal-National Party and four informal votes. I wonder why these changes occurred.

I refer to Yam Island. In 1987, there were 29 votes for the ALP, 47 for the Liberal-National Party and only three informal votes. Three years later, with the benefit of this program there were, would you believe, 77 votes for the ALP, only 21 for the Liberal-National Party--that is a remarkable turnaround--and five informal votes.

I will look quickly at Yorke Island. In 1987, there were 86 votes for the ALP, 13 for the Liberal-National Party and one informal vote. Three years later, there were 83 votes for the ALP, nine for the Liberal-National Party--it has still gone down--and five informal votes.

There seems to be a very low informal vote. There seems to be a very astute and articulate expression of opinion by these people. It would seem that it is not necessary to educate these people in the way of voting because they already seem to be very well aware of it. That is also my experience. I believe that they fully understand the system, they know what they want to do, and I would not think that they need this assistance.

If $1m has been spent on this program--I have guessed that that is what it might be; I do not have any figures--I suggest that that $1m would be far better spent on 10 houses in those communities than on employing 13 or so public servants to run around trying to explain to them something that they already do very well. Can we not allocate those resources to something that would really benefit Aboriginal Island people, such as housing in those more remote communities, which give them a direct, real and lasting benefit?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to speak to this report. It being so near to 10.30 p.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to speak not in relation to the matter which has just been mentioned by Senator Reid but in relation to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. I have an obligation to do this as Chairman of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: An article that appeared in the Canberra Times dated 7 October 1991 was brought to my attention on Tuesday of this week at a meeting of the Committee here in the House. The article was headlined `Whitewash feared from Family Law Inquiry' by Michael Bachelard and was accompanied by a photograph of a Mr Ian Monk. The allegation of whitewash, together with a number of other allegations reported by the newspaper as having been made by Mr Monk, reflect on the integrity of the members of the Committee and on its independence. On behalf of all members of the Committee, which is bipartisan, I completely reject the allegations as having any substance whatsoever.

Unfortunately, Mr Monk has cast a slur on each member of the Committee. No member of the Committee objects to Mr Monk having the right to express his concerns freely on the matter into which the Committee is inquiring by making a submission to the inquiry. However, despite the agitation that the Committee has witnessed in respect of Mr Monk from regional New South Wales and metropolitan Sydney, Mr Monk has not felt it necessary to address a submission to the Committee on the wide terms of reference that the Parliament has given us.

The Committee is bemused that Mr Monk has consistently claimed credit for the establishment of the inquiry into the Family Law Act. Requests for such an inquiry have come from a number of sources, as members from both sides of the Parliament will attest. No individual has the right to claim to be responsible for the establishment of this or any other inquiry established by the Parliament.

The Committee is particularly concerned that the Canberra Times, a reputable newspaper, should publish offensive and defamatory allegations about the Committee and its members. This has been done without even speaking with me as Chairman or with any other member of the Committee, of which there are 10 in number, including myself. Those concerned have not even spoken to the very efficient secretariat that serves the Committee. This is inexcusable for a reputable newspaper such as the Canberra Times.

The simple expedient of contacting any of the Committee members would have revealed to the Canberra Times the following information. The Committee, which was only established earlier this year, has so far received close to 1,000 submissions. The Committee, apart from concluding its consideration of the term of reference concerning the retiring age of judges, has barely commenced the investigatory stage of the inquiry and to date has held public hearings in Canberra and Sydney only. The Committee will not be in a position to formulate a view in relation to its other terms of reference until after an extensive and thorough examination of all the evidence presented to it by way of submission or the public hearings that we intend to hold.

The Committee over the next six months will be holding public hearings in every capital city in Australia and in a number of regional centres. In a couple of weeks time we will be having a two-day public hearing in the city of Adelaide, and next month it will be Townsville's turn for one day and Brisbane's for two days. The Committee is developing a seminar or workshop program to facilitate further public consultation. The Committee has commenced and will continue an extensive process of inspections of, and discussions with, facilities and personnel connected with family law in Australia. The Committee will not be reporting to the Parliament until August next year.

I would also point to the inaccuracy of some of the reported statements in the Canberra Times in relation to the recommendations of the 1980 review of the Family Law Act. The majority recommendations in this report did not recommend the abolition of the Family Law Council or the Australian Institute of Family Studies.

It appears from this article that Mr Monk has certain views on certain aspects of the Family Law Act. Many of those who have made submissions to the Committee would support some of the suggestions for reform attributed to Mr Monk, just as many do not. Recommendations on issues such as joint custody, an issue which has been raised by Mr Monk, can only be made after the Committee has examined the various viewpoints presented to it and should not be predetermined. The Committee is extremely careful not to predetermine any of the reference points that have been given to it prior to a full and detailed examination. It would seem that it would come as a surprise to Mr Monk to learn that some parent organisations do not support his views on this particular question.

The Committee is involved in a serious examination of the issues contained in its terms of reference. The inquiry will involve the most rigorous assessment of the Family Law Act yet undertaken. Neither the Committee nor individual members, other than on the question of the retiring age of judges on which the Committee has already reported to Parliament, have determined a view on any of the other issues with which it is concerned.

Whereas the Canberra Times has reported on the personal views of one individual, the Committee is committed to an objective evaluation of all the issues that relate to its terms of reference. Mr Monk's assertion that the Committee has failed to see that the Family Court system has not succeeded is totally unfounded and, indeed, presumptuous. If such a conclusion is warranted, it will be made only after a proper assessment of the facts. The attack by Mr Monk on the Committee and its members, which the Canberra Times has uncritically reported, is deplorable.

Mr Monk has commented on the Committee's refusal to invite an American consultant on family law issues to Australia to give evidence. The Committee is of the opinion that sufficient evidence would be available in an Australian context without calling upon any number of possible experts from other countries. Indeed, the Committee has no intention of visiting other countries to see what happens in relation to family law there. Mr Monk has attacked some individual Committee colleagues without actually naming them. He is reported in the Canberra Times as saying:
. . . several lawyers on the parliamentary committee and a lot of lawyers in Parliament are making it difficult to change the system.

As Chairman of the Committee, I refute in the strongest possible terms the assertion that Mr Monk is making here. There are a number of people on the Committee--and I am proud to serve with them--who have had legal training. I do not think any of them could now be described as lawyers. It would be more proper to describe them as parliamentarians who have legal training. It is unfortunate that Mr Monk chose to single out some individual Committee members.

On previous occasions I have made the assertion that at times this chamber and the other place can be a coward's castle where individual honourable members and senators can make attacks on individuals who do not have the same rights as we do--that is, parliamentary privilege. I have restrained myself very strongly in speaking tonight and have not perhaps been as forthright in my criticism of Mr Monk as I would have liked to be. I do not want to abuse the privilege that I have available to me in this place as a serving senator in the Australian Parliament.

Mr Monk has been in constant contact with a number of members of the Committee at various times and with the secretariat on a regular and frequent basis and yet, despite all his contact and his reported interest in the subject matter the Committee is inquiring into, he has not seen fit to address a submission to the Committee. I dare say that this will not be the last occasion on which the Committee or, indeed, the Parliament hears from Mr Monk.

Finally, on behalf of the Committee I have addressed a letter to the Canberra Times indicating our objections to the manner in which it published the comments by Mr Monk. I have expressed our view that it is unfortunate that it did not seek to consult us. I have also taken the opportunity to make contact with the individual reporter, Mr Michael Bachelard, to give him of a copy of the letter. I informed him that I would be speaking here tonight and I have indicated that he will be provided with a copy of the Senate debate after the pinks have been checked for accuracy. That is something that the Canberra Times, the individual reporter and Mr Monk have not sought to do for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Tonight I wish to take a few moments of the Senate's time to discuss the need for access to accountants' papers under self-assessment to be legally confidential. One of my major concerns since the introduction of self-assessment and other major changes within the Australian income tax system has been the protection of the taxpayers' rights. Tonight I refer to the fact that, under a system of self-assessment, a taxpayer's discussions with his tax agent are not formally recognised or enshrined in law as being confidential. This is in direct contrast to the situation of a taxpayer discussing his affairs with a solicitor.

SPEECH.PARA: The law as it presently stands recognises that confidentiality exists between a solicitor and his client, but not necessarily between a tax agent and his client. In Australia at the moment we have over 27,000 registered tax agents, who prepare over 70 per cent of all non-company tax returns and generate 55 per cent of the income tax collected annually. In relation to company returns, the proportion is a lot higher. Therefore, the significance of the role played by registered tax agents in the efficient administration of the income tax system and of the support role they play can readily be seen.

In order for self-assessment to operate satisfactorily, taxpayers need to be able to approach their tax advisers--primarily accountants who are registered tax agents--secure in the knowledge that they can fully disclose to those agents all of the circumstances involving income derivation, expenditures and other possible deduction entitlements. At the same time, the taxpayer needs to be able to obtain confidential advice from his agent which is protected from disclosure to the Australian Taxation Office in circumstances similar to those applying to a lawyer.

Under full self-assessment, all taxpayers will be obliged to prepare returns based on the advice obtained from their tax agents on the basis of a full disclosure of their affairs to the agents. Even though only a small number of returns lodged would be subject to an audit in a particular year, taxpayers still need to be confident that the advice obtained will cover

all the advantages and disadvantages and that the arguments are protected from disclosure. Unless this is the case, a full and frank discussion cannot occur. Further, clients when contacting their agents intuitively act on the assumption that the communications with their accountants are confidential. So the relationship of trust and mutual respect is vital to a tax agent discharging his duty in the same way as in the relationship between a client and a solicitor.

I do not wish to condemn the Government completely because much has already been done. As a result of lobbying in November 1989 by various organisations representing accountants, the ATO has issued a set of accountants access guidelines. These guidelines, which continue in force, recognise that in normal business dealings taxpayers are able to consult their accountants on a confidential basis. Their basic reason for existence is to limit the exercise of the Commissioner's access powers under sections 263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Unfettered use of the powers under section 263 would permit access by the Commissioner and his officers to all documents prepared in the course of an agent's work. However, let me say again that these are only guidelines. They do not have legal status.

These accountants access guidelines were to be reviewed in November 1990, but in the initial discussions of the review the Australian Taxation Office has decided that confidentiality could not be extended should a taxpayer wish to exercise his or her rights of review before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the courts. Confidentiality was assumed in 1989 to extend to the litigation process but the adoption of the stance of the Australian Taxation Office on the lack of confidentiality in the courts has called into question for a time the workability of those guidelines announced in 1989. However, the AustralianTaxation Office has now relented and has agreed that the access guidelines should apply subject to certain qualifications in the course of litigation.

What I am concerned about is that all these guidelines have only ever been guidelines. There is nothing enshrined in the statute books as to the confidentiality of the process between the agent and his client. To ensure taxpayers' rights and to restore taxpayers' confidence in their agents in that relationship, the Government should consider enshrining in law the confidentiality of discussions between tax agents and clients. I seek the support of the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what way is the Australian content of Australian defence capital equipment contracts determined.
(2) What factors are taken into account in determining the Australian content of a contract.

(3) Is any consideration given to: (a) the degree of foreign ownership of a contractor; (b) the proportion of the contract price to be spent in Australia; or (c) the proportion of work-time performed in Australia; if not, why not.

(4) (a) Who supplies the data from which Australian content estimates are made; and (b) if the data comes from the contractor, does the Department of Defence evaluate the contractor's data independently; if not, why not.

(5) (a) Was the Australian content of the ANZAC frigate project estimated prior to the award of the contract; if not, why not; and (b) in what way is the Australian content of the ANZAC frigate project currently monitored now that construction is underway.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian content of major capital equipment contracts is equivalent to the difference between the total contract value and the value of the goods imported under the contract.
(2) The Australian content in major capital equipment contracts is determined on a case by case basis taking into account the following principal factors:
Defence self-reliance objectives, for through life support;
the relative costs of importation versus Australian production of principal equipments and follow-on spares; and
the Government's Defence Industry development policies.

(3) (a) No. The degree of foreign ownership of a contractor is not a consideration. However, to qualify as Australian content the work must be carried out in Australia by either an established Australian company or Australian subsidiary of the overseas contractor. Where an overseas contractor establishes a company in Australia in order to comply with the Australian content requirements of a defence contract, an important factor is the demonstration of viability beyond the life of the contract.
(b) and (c) Yes.
(4) (a) Contractors are required to supply the data in responding to Requests for Tender as part of the competitive tendering process.
(b) Defence carries out independent assessments of contractors' estimates utilising cost investigators where appropriate.
(5) (a) Yes. Australian content was a principal source selection consideration leading to contract award and is a contract deliverable subject to payment of liquidated damages for non-performance.

(b) There is continuous monitoring of the contractor's achievement against contractual obligations. The contract includes detailed reporting and monitoring mechanisms which are obligations on the contractor and it provides for verification of progressive achievement by the Project Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 16 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the World Health Organisation's international code of marketing of breast milk substitutes be fully implemented.
(2) Why has the Australian Government neglected the nutritional advice of the World Health Organisation in relation to breast milk substitutes.
(3) Which is more important: (a) the health of infants; or (b) the profits of companies marketing breast milk substitutes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has been implementing the World Health Organization's (WHO) international code of practice for the marketing of breast milk substitutes (the WHO Code) progressively since it was an early signatory to it in the World Health Assembly in 1981.
In keeping with the aims and principles of the WHO Code, actions taken by the Government to implement the WHO Code in Australia include:
the negotiation of an Industry Code of Practice for the Marketing of Infant Formula in 1983 and last signed in 1986 (now under review following the Trade Practices Commission report);
the incorporation of the relevant articles of the WHO Code into the Food Standards Code; thereby regulating the quality, composition and labelling of foods for infants and young children;

the incorporation of the relevant articles of the WHO Code into Dairy Orders of the Export Control Act, thereby regulating the quality, composition and labelling of infants foods exported from Australia;
establishment of a Working Party of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to prepare guidelines on implementation of the Code;

distribution of the subsequent paper, Report of the Working Party on Implementation of the WHO International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes, to all States and Territories and to the Colleges of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and of Paediatrics. The report also continues to be distributed among health workers;
preparation and distribution of a booklet `Baby's first food', a publication which is directed to pregnant women and is available in 16 languages as well as English;

provision of a grant under the National Health Promotion Program to make available to nurses, midwives and others concerned with the care of lactating women, 5 000 copies of the book Successful Breastfeeding by the Royal College of Midwives.

I recently announced, in conjunction with the Bureau of Consumer Affairs, that a meeting of industry, consumer, and non-government representatives is to be convened in October 1991. The meeting is to provide a forum in which to consider the development of sector specific codes of practice for Australia and the authorisation of the existing Industry Code of Practice for the Marketing of Infant Formula under the Trade Practices Act. These will define the self-regulation of marketing of products covered by the WHO Code, and will include monitoring.
(2) Australia has never neglected the nutritional advice of the WHO in relation to breast milk substitutes.

On the contrary, Australia is considered by WHO as an exemplary country in relation to implementation of the WHO Code. This is evidenced by the recent invitation from WHO for Australia to participate in an international review of implementation of the Code, on the tenth anniversary of its ratification, together with three other countries in the Western Pacific Region. The chief purpose of the review is to provide advice and experiences from countries where infants are primarily breastfed and infant health morbidity and mortality are low, to those countries where the WHO Code could be implemented more effectively.
The review should provide a useful analysis of government and non-government strategies used in Australia to promote breastfeeding and to implement the WHO Code.

(3) (a) is more important. The nutritional, immunological and other unique benefits which human milk confer to both mother and infant are well-recognised and the NHMRC and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the optimal method for feeding infants for at least the first 4-6 months of life, where this is possible.
